Name: AskUI vs Robot Framework: Visual AI vs Keyword Test Tool
Post Body:
AskUI vs Robot Framework: Which One Is Right for Your QA Strategy?

AskUI and Robot Framework serve different ends of the test automation spectrum.
If you're evaluating tools for cross-platform UI automation or looking to simplify QA with AI and natural language, this guide breaks down the core differences‚Äîfast.

AskUI enables test automation through visual UI recognition and plain English prompts.
Robot Framework uses keyword-based scripting and thrives in traditional, code-driven pipelines.

Let‚Äôs compare them across use cases, technical skills, and deployment needs.

AskUI: AI-Driven Visual Automation

AskUI enables automation by visually identifying and interacting with UI elements across platforms‚Äîjust like a human would. This makes it ideal for automating applications where traditional DOM selectors fail (e.g., canvas apps, Citrix, desktop GUIs).

Key Capabilities:

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Turn plain English prompts into automated workflows.
  • Cross-platform support: Automate desktop, web, mobile, and canvas applications.
  • Pretrained models: Use adaptable AI models (e.g., UIDT) to recognize elements and adapt to UI changes.
  • Flexible deployment: Run locally, in the cloud, or hybrid.
  • Tool integration: Supports Docker, Jenkins, Zapier, n8n.

Robot Framework: Open-Source Keyword-Based Automation

Robot Framework is widely used in both test automation and robotic process automation (RPA). It offers a flexible syntax and is extended via community-built libraries.

Key Capabilities:

  • Human-readable syntax: Built on keywords, suitable for collaborative test development.
  • Extensibility: Add libraries using Python, Java, or .NET.
  • Large open-source ecosystem: Active community and rich third-party library support.
  • Zero license cost: 100% open source, making it accessible for all teams.

AskUI vs Robot Framework: Feature Comparison

Feature AskUI Robot Framework
Target Applications Desktop, Web, Android, Canvas Test automation & RPA
AI Integration Yes ‚Äì Visual AI + NLP No
Programming Skills Required Minimal (Plain English Prompts) Low to Medium (Keyword-based + Python/Java)
Open Source Open Source SDK; SaaS backend Yes
Community Support Focused product community Large global open-source community
Deployment On-premise, Cloud, Hybrid Tool-integrated environments

When Should You Use AskUI?

AskUI is the right fit if:

  • You need to automate non-standard UIs like canvas or Citrix.
  • Your team lacks deep coding experience.
  • You want AI-powered automation that adapts to UI changes.
  • You prefer writing test logic in plain English.

When Should You Use Robot Framework?

Robot Framework works best if:

  • You rely on a strong open-source community.
  • Your workflows are heavily keyword- or script-driven.
  • Your team is comfortable with Python/Java.
  • You want maximum flexibility and cost-efficiency.

Unique Advantages of AskUI

  1. Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Execute complex automation using natural language commands.
  2. AI-Powered Element Detection: Interact with UI based on visual cues rather than DOM structure.
  3. Cross-Platform Coverage: Automate beyond browsers‚Äîdesktop, Android, Linux, and more.
  4. Hybrid Deployment: Choose between local, cloud, or hybrid setups based on compliance needs.

Internal Resources

  • AskUI vs Cypress: A Comparison
  • Building Agentic AI Pipelines
  • Agentic AI for Desktop Testing

FAQ

Q: How do AskUI and Robot Framework work together in a hybrid setup?
A: AskUI excels at visually automating UI tasks, especially for non-standard interfaces like canvas or Citrix. Robot Framework can complement it by handling backend logic, validations, and API-based test flows‚Äîmaking them ideal for hybrid QA pipelines.

Q: Which parts of AskUI are open-source, and which are proprietary?
A: The AskUI SDK is fully open-source and available on GitHub for integration and customization. However, the AI inference backend (which powers the visual understanding) is SaaS-based or deployable on-premise for enterprise environments.

Q: Can Robot Framework be used for mobile app testing?
A: Robot Framework does not natively support mobile automation. However, it can be integrated with mobile testing tools like Appium to enable Android and iOS test execution within the same keyword-driven framework.

Name: AskUI vs Selenium: Verified Feature Comparison for QA Teams
Post Body:
AskUI vs Selenium: Verified Feature Comparison for QA Teams

AskUI is an AI-based automation tool that interacts with desktop, web, Android, and canvas applications through computer vision and natural language commands.
Selenium is an open-source web automation framework primarily used for browser testing via scripted code.

Key Differences Between AskUI and Selenium

Feature AskUI Selenium
Target Applications Desktop, Web, Android, Canvas Web only
AI Integration Visual recognition + natural language processing No AI features
Programming Requirement Minimal; plain-English commands supported Moderate to advanced; scripting required
Cross-Browser Testing Visual layer across browsers and OS WebDriver & Grid manage cross-browser setups
Platform Support macOS, Windows, Android, Linux Multi-platform with setup variation
Deployment On-premise, cloud, hybrid Local, Selenium Grid

AskUI Core Capabilities

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Converts plain-language instructions into automated actions.
  • UIDT Models: AI-based UI detection tailored to varied interfaces.
  • Deployment Flexibility: Supports cloud, hybrid, and on-premise workflows.
  • Integrations: Compatible with Zapier, Jenkins, Docker, and n8n.

Selenium Component Overview

  • WebDriver: Enables code-based control of browser sessions.
  • Selenium IDE: Record-and-playback tool for quick test creation.
  • Selenium Grid: Enables parallel testing across different environments.

Which Tool Fits Better by Scenario?

Use Case Recommended Tool
Web-only with detailed logic Selenium
Multi-platform automation AskUI
Fast setup with low-code teams AskUI
Custom scripting flexibility Selenium

AskUI vs Selenium: Summary of Strengths

Tool Strengths Limitations
AskUI - Cross-platform UI automation
- Minimal coding
- Visual automation using NLP 		- Less precise for complex DOM structures
Selenium - Full browser control
- Mature community
- Highly customizable 		- Web-only
- Higher code maintenance

FAQ

Q: Can AskUI fully replace Selenium for web testing?
A: No. Selenium is more precise for code-driven, DOM-based validation.

Q: Is Selenium outdated due to AI tools?
A: No. Selenium remains essential for scripted browser automation.

Q: Can the two be used together?
A: Yes. Teams often use AskUI for UI automation and Selenium for browser control.

Final Recommendation

AskUI is best for cross-platform UI testing with minimal coding and fast ramp-up. Selenium is better suited for developers needing fine-grained control over browser behavior. Use both tools complementarily depending on your team‚Äôs technical setup and application architecture.

Name: AskUI vs SikuliX: Which Visual Automation Tool Fits Your QA Needs?
Post Body:
What Is the Key Difference Between AskUI and SikuliX?

AskUI uses AI-driven vision and natural language input for automation, while SikuliX relies on image recognition and scripting. This defines their core usage and integration approaches.

What Is AskUI?

AskUI is a visual automation tool powered by AI that allows users to automate applications using natural language instructions. It processes UI elements with pretrained computer vision models.

Core Features:

  • AI Vision Models: Detect UI components with pretrained and retrainable models.
  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Translates natural language commands into UI actions.
  • Cross-Platform Support: Supports Windows, macOS, Linux, and native mobile platforms.
  • Deployment Options: Offers cloud, on-premise, and hybrid setups using Docker or virtual machines.
  • Integrations: Compatible with tools such as Zapier, n8n, Jenkins, and Docker.

What Is SikuliX?

SikuliX is an open-source automation tool that relies on image recognition using OpenCV to interact with graphical user interfaces.

Core Features:

  • Image-Based Scripting: Uses image patterns to locate UI elements.
  • Integrated IDE: Includes its own scripting IDE and supports Java, Jython, JRuby, Scala, and other JVM languages.
  • Platform Support: Works on Windows, macOS, and most Linux/Unix systems.
  • OCR Integration: Uses Tesseract for basic optical character recognition.
  • Multi-Monitor Support: Allows automation across multiple monitors and remote systems, with some limitations.

AskUI vs SikuliX: Feature Comparison Table

Feature AskUI SikuliX
Core Technology AI-driven vision technology Image recognition using OpenCV
Input Method Natural Language Instructions Image-based scripting/programming
Cross-Application Yes Yes
Platform Support Windows, macOS, Linux, native Mobile Windows, macOS, Linux/Unix
Scripting Zapier, n8n, Jenkins, Docker integrations Dedicated IDE and JVM language support
OCR Retrainable proprietary model Basic OCR via Tesseract
Multi-Monitor Yes, including remote interaction support Yes, with limitations

AskUI vs SikuliX: Performance Comparison

What does official documentation say about performance?

Neither AskUI nor SikuliX provides standardized performance benchmarks such as execution time or latency.

Metric AskUI SikuliX
Execution Approach AI model inference via cloud or on-prem Local OpenCV-based image search
Parallel Execution Supported (Docker, VM, CI/CD) Script-based setup required
Headless Execution Supported Partial support (manual setup)
OCR Engine Retrainable proprietary model Tesseract OCR
Note: These comparisons are based on official documentation and architectural design. No formal latency or performance metrics are publicly available.

Why Choose AskUI?

  • Natural Language Input: Enables non-technical users to create test scenarios.
  • Cross-Platform + Mobile Support: Suitable for teams working across multiple environments.
  • Flexible Deployment: Supports enterprise needs with on-premise and Docker setups.

Why Choose SikuliX?

  • Image-Based Simplicity: Useful for legacy systems without code access.
  • JVM Language Support: Integrates well with Java ecosystems.
  • Open Source: No licensing costs.

FAQs

Does AskUI provide official performance benchmarks?

No. AskUI does not currently publish latency or benchmark data.

What OCR engine does SikuliX use?

SikuliX uses the open-source Tesseract OCR engine.

Can both tools support multi-monitor setups?

Yes. Both support multi-monitor environments, although SikuliX may have some limitations depending on configuration.

Name: AskUI vs SmartBear TestComplete: Which UI Test Automation Tool Fits Your Team?
Post Body:
Updated: June 2025

What‚Äôs the key difference between AskUI and TestComplete?

AskUI focuses on AI-powered, vision-based UI automation across platforms using natural language inputs. TestComplete emphasizes robust, code-free or coded test automation with SmartBear HaloAI enhancements.

Both tools help QA teams streamline UI testing, but their strengths differ based on team structure, test complexity, and technical needs.

How does AskUI‚Äôs AI-driven approach work?

AskUI uses computer vision and natural language to automate UI interactions. It mimics human behavior by recognizing UI elements visually rather than relying on fragile selectors.

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Converts plain English commands into UI actions
  • UIDT model: Learns and adapts from user-provided data
  • PTA-1 architecture: 270M parameter model built on Florence-2, hosted on Hugging Face
  • No-code automation: Ideal for QA teams with minimal coding experience
  • Supported OS: MacOS, Windows, Android, Linux

AskUI supports local, cloud, and hybrid deployments and integrates with Zapier, Docker, Jenkins, and more. It also automates Citrix and Remote Desktop environments using vision-based recognition.

What does TestComplete offer for UI automation?

TestComplete is a mature test automation platform with a wide range of features:

  • Codeless or coded tests: Record-and-replay or script-based workflows
  • SmartBear HaloAI: For OCR, self-healing tests, and test data generation
  • Broad integration: Works with Git, Jira, Jenkins, Azure DevOps
  • Over 500 UI controls supported
  • Free trial with access to 500+ remote test environments

Its strength lies in GUI testing across web, desktop, and mobile apps.

AskUI vs TestComplete: Feature Comparison Table

Feature AskUI TestComplete
Target Applications Desktop, Web, Mobile, Canvas, Citrix Desktop, Web, Mobile
AI Integration Visual recognition, natural language (PTA-1) HaloAI: OCR, visual testing, self-healing
User Interaction Prompt-to-Action (PTA), no-code scripting Codeless + coded, record and replay
Deployment Local, Cloud, Hybrid Local, Cloud
Key Focus AI-first automation for any skill level Comprehensive UI testing with traditional workflows

What are AskUI‚Äôs unique advantages?

AskUI provides a modern, AI-native experience ideal for future-ready QA teams:

  • Natural Language Interface: Automate with simple English commands
  • Cross-platform coverage: Supports canvas-based, Citrix, desktop, and mobile apps
  • Minimal setup: No need to define fragile selectors manually
  • Customizable AI: Train models with your own data (PTA-1)

These strengths make it well-suited for startups, SMEs, and teams seeking agility.

When should teams choose TestComplete?

Choose TestComplete if you need:

  • Enterprise-grade support and documentation
  • Support for legacy systems with standard object repositories
  • Integration with DevOps pipelines and enterprise tools
  • Flexibility between codeless and coded tests

It is especially valuable in large organizations with mixed-technical QA teams.

Internal Resources for Further Reading

  • AskUI vs Selenium: Verified Feature Comparison
  • Agentic AI in Desktop Test Automation

FAQs

How beginner-friendly is AskUI for non-technical users?

AskUI's Prompt-to-Action enables users without coding knowledge to automate tasks using natural language instructions.Yes. AskUI's Prompt-to-Action enables anyone to automate tasks using natural language.

Does TestComplete support AI?

Yes. TestComplete includes SmartBear HaloAI for visual testing, OCR, and test data generation.

What deployment modes does AskUI support (local, cloud, hybrid)?

AskUI supports hybrid, local, and cloud deployments, providing flexibility for different IT environments.Yes. AskUI supports hybrid, local, and cloud deployments.

Can AskUI automate Citrix and remote desktops?

Yes. AskUI uses vision-based detection to automate applications in Citrix and remote desktop environments.

Is TestComplete better for traditional teams?

Yes. It offers familiar test creation tools and integrations preferred by enterprise QA teams.

Name: AskUI vs TestArchitect: Which UI Automation Tool Is Right for You?
Post Body:
Updated: June 2025

AskUI vs TestArchitect: Which UI Automation Tool Is Right for You?

What are the key differences between AskUI and TestArchitect?

AskUI and TestArchitect serve different test automation needs. AskUI is AI-driven and enables natural language automation across platforms, while TestArchitect is a codeless, keyword-based tool focusing on team collaboration and scalability.

What is AskUI?

AskUI is an AI-powered UI automation tool that uses computer vision and natural language processing. It supports desktop, web, and canvas-based applications, and works across macOS, Windows, and Linux.

  • No coding required ‚Äî users can describe actions in plain English.
  • Uses Prompt-to-Action (PTA) for task execution.
  • Adapts to UI changes with visual recognition.
  • Flexible deployment: local, cloud, or hybrid.
  • Integrates with Zapier, n8n, Jenkins, Docker.

What is TestArchitect?

TestArchitect is a codeless automation platform using keyword-driven testing. It supports team collaboration through Action-Based Testing Language (ABTL).

  • Suitable for web, web services, desktop, image, and database testing.
  • Provides an IDE and prebuilt action libraries.
  • Enables collaboration between business and technical testers.
  • Supports CI/CD tools for continuous testing.

Feature Comparison Table

Feature AskUI TestArchitect
Target Applications Cross-platform: desktop, web, Android, canvas Web, web services, desktop, image, database
AI Integration Visual recognition + NLP None
User Interaction Natural language (Prompt-to-Action) Keyword-based (ABTL + IDE)
Deployment Local, cloud, hybrid Supports CI/CD tools
Primary Strength AI-powered UI automation accessible to all skill levels Scalable, team-focused keyword automation

What makes AskUI stand out?

AskUI brings visual AI and NLP to test automation, bridging the gap between technical and non-technical users. With PTA, users can instruct the system in plain English. This makes UI automation faster, more intuitive, and more resilient to UI changes.

Key differentiators:

  • Visual UI recognition mimics human-like interaction.
  • Pre-trained and customizable AI models.
  • Works without relying on fragile selectors.

Who should choose TestArchitect?

Choose TestArchitect if you want a structured, keyword-driven approach and need to scale team-wide collaboration in enterprise testing. It‚Äôs ideal for organizations with established QA workflows who value codeless scripting with domain-specific language.

Best for:

  • QA teams with mixed technical expertise.
  • Organizations needing cross-platform test management.
  • CI/CD-driven environments.

Frequently Asked Questions

1. Can non-technical users automate UI workflows with AskUI?
Yes. AskUI lets users define automation flows in plain English using Prompt-to-Action, removing the need for coding or technical scripting knowledge.

2. Does TestArchitect include any AI-driven automation features?
No. TestArchitect relies on keyword-driven testing without visual AI or natural language processing.

3. Is AskUI deployment-ready for enterprise QA teams?
Yes. AskUI supports enterprise-grade use cases with flexible deployment options, including on-premise, cloud, and hybrid models.

4. How do CI/CD capabilities differ between AskUI and TestArchitect?
Both tools integrate with CI/CD pipelines, but AskUI supports modern DevOps tools like Docker and Jenkins, while TestArchitect is more aligned with legacy enterprise CI workflows.

‚Äç

Name: AskUI vs Testers.AI: Feature-by-Feature Comparison for QA Leaders
Post Body:
What‚Äôs the Key Difference Between AskUI and Testers.AI?

AskUI automates user interfaces using visual recognition and plain-language commands. Testers.AI delivers AI-generated insights that simulate expert-level QA review.

This comparison helps QA Managers and Test Automation Leads choose the right tool based on automation goals and testing depth. While both tools offer valuable capabilities, AskUI stands out with its unique blend of vision-based interaction and natural language automation‚Äîbringing intuitive control to modern QA teams.

What Is AskUI?

AskUI is a computer-vision-based automation platform that mimics human interaction across diverse interfaces‚Äîdesktop, web, mobile, and canvas.

  • Detects visual elements for robust automation
  • Supports natural-language task inputs through PTA (Prompt-to-Action)
  • Offers local, cloud, and hybrid deployments
  • Runs on MacOS, Windows, Android, Linux
  • Connects with Zapier, n8n, Docker, Jenkins, and more

What Is Testers.AI?

Testers.AI simulates the mindset of expert testers to produce high-quality assessments of your application‚Äôs performance and UX.

  • Mirrors the reasoning of elite QA professionals (e.g., Jason Arbon approach)
  • Provides summaries, usability findings, performance diagnostics
  • Offers exploratory AI testing, issue triage, and benchmarking
  • Outputs structured results in JSON for enterprise integration

AskUI vs Testers.AI: Feature Comparison Table

‚Äç

Feature AskUI Testers.AI
Target Applications Multi-platform: desktop, mobile, canvas, web Primarily app-focused: UI/UX, performance, accessibility, API, content
AI Capabilities Visual element detection + plain-language automation AI-modeled expert logic to generate QA insights
User Commands Type natural language to initiate UI workflows Automated UX feedback and usability findings
Deployment Options Supports both on-prem and cloud deployments Deployment mode not specified
Main Use Case Automation for UI flows across environments Expert-level validation without writing test scripts

Why Choose AskUI?

  • Screen-Based Element Detection: Automates tasks based on how elements visually appear on screen.
  • Conversational UI Control: Launch actions using descriptive English phrases.
  • End-to-End Support: Automates beyond the browser‚Äîincluding desktop apps and hybrid environments.
  • Custom AI Training: Fine-tune AskUI‚Äôs vision and interaction logic for domain-specific tasks.

AskUI not only helps QA engineers work faster but also empowers non-technical stakeholders to contribute to automation, making it a strategic asset for agile teams.

Why Choose Testers.AI?

  • Enterprise-Ready Reports: JSON-formatted results streamline CI/CD and dashboards.
  • Market Insight Layer: Offers competitor comparison features for benchmarking apps.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

Is AskUI beginner-friendly for non-engineers?

Yes. Its language-based input system means even non-developers can build automation flows.

Can Testers.AI be used for visual UI automation?

No. Testers.AI focuses on analysis and reporting. It does not interact with the UI like a human.

Are AskUI and Testers.AI compatible in workflows?

Yes. AskUI can automate workflows while Testers.AI provides QA feedback on the same apps.

Does Testers.AI integrate with enterprise tools?

Yes. Its results are structured in JSON format and can be integrated into CI/CD pipelines.

Final Verdict

Need hands-on UI interaction and workflow control? Choose AskUI.

Looking to enhance QA with AI-generated insight reports? Go with Testers.AI.

Name: AskUI vs Testsigma: Which Test Automation Tool Fits Your Team?
Post Body:
What is AskUI?

AskUI is an AI-driven test automation platform that uses visual recognition and natural language processing to intelligently navigate applications. It seamlessly automates workflows across desktop, web, mobile, and canvas-based UIs, minimizing fragile code dependencies.

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Lets teams create automation flows in plain English, so even non-developers can contribute to test scenarios.
  • Pre-trained & Custom Models: Offers out-of-the-box automation frameworks like PTA and UIDT, while also supporting tailored models built on your data.
  • Flexible Deployment: Supports MacOS, Windows, Linux, and Android, with options for on-premise, cloud, or hybrid‚Äîideal for companies with strict data governance.
  • Integration Ecosystem: Connects with Zapier, n8n, Docker, Jenkins and more, adapting easily to existing pipelines.

Many QA teams choose AskUI to lower maintenance costs, since visual automation tends to be less brittle against frequent UI changes‚Äîhelping extend test lifespan and stability.

What is Testsigma?

Testsigma is a cloud-based platform for unified test automation, designed to accelerate end-to-end QA cycles with its broad device lab and AI-enhanced scripting.

  • Test Coverage: Handles web, mobile, desktop, API, and Salesforce testing.
  • GenAI Scripting: Allows teams to generate and maintain tests in natural language with generative AI assistance.
  • Distributed Device Lab: Runs tests across 3000+ browser and device combinations in the cloud.
  • Extensive Resources: Includes tutorials, documentation, blogs, and webinars to support onboarding and scaling.

As enterprises move toward multi-platform products, many look to tools like Testsigma for large-scale cloud executions and quick coverage expansion.

How Do AskUI and Testsigma Compare?

Here‚Äôs a side-by-side feature comparison to help identify which solution best aligns with your QA priorities.

Feature AskUI Testsigma
Target Applications Desktop, web, mobile, canvas Web, mobile, desktop, API, Salesforce
AI Integration Visual recognition + natural language GenAI-powered automation
User Interaction Define flows in plain English (PTA) Plain English scripts + GenAI generation
Deployment On-prem, cloud, hybrid Cloud-only
Primary Focus Making UI automation accessible to diverse teams Accelerating large-scale end-to-end testing

Why Teams Prefer AskUI

  • Plain English Automation: AskUI‚Äôs PTA bridges gaps between QA and business users, enabling broader team collaboration without code.
  • Non-Browser Interfaces: Excels at automating desktop and canvas-based UIs that many tools overlook.
  • Controlled Deployment: On-premise and hybrid setups keep sensitive data in-house, supporting compliance in regulated sectors.

This approach ensures AskUI stays subtly positioned as a versatile, security-conscious choice without overt sales language.

When to Consider Testsigma

  • Cloud Scale: Best for organizations that prioritize vast device/browser coverage with minimal infrastructure overhead.
  • AI Maintenance: GenAI streamlines test creation and upkeep, reducing manual intervention.
  • Onboarding Resources: Their rich library of guides helps teams quickly get productive.

FAQs: AskUI vs Testsigma

Do both platforms support no-code or low-code automation?

Yes. AskUI uses natural language-driven flows (PTA) while Testsigma combines plain English scripting with GenAI-powered test building.

Which is better for non-browser automation like desktop apps or design canvases?

AskUI stands out here, using visual AI to automate native desktop and canvas interfaces that many cloud platforms don‚Äôt fully handle.

Can Testsigma be deployed on-premise?

No. Testsigma is built exclusively for cloud use. For teams needing local or hybrid deployments, AskUI offers those options.

Name: AskUI vs Traditional QA Tools: A Factual Comparison for 2025
Post Body:
Why Traditional UI Test Automation Tools Face Limitations

Most established UI test tools such as Selenium, Cypress, and Playwright use selectors to interact with web elements through the DOM. These include identifiers like id, class, or XPath, which must be kept consistent for tests to remain reliable.

In modern UI development environments, especially those powered by LLMs or no-code platforms, layouts and element structures can change frequently. This leads to increased test failures and high maintenance overhead when using selector-based automation tools.

How AskUI Uses a Visual-First Approach

AskUI offers a fundamentally different method: it automates UI tasks by visually interpreting the screen, similar to how a human would. Instead of relying on DOM structures or internal code, it interacts with visible UI components based on pixel and text recognition.

Feature Selector-Based Tools
(Selenium, Cypress, etc.)		 AskUI
UI interaction method DOM element selectors Vision-based screen understanding
Platform support Browser-based only Cross-platform (Windows, macOS, Linux, Android)
Test authoring Code required (JavaScript, Python, etc.) Natural language or Python wrapper
Resistance to UI layout changes Low (selectors must be updated) High (position-aware visual matching)
CI/CD integration Supported Supported (PyTest, GitHub Actions)

What ‚ÄúLaunching Chat‚Äù Does As Shown in the Demo

In a live demo by AskUI CEO Jonas, the AskUI agent completed a UI test on an Android emulator using only a single natural language prompt:

üß† Example Prompt from the Demo:
‚ÄúPlease increase the temperature on the right seat by one degree through the UI.‚Äù

Here's what occurred:

  • The agent connected to the emulator
  • Captured and analyzed the screen
  • Identified the fan icon and +1 button
  • Executed the clicks
  • Verified the temperature had increased

This process involved no DOM access, scripting, or API integration only vision-based automation.

Later in the same demo, AskUI was shown working with a Windows desktop app via PyTest, executing test flows, asserting results, and generating a visual test report with screenshots and logs.

Example of a Prompt-Driven UI Test

AskUI tests can be written in natural language or integrated with Python test scripts.

This allows developers, QA testers, and even non-technical team members to define test flows in plain language.
When AskUI Is the Right Tool
AskUI is particularly well-suited for teams that:
  • Work across operating systems or platforms
  • Use LLM-generated, visual, or rapidly changing UIs
  • Prefer fast iteration over manual script maintenance
  • Need visual confirmation that workflows behave correctly
It complements but does not replace all testing types.
For backend logic, unit tests, or DOM-level attribute validation, traditional tools may still be the better choice.
Output and Reporting
When running tests through AskUI:
  • Every step is documented with screenshots
  • Agent decision points are logged
  • Assertions are stored in a readable test report
This can be integrated directly into CI/CD pipelines like GitHub Actions or Jenkins via PyTest.
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
Does AskUI require code to write tests?
No. You can use plain English to define test steps. For advanced use, a Python interface is available.
Can I use AskUI with desktop apps?
Yes. AskUI supports automation across Windows, macOS, Linux, and Android environments.
What types of testing is AskUI best for?
AskUI is designed for visual regression, UI workflow validation, and functional testing through user-visible elements.
Can I still use Selenium or Cypress with AskUI?
Yes. AskUI can complement traditional tools when visual accuracy or OS-level automation is required.

Name: AskUI vs Ui.Vision RPA: Which UI Automation Tool Fits Your Team?
Post Body:
Updated: July 2025

What‚Äôs the key difference between AskUI and Ui.Vision RPA?

AskUI uses AI vision and natural language to automate complex multi-application workflows, while Ui.Vision RPA is an open-source tool focused on visual desktop and browser automation using image and text recognition.

Overview: AskUI vs Ui.Vision RPA

Both tools aim to reduce manual UI testing for QA teams and test automation leaders, but they differ significantly in technology, scalability, and how they handle change.

‚Äç

Feature AskUI Ui.Vision RPA
Technology AI vision, NLP Computer vision, OCR
Platform Support Windows, MacOS, Linux, Mobile Windows, MacOS, Linux
Use Cases Web, desktop, canvas, Android Desktop & browser via extensions
Key Features PTA, human-first UI, CI/CD, integrations Visual testing, Citrix & SAP, CLI
Pricing Commercial, free trial Open-source, paid PRO/Enterprise

How does AskUI work?

AskUI combines AI-powered object recognition with natural language commands. Instead of writing brittle XPath or CSS selectors, you simply tell it, ‚Äúclick the submit button‚Äù or ‚Äútype in the invoice field.‚Äù Its computer vision understands UI elements across apps and platforms.

AskUI also offers robust integration with Docker, Jenkins, Zapier, and n8n, making it easier for large QA teams to embed in existing pipelines. Because it avoids code selectors, AskUI reduces maintenance costs when UI layouts or DOM structures change frequently.

How does Ui.Vision RPA work?

Ui.Vision RPA focuses on codeless automation via computer vision and OCR. It visually scans screens and mimics human interactions based on image and text patterns, without relying on underlying window or DOM details.

This makes it well-suited for automating legacy apps, Citrix, or SAP. Being open-source under GPL, it‚Äôs budget-friendly and keeps data local, which is attractive for teams concerned about cloud dependencies.

Additional facts that matter

  • Test maintenance: AskUI‚Äôs AI adapts to UI or DOM changes better, reducing time spent rewriting selectors. Ui.Vision might need manual updates if image templates or text areas shift.
  • Speed and scale: Ui.Vision is extremely lightweight for simple scripts and proofs of concept, running via browser extensions. AskUI, with Docker or hybrid setups, excels in more complex multi-application workflows.
  • Security options: AskUI explicitly supports secure on-premises deployments for compliance-heavy environments. Ui.Vision, while open source and local by default, may require enterprise agreements for formal SLAs.
  • Developer workflow: Ui.Vision shines with its CLI for direct scripting. AskUI‚Äôs prompt-to-action lowers barriers for non-technical users, allowing manual testers or business analysts to participate in automation.
  • Community & ecosystem: Ui.Vision has an active open-source community with extensive GitHub examples and user forums. AskUI focuses on enterprise partnerships and customer success to drive adoption.

FAQs

Which tool is better for multi-application UI automation?

AskUI. Its AI vision is specifically designed to automate across web, desktop, canvas, iframes, and Android environments, all driven by natural language instructions.

Is Ui.Vision really free?

Yes. It‚Äôs open source under the GPL license, with optional paid PRO and Enterprise tiers for advanced capabilities.

Can both tools integrate into CI/CD pipelines?

Absolutely. AskUI provides native Docker and Jenkins support for scalable deployments. Ui.Vision offers a robust command-line interface, ideal for shell scripts or simple CI/CD jobs.

How well does AskUI handle frequent UI changes?

Very well. Since it relies on AI visual recognition rather than static code selectors, UI changes like DOM shifts or redesigned layouts typically require fewer adjustments.

Is Ui.Vision suitable for quick proofs of concept?

Yes. Teams can install a browser extension and begin recording desktop or web tasks in minutes, making it ideal for validating automation concepts before committing to larger frameworks.

Internal Links

  • See how AskUI compares to SikuliX for visual automation
  • Explore why modern QA teams adopt Agentic AI for test pipelines

Choosing the right tool

Your choice comes down to priorities:

Use Case Best Fit
Rapid small tests & proofs of concept Ui.Vision RPA
Large-scale, multi-application workflows AskUI
Security-critical, on-premises deployments AskUI or Ui.Vision
Teams needing direct CLI scripting Ui.Vision RPA
Non-technical teams favoring natural language AskUI

Name: AskUI vs UiPath: Which Automation Tool Fits Your QA Strategy?
Post Body:
What fundamentally sets AskUI apart from UiPath?

AskUI is purpose-built for AI-driven UI automation, focusing on visually recognizing elements on a screen. In contrast, UiPath serves as a large-scale enterprise platform, orchestrating end-to-end business processes across multiple departments. Their goals are different: AskUI aims to simplify interface interactions, while UiPath targets holistic process transformation.

How does AskUI streamline UI automation for QA teams?

AskUI employs advanced computer vision to interpret screen elements like a human would. Its Prompt-to-Action (PTA) feature lets testers write steps conversationally, without managing fragile selectors or intricate scripts.

üëâ Why this matters:

  • Supports cross-platform automation on Windows, MacOS, and Linux.
  • Handles diverse UI contexts, including desktop apps, browsers, mobile views, and even canvas-heavy interfaces.
  • Integrates effortlessly into CI/CD with Jenkins, n8n, Zapier, or Docker.

This lowers technical hurdles, empowering QA teams of all backgrounds to define tests without deep programming expertise.

Compare AskUI vs SikuliX for multi-platform UI automation ‚Üí

What is UiPath‚Äôs approach to enterprise automation?

UiPath takes automation far beyond the screen. It structures initiatives into three core stages:

  1. Discover: Uses process mining and communications analysis to pinpoint high-value automation opportunities.
  2. Automate: Offers tools for building UI and API workflows, extracting data from documents, and creating low-code apps ‚Äî all underpinned by AI.
  3. Operate: Delivers dashboards, continuous testing, and governance frameworks to maintain reliable automations at scale.

üëâ Ideal for:
Companies seeking to streamline entire business functions, not just QA processes.

Explore how modern QA teams build AI-driven automation pipelines ‚Üí

AskUI vs UiPath: Key feature comparison

Feature AskUI UiPath
Scope of Automation Screen-focused: desktops, browsers, mobile, canvas End-to-end processes across business departments
AI Capabilities Visual recognition + natural language execution AI for mining, building, optimizing workflows
Interaction Model Plain English to executable actions (PTA) Orchestrates bots and human-in-the-loop decisions
Deployment Options On-prem, cloud, hybrid Primarily cloud, supports enterprise self-hosting
Target Users QA teams focused on interface-level automation Organizations pursuing company-wide process automation

Why might QA teams pick AskUI over UiPath?

  • Conversational design: Outline test flows using simple language ‚Äî no need to maintain brittle locators.
  • Versatile interface coverage: Automate across browsers, desktop apps, mobile screens, and graphic-intensive environments.
  • Trainable AI: Adapt pre-trained models with your own data for sharper, project-specific accuracy.

FAQs: Comparing AskUI and UiPath

Can AskUI replace a full RPA suite like UiPath?

No. AskUI is built for UI-level workflows and excels at them. UiPath covers complete business processes, integrating back-office tasks, analytics, and compliance.

Is there functional overlap?

Only partly. Both automate user interfaces, but UiPath‚Äôs strength is managing broader business flows, whereas AskUI keeps focus on UI testing and operation.

Which tool is easier for fast QA automation?

AskUI typically needs less upfront setup. Its natural-language interface and visual learning cut down configuration time compared to large-scale RPA platforms.

Name: AskUI vs. Adept: Which AI UI Automation Tool Is Right for You?
Post Body:
Updated: June 2025

What‚Äôs the Difference Between AskUI and Adept?

AskUI and Adept both offer AI-driven automation, but they target different needs. AskUI excels in visual UI interaction and natural language-based action prompts. Adept focuses on building autonomous agents for complex enterprise workflows.

Below is a side-by-side comparison to help QA managers, engineers, and automation leads decide which fits their environment best.

What Is AskUI and How Does It Work?

AskUI is a prompt-driven UI automation platform powered by computer vision.

It simulates human interactions by visually identifying and interacting with UI elements‚Äîacross desktop, mobile, canvas, and web‚Äîwithout relying on fragile element selectors.

Key Features of AskUI

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Users describe actions in plain English. AskUI translates them into executable UI interactions.
  • Visual Recognition: Automates any visible interface‚Äîbuttons, text, or graphics‚Äîjust like a human tester would.
  • Pre-trained & Custom AI Models: Preloaded with UIDT and PTA models, which can be fine-tuned for specific workflows.
  • Platform Flexibility: Works on macOS, Windows, Android, and Linux.
  • Deployment Options: Local, hybrid, or cloud-based automation.
  • Tool Integrations: Compatible with Zapier, n8n, Jenkins, and Docker.

‚úÖ Best For:
QA teams looking for visual-first automation, cross-platform support, and low-code setup.

What Is Adept AI Agent Automation?

Adept builds full-stack AI agents that automate complex tasks across enterprise software.

Its agents combine proprietary multimodal models with task-specific actuation systems to perform end-to-end workflows.

Key Features of Adept

  • Enterprise AI Agents: Designed to handle multistep, multi-app workflows across enterprise systems.
  • Multimodal Understanding: Processes text, charts, tables, and documents to make intelligent decisions.
  • Fast Setup with NLP Prompts: New workflows can be initiated using natural language, often in minutes.
  • High Accuracy & Resilience: Agents adapt to UI changes and minimize maintenance needs.
  • Planning & Execution Engine: Adept claims superior planning performance over models like GPT-4 in enterprise contexts.

‚úÖ Best For:
Organizations needing intelligent agents that can manage entire workflows across multiple enterprise tools.

‚Äç

AskUI vs. Adept: Feature Comparison

Feature AskUI Adept
Automation Type Visual UI Interaction Enterprise Workflow Agents
Input Method Prompt-to-Action (Natural Language) Natural Language Prompts
Core Strength AI vision-based interaction End-to-end workflow execution
Platform Support Windows, macOS, Android, Linux Web UIs, Enterprise Software
Deployment Local, Cloud, or Hybrid Cloud-first
Visual UI Adaptability High (self-healing) Medium
Setup Time Minutes via natural language prompts Minutes to hours (depends on complexity)

‚Äç

Which Tool Should QA Teams Choose?

  • Choose AskUI if your focus is on cross-platform UI automation, vision-based testing, and low-code flexibility.
  • Choose Adept if you need AI agents to plan and execute enterprise-grade workflows across apps, systems, and data formats.

For hybrid environments, AskUI's flexibility in both local and cloud-based deployment may provide a more agile solution for QA testing pipelines.

FAQ

What makes AskUI better for UI testing?

AskUI mimics human vision to detect and interact with UI elements, making it highly robust to UI changes and layout updates.

Can non-developers use AskUI or Adept?

AskUI is more beginner-friendly due to its plain-English prompt system. Adept may require more configuration for enterprise agents.

Are both tools secure for enterprise use?

Yes, both tools offer enterprise-ready deployment options. AskUI can run locally for security-sensitive environments.

Final Thoughts

AskUI and Adept take two different but powerful approaches to UI automation. AskUI empowers teams with visual interaction and natural language prompts across platforms, making it a flexible, accessible solution. In contrast, Adept‚Äôs agent-based automation excels in navigating complex enterprise workflows with multimodal intelligence.

Your decision ultimately comes down to your use case. For visual UI testing and simplicity, AskUI is a great fit. For orchestrating end-to-end enterprise processes, Adept may be the stronger choice.

Name: AskUI vs. Airtest: Which UI Automation Tool Is Better for You?
Post Body:
Updated: June 2025

What Is the Difference Between AskUI and Airtest?

AskUI focuses on AI-driven, visual UI automation powered by natural language input.
Airtest targets game testing with image recognition and Python-based scripting.

What Is AskUI?

AskUI is an AI-powered automation tool designed to interact with user interfaces visually, like a human. It supports automation across desktop, web, and even canvas-based applications. The platform does not rely on fragile DOM selectors or element hierarchies‚Äîinstead, it uses advanced visual recognition to identify elements on-screen.

Key Features of AskUI

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Automate using natural language. No coding required.
  • Cross-platform support: MacOS, Windows, Linux.
  • Deployment options: Local, cloud, or hybrid environments.
  • Third-party integrations: Supports Zapier, n8n, Docker, Jenkins.
  • AI fine-tuning: Customize pre-trained models (e.g., UIDT) with your own data.

AskUI is ideal for teams seeking resilient, low-maintenance automation with minimal scripting.

What Is Airtest?

Airtest is a script-based UI test automation tool focused primarily on game testing. Developed by NetEase, it uses image recognition and UI hierarchy analysis to automate app interactions across Android, Windows, and web platforms.

Key Features of Airtest

  • Game engine support: Especially strong for Unity-based games.
  • Multi-platform testing: Android, Windows, iOS (with Poco), and web (with Selenium plugin).
  • Airtest IDE: Cross-platform scripting environment (Windows, macOS, Ubuntu).
  • Script recording: One-click script recording and playback for quick test creation.
  • Python-based scripting: Full flexibility for developers.

Airtest is best suited for QA teams working on mobile games, apps, or cross-device experiences where scripting is preferred.

AskUI vs Airtest: Real-World Use Case Comparison

Use Case Scenario AskUI Airtest
Automating legacy desktop apps Works across canvas and desktop UIs visually Limited unless UI elements are easily recognized
Testing Unity-based mobile games Not designed for game engines One-click recording & Unity-specific features
Cross-platform UI automation (macOS/Win/Linux) Full support for all major OSs Available via Airtest IDE with scripting
Natural language-based UI testing Prompt-to-Action, no code needed Requires Python scripting
Non-technical stakeholder collaboration Easily share prompt-based flows Requires technical understanding

Which Tool Should You Choose?

Choose AskUI if:

  • Your team lacks coding expertise.
  • You need automation across varied app types (web, desktop, canvas).
  • UI changes frequently and break element-based scripts.
  • You're focused on fast test creation via natural language.

Choose Airtest if:

  • You're automating mobile or game apps (e.g., Unity).
  • Your team prefers Python scripting.
  • You need native element access on Android/iOS.
  • You value record-and-playback for testing.

What Makes AskUI Unique?

AskUI‚Äôs two standout advantages are:

  1. Visual UI Recognition: It sees and understands the UI like a human, enabling it to automate dynamic interfaces that break traditional tools.
  2. Natural Language Interface: Its Prompt-to-Action (PTA) lets non-developers build automation just by describing what needs to be done.

This combination makes AskUI more inclusive and future-proof as automation becomes more accessible.

FAQ: Choosing Between AskUI and Airtest

Which platform is better for non-technical QA teams?
AskUI is more accessible for non-developers thanks to its natural language automation. Airtest, on the other hand, requires scripting skills.

Can Airtest fully automate iOS apps?
Airtest can interact with native iOS elements using Poco, but configuration is more complex and less stable than Android automation.

Does AskUI support advanced automation workflows?
Yes. While AskUI is no-code by default, it can be extended with CI/CD tools, APIs, and integrations like Docker and Jenkins.

Is Airtest suitable for dynamic, frequently changing UIs?
Not ideally. Since Airtest depends on static image recognition, it's less effective when UI layouts frequently change.

Final Thoughts

If you're looking for code-free, visually-driven automation across platforms, AskUI is a future-ready choice.
For developers testing mobile games or apps in Unity or Android, Airtest remains a flexible, script-friendly option.

Evaluate based on your team‚Äôs technical comfort, platform focus, and UI complexity.

Related Resources

  • Agentic AI vs. Traditional Test Automation
  • AskUI Flutter Automation Guide

‚Äç
Post Summary: Compare AskUI and Airtest for UI automation. Learn which is best for cross-platform, game, or natural language automation needs.

Name: AskUI vs. Appium: Which UI Automation Tool Is Right for You?
Post Body:
Updated: June 2025

What Is AskUI?

AskUI is a visual-first UI automation platform powered by AI.

‚Äç It allows users to automate interfaces across web, desktop, and mobile apps using natural language instructions and visual object recognition, eliminating the need for traditional selectors.

Key Features of AskUI

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Define automation actions using plain English prompts.
  • AI Visual Recognition: Detects and interacts with UI elements like a human would.
  • Platform Support: MacOS, Windows, Linux, Android.
  • Flexible Deployment: On-premise, cloud, and hybrid.
  • Tool Integration: Compatible with Zapier, n8n, Docker, Jenkins.

What Is Appium?

Appium is a code-driven, open-source automation framework based on the WebDriver protocol. It supports a wide range of platforms, from mobile and desktop to smart TVs, and is favored for its versatility and community support.

Key Features of Appium

  • Driver-Based Architecture: Uses platform-specific drivers to maintain flexibility.
  • WebDriver Compatibility: Supports scripting in multiple programming languages.
  • Broad Platform Coverage: iOS, Android, Windows, macOS, Roku, tvOS, Samsung.
  • Open Ecosystem: Actively maintained with strong community contributions.

AskUI vs. Appium: Feature Comparison

‚Äç

Feature AskUI Appium
Target Applications Cross-platform, including desktop, web, Android, canvas Web, mobile, desktop, TVs (Roku, tvOS)
AI Integration Built-in AI for visual automation and NLP No native AI; extendable via third-party tools
Programming Requirements Low-code via plain English prompts Requires scripting with client libraries
Open Source Hybrid (Open SDK + SaaS backend) Fully open-source
Deployment Local, cloud, hybrid Flexible: cloud or local

When Should You Use AskUI?

Use AskUI when you need a faster, more intuitive way to automate UIs without writing code. It excels in:

  • Projects with non-technical users
  • Complex canvas- or graphics-based UIs
  • Teams looking for AI-first test automation
  • Rapid prototyping environments

When Should You Use Appium?

Choose Appium if you require broad platform support and prefer traditional scripting methods. It‚Äôs ideal for:

  • Cross-platform mobile testing at scale
  • QA teams with strong coding skills
  • Projects needing advanced customization
  • Integration with established WebDriver tools

Key Differentiators: AskUI

  • Prompt-to-Action (PTA): Write automation commands in natural language.
  • AI Visual Understanding: Recognizes UI elements visually, not by code locators.
  • Minimal Setup: No need for app source access or element IDs.

FAQ: AskUI vs. Appium

How does AskUI compare to Appium in UI automation?
AskUI uses AI-powered vision and natural language prompts for cross-platform automation. Appium relies on traditional code-based scripting via WebDriver.

Which is better for non-technical QA teams?
AskUI offers a more accessible interface through Prompt-to-Action, ideal for teams without strong programming backgrounds. Appium requires coding expertise.

Can AskUI handle mobile automation like Appium?
For straightforward mobile workflows, yes. For complex device control and advanced gestures, Appium is more robust.

Which tool adapts better to UI changes?
AskUI excels with AI-based visual selectors, reducing test flakiness from UI updates. Appium can struggle if element locators break.

Do both tools support CI/CD pipelines?
Yes, both integrate with popular tools like Jenkins, Docker, and GitHub Actions.

Can AskUI replace Appium for mobile automation?

  • For simple workflows, yes. For advanced mobile testing with deep device control, Appium is still superior.

Do both tools support CI/CD?

  • Yes. Both integrate with Jenkins, GitHub Actions, and other CI/CD pipelines.

Related Resources

  • Agentic AI vs. Traditional Automation
  • AskUI Flutter Automation Guide
  • AskUI vs. Adept AI

Final Thoughts

AskUI and Appium serve different needs.

If you're building AI-powered workflows or want a no-code option, AskUI is the better fit.

If your team is comfortable with code and you need extensive device testing, Appium remains a top-tier choice.
Post Summary: Compare AskUI and Appium for cross-platform UI automation. Discover their strengths, use cases, and AI-powered capabilities.

Name: Automate Business Process Through Intelligent Vision AI Agents
Post Body:
Intelligent automation is revolutionizing business operations. One of the emerging technologies at the forefront of this transformation is Vision Agents‚Äîtools that leverage visual understanding to streamline workflows and enhance efficiency. Let‚Äôs explore how this innovative approach is reshaping automation.

What Are Vision Agents?

Vision Agents are intelligent systems designed to interpret, process, and act on visual information, such as graphical user interfaces (GUIs) or images. Instead of relying on traditional rule-based logic, Vision Agents use advanced visual understanding techniques to interact with applications the same way humans do‚Äîby observing and responding to what they see on the screen.

By mimicking human vision, these agents have the potential to carry out repetitive and complex tasks across diverse platforms without requiring underlying access to application code or APIs.

How Vision Agents Enhance Business Processes

1. Automating Repetitive Tasks: Vision Agents can quickly learn to perform repetitive tasks like form filling, data extraction, or navigating software applications. By automating these processes, organizations can reduce manual errors, boost productivity, and free up employees to focus on higher-value activities.

2. Improving Workflow Efficiency: By visually understanding interfaces and automating interactions, Vision Agents streamline workflows that might otherwise require custom integrations or manual oversight. This efficiency benefits industries that rely on software-intensive processes, such as finance, healthcare, and retail.‚Äç

3. Overcoming Integration Limitations: Traditional automation often depends on APIs or custom scripts, limiting flexibility and scalability. Vision Agents bypass these limitations by directly interacting with the visual layer of an application, enabling automation in systems without API access or outdated software environments.

Key Benefits of Vision Agents

  • Human-like Precision: These agents act in ways that mimic human interaction with screens, ensuring more accurate decision-making even in visually complex applications.
  • Adaptability: Vision Agents can adapt to dynamic user interfaces, making them suitable for modern applications that frequently change or update.
  • Scalability: Once trained, these systems can be deployed across multiple use cases or platforms, scaling operations with ease.

The Role of Intelligent Vision in Future Business Innovation

As automation solutions continue to evolve, intelligent technologies like Vision Agents are bridging the gap between systems and interfaces that were previously challenging to integrate. These advancements not only improve process efficiency but also enable businesses to deliver better services and customer experiences.

Conclusion

With their ability to bring intelligent vision into business processes, Vision Agents represent a powerful tool for automation. By harnessing visual understanding, organizations can redefine their workflows, gaining efficiency and scalability in the ever-evolving digital landscape.
Post Summary: Discover how Vision Agents are transforming automation with human-like visual understanding. Streamline workflows, boost efficiency, and solve integration hurdles!

Name: Automate Github 2-Factor Authentication (2FA) with Android Device
Post Body:
Today, we're building a two-factor authentication GitHub workflow automation with a browser we have on our Personal Computer (PC) and a physical Android device.

Cross-Platform automation and within one framework is hard to do. That is why testing is often done by humans. This means it is expensive. Both in working hours and also for elaborate setups with multiple devices.

We will show you a way to automate cross-platform based on visual selectors and Operating System (OS) automation (Clicks/Taps, mouse movement, keystrokes.). Getting you started on your journey to real Cross-Platform UI Automation.

Setup

For the setup of this tutorial, we need to do two things:

  • Set up your Android device
  • Set up our GitHub account with the Android device as a second factor

Android Device

We need to enable USB debugging, install the LastPass Authenticator app, and enable screenshots for it. So let's do that now.

Lastpass Authenticator App

You have to install the LastPass Authenticator app from the Google Play Store.

Enable Screenshots in the LastPass Authenticator App

Open the app. Go to the settings of the LastPass Authenticator app and enable screenshots.

Enable USB Debugging

Next, we have to enable USB debugging on the device. Depending on your Android version and the manufacturer of the device, this always is a little bit different. So I'll show you how it's done on my device.

First, head over to the settings. Then find System and scroll down to About the Tablet. Then find the Build Number and hit it seven times. A little pop-up on the bottom should show up which says: You are now a Developer!. If it were always this easy to learn a new profession üòã

Let's go back to System and there should be a new option: Developer Options. Tap it and scroll down to USB debugging. Make sure it is enabled and now you're good to go to complete the setup.

Here is a video-tutorial to show it visually!

That is it for the basic setup of your Android device ü•≥

Link LastPass Authenticator App to GitHub Account

You have to link your two-factor authentication of GitHub with your LastPass Authenticator app. Hop over to GitHub.com and you should see your personal page after logging in. Then click on the avatar on the right top, go to Settings, Password and Authentication and there you should be able to enable the two-factor authentication by following the instructions steps.

You should end up with something like this in your app:

And that's it! You're good to go and can start implementing the automation for AskUI üòé

Implement the Automation of 2-Factor Authentication with AskUI

If you want to follow along, clone our GitHub repository.

If you followed the tutorial for setting up the ADB, you should also have the ADBKeyboard in version 2.1 installed.

Once you have everything set up, head over to your preferred IDE, open a terminal, and type in adb devices. You should see your device successfully connected if you connected it to your PC.

Setup AskUI

Please follow along the specific tutorial for your operating system and come back once you set that up:

  • Windows
  • macOS
  • Linux

Setup the UI Controllers - One for your System and one for your Android Device

We need two UI controllers, one for the Android device and one for our browser on our PC.

We'll also need to start the UI controllers manually. They'll expose their service on a specific port:
  • For the browser 7007
  • For the Android device 6769
Start the AskUI Controller for your Android device by running:
Then start your browser AskUI Controller by running:
You must first insert your Github-Username on line 9 and your password on line 19 of the my-first-askui-test-suite.test.ts file
Execute the test by running:
Breaking Down the AskUI Code
We start by importing the UiControlClients for our browser and our Android device.
Then, we have the basic jest structure which describes a test suit, and then the test case.
Fill Out the Initial Login Form
Line 1: The first instruction is to click on the browser again to get the focus when we start our automation.
Line 2: Then we want to click on Sign In to bring up the login form from GitHub.
Line 4-10: Next, we want to type in our username into the text field that is below the text field with the label ‚Äúusername or email address‚Äù. Notice how we use { isSecret: true, secretMask: '**' } here, so no sensitive information is sent to the AskUI backend.
Line 12: Then press ESC to lose the focus of the text field and select the password field.
Line 14-20: We want to type in our password into the text field that is below the text field with the label Password.
Line 22-23: Then we want to TAB to get focus on our login button and press enter.
This is where the browser automation stops and we have to switch to our Android device.
Get a Token from LastPass Authenticator App
Line 1: We use our Android key here to wake up the tablet if it has gone to sleep.
Line 4: Then we want to start the LastPass Authenticator App. Starting it over the UI is not too intuitive to automate. For the sake of brevity, we use execOnShell() with the ADB. That's a little bit of a trick here üòâ.
Line 6-15: The text that displays our token is the first element below the GitHub text. We want to copy it and then paste it into the input field that comes up when we do the browser automation.
Line 18-24: To get the element, we're going to sort the elements based on the bounding box's ymin-coordinate. This should give us the token as the first element. We can take the first element and get its text, replacing all the new lines or spaces we find.
Type the Token Into the Authentication Form
We then type the token into the input field which contains the text XXXXXX.
If the token is correct this should bring us to our personal page on GitHub üíÉüèª.
Conclusion
In this tutorial, you learned how to instrument two different devices on two different platforms with AskUI in one automation case.
With this knowledge, you can now start to write your own cross-platform automation üòé.

Name: Automate Glowing Outline Effect in Gimp with AskUI
Post Body:
AskUI shines when you realize a workflow has a complex clickpath and you want to automate it adhoc.

This blog post shows you how you can automate a graphics effect I need for YouTube thumbnails: Outline glow effect of a cropped out person in Gimp!

Why automate this in the first place? It causes wrist pain because of the long clickpath üòã.

Here is the automation in action:

Prerequisites

  • AskUI installed and configured on your system (Windows, Linux, macOS)
  • Gimp and a cropped out person you want to a add glow effect to

Prepare Layers in Gimp

Your Layer with the cropped out person needs to have a distinctive name - In this example Johannes. Also scale it to the image size by right-clicking on the layer and select Scale to image size.

Then activate the Magic select-tool (magic wand icon) and place the mouse cursor next to the person.

Step-by-step Code Walkthrough

1. Select Only the Person

With the Magic select-tool clicking left selects everything except the person. By inverting the selection with the shortcut CTRL+i (Command+i on macOS) you select only the person.

2. Create New Layer for Glow
Then create a new layer above the layer of the cropped out person layer. This is why you need a distinctive name for it, so you can move the mouse cursor to it reliably üôÇ.
3. Grow the Selection and Fill It with Background Color
Let's grow the selection so we can get an actual outline and fill it with the background color.
4. Apply Blur Filter for Smoother Glow
Now you have to navigate to the menu item Filters and click it. After that move the mouse cursor to the Blur menu item. Navigate with keypresses to Gaussian Blur and set the size to 6.16 for a nice glow. Apply the filter by clicking the OK-button.
5. Move the Layer below the Person Layer
Nearly finished! But the glow has to be behind the person. For this you have to drag the person-layer over the Glow-layer in the layers menu.
You can achieve this by doing the following: Move the mouse over the person-layer, toggle the mouse down so you can drag it. Then move it relatively just over the Glow-layer and release the mouse by toggling up.
Full Code
And finally the full code used for the AskUI Workflow.
Conclusion
The automation of the workflow is not faster then me doing it manually. But it is much less straining for your wrist, which is a big thing to keep you productive in the long run.

Want to build an automation yourself? Sign up to get free access to AskUI.

Name: Automate Highlighting in WYSIWYG Editors with AskUI
Post Body:
Working in What-You-See-Is-What-You-Get editors (WYSIWYG) can be very tiring and also taxing on your wrists. Things like highlighting the same thing over and over again can often not be done with search-and-replace, because there is just no button for it üò§

I recently had to put a transcript of a podcast into such an editor and had to bold the speaker hints, so that you clearly know who was speaking in that part of the podcast. It looks like this:

JD: Welcome to J^2 Talk AI
JH: I think first of all we should understand...

It is always alternating between JD and JH as that is the nature of a conversation üòã.

Bolden the beginning speaker hints would need me to double-left-click the abbreviations and then hit the shortcut cmd+b (I am on macOS) in this particular editor.

I do not want to do this by myself as that would mean to do roughly 20*2 = 40 actions on average per episode. And I had 5 episodes... Extremely straining on your wrists and arms and it is dull work also!

In this tutorial I will show you how I automated this task with AskUI and also how to work around some kinks of WYSIWIG-Editors like microanimations and strange behaviour.

Prerequisites

* AskUI installed (Windows, Linux, macOS)

* Open your favorite WYSIWIG-Editor

The Problem

So what do we need to do?

* Find all the JD and JH

* Double-left-click each one

* Press cmd+b (macOS) or (ctrl+b Linux and Windows)

‚Äç

This is how it looks:

‚ÄçLet Us Develop It Step-By-Step

So the first thing that needs to be done is finding all the JD and JH. This can be done with the get() command. As you can see in the demo above there are possibly multiple pages, so we have to scroll somehow. The easiest way to do this is to press the pagedown-key. So let us be conservative and press that key three times.

Every time we press it there is a scroll animation that might mess up the inference. So let's wait two seconds with waitFor(2000). That should be enough to finish the animation.

This already looks like it would be a good idea to refactor it and put the actual highlighting code into a function highlight().
Great, now we need to mouse-double-left-click the text JD and JH one by one with a for-loop. But when we try it with await aui.moveMouseTo(jds[0]).exec() it will move the cursor to the middle of the line where JD/JH is at the beginning. We have to use the bounding box x-min and y-min values to get to the beginning of the line. Also we have to add like 10 pixels to the values to actually move the cursor over the JD/JH.
Now we can do the highlighting by mouse-double-left-click and press the bold shortcut.
That should highlight all the JD. Let's do the same with JH. Also we need to add a keypress of escape here because the mini-menu that pops up when double-left-clicking the last JD  might cover a JH 
Two More Tweaks - Complete Code
Another problem you might run into is missing focus on the editor. This is why adding the first two lines to your code is beneficial. It moves the mouse cursor into the editor and with the left-click gets the focus.
Also extracting a function boldenText(bbox) that does the highlighting given a bounding box bbox avoids duplicate code.
Here it is, the complete code:
‚ÄçConclusion
In this tutorial you learned how to automate tedious tasks like highlighting some recurring text in a WYSIWYG-Editor.
You also learned how to overcome some of the challenges user interfaces throw at you like mini-popups and micro-animations.

Name: Automate Web Search on Android with AskUI (2026 Updated Guide)
Post Body:
Want to automate tasks on your Android device just by describing what you see? Forget complex selectors or device specific code. With AskUI's intelligent vision AI agent and Python, you can automate virtually any app on your Android device using simple, human like instructions.

As the team behind AskUI, we know getting started with mobile automation can sometimes feel tricky. This updated tutorial is the next step in our Android series. It assumes you have already set up your device and now want to write your first real automation using Python to perform a simple web search starting from your home screen.

We've refined these steps based on our latest software and user feedback to make it as smooth as possible.

Why Automate Android with AskUI?

Before we dive in, let's quickly recap why AskUI is uniquely suited for Android automation:

  • Truly Universal: Unlike tools that rely on app code, AskUI sees the screen like you do. This means it works consistently across native apps, web apps, hybrid apps, and even games.
  • Resilient to Changes: Because it understands visually, minor UI updates like button placement changes often don't break AskUI automations, drastically reducing maintenance.
  • Simple Instructions: You describe actions based on visual elements such as "click the button with the text 'Search'" making scripts intuitive.

You can understand the core tech by reading our guide: What Exactly is an Intelligent Vision AI Agent?

Prerequisites: Getting Your Setup Ready

Before you begin this tutorial, please ensure you have completed these key steps:

  1. Python Installation: You need Python installed on your computer. Download it from python.org if you haven't already. (External Link)
  2. AskUI Account: You'll need AskUI credentials. Sign up for free at AskUI Sign Up.
  3. Android Device & Controller Setup: Your Android device or emulator must be connected via ADB, with "USB Debugging" enabled, and the AskUI UI Controller app installed and running.

If you have not done the Android setup, please follow our detailed guide first:: Tutorial: Setting Up Android Devices for Testing Mobile Apps

You will also need ADB Platform Tools.

Step 1: Initialize Your AskUI Python Project

Let's create a simple project folder and set up AskUI with Python:

1. Create Project Folder: Open your terminal or command prompt and run:

2. (Recommended) Create a Python Virtual Environment: This keeps your project dependencies isolated
3. Install the AskUI Python Client: Use pip to install the AskUI library.
4. Create Your Test File: Create a Python file named search_test.py.
Step 2: Writing Your First Android Automation Script in Python
Open search _test.py  and add the following code. We'll use AskUI's Python library to automate opening Chrome, searching for "spacecraft" (to match our example images), and verifying the Wikipedia result.
Important: Remember to replace YOUR_WORKSPACE_ID  and  YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" with your actual AskUI credentials. For security, it's highly recommended to use environment variables instead of hardcoding credentials in real projects.
Step 3: Running Your Python Automation
Make sure your Python virtual environment is activated, your Android device is connected, unlocked, and the AskUI UI Controller app is running. Now, execute your script from the terminal using this command:
Watch your Android device! You should see the following steps happen automatically:
Our starting point: The Android home screen.
‚Äç
1. AskUI identifies and clicks the "Chrome" icon
2. Chrome opens, and AskUI finds and clicks the search bar.
3. AskUI types "spacecraft," presses Enter, and successfully identifies the "Spacecraft - Wikipedia" text on the results page.
If your console logs "Search successful! Wikipedia link found," congratulations. You've successfully automated a web search on Android using AskUI and Python.
Troubleshooting & Tips from Our Experience
Here are a couple of common issues:
  • "Element not found": Mobile UIs vary. If AskUI can't find your "Chrome" icon or the search bar, use the await askui_core.annotate() command temporarily in your script. Run it. It will generate an annotated screenshot (annotation.png) showing how AskUI sees the screen. Adjust your element descriptions (icon().with_text() , textfield(), etc.) based on what AskUI sees.
  • Timing Issues: Apps can be slow. Use await asyncio.sleep(seconds) generously, especially after launching apps or triggering actions.
Final Thoughts
You've just automated a web search on Android using Python and the power of intelligent vision! This simple example only scratches the surface. Because AskUI interacts visually, you can use the same principles to automate virtually any task within any Android application, no matter how complex or dynamic its UI might be.
Ready to automate more? Explore our AskUI Documentation for more commands and advanced techniques. Happy automating.

This article was written and fact checked by the AskUI Content Team. Our team works closely with engineers and product experts to bring you accurate, insightful, and practical information about the world of Agentic AI. We are passionate about making technology more accessible to everyone.
