Name: Challenges in User Interface Automation: The Future is Now
Post Body:
In the previous two installments (link to Part 1, link to Part 2) of the series, we discussed how the state-of-the-art selector-based approaches to User Interface (UI) Automation can be enhanced with Smart Selectors. They remedy the flakiness of tests by working on relations of UI Elements, finding UI Elements with Optical Character Recognition, or Picture-in-Picture search.

In this last blog, we look at cutting-edge and future technologies that promise to solve UI Automation for user interfaces that are currently hard to test without a special setup.

The Problem with 2D Planes

There is a whole class of applications selector-based tools are unable to test: 2D planes!

In HTML for example you can define a canvas where selector-based tools can not get any of the elements drawn into them.

Adoption of Cross-Platform Development
Native apps for Android and iOS are the preferred way to deliver a product to end users as they can efficiently leverage all the platform-specific APIs. The downside is, that you need specialized development teams to develop the apps. Development on each platform is completely different. This leads to additional costs!
A solution to this problem is cross-platform development, where only one codebase is maintained that compiles to every platform. In fact, cross-platform development is picking up momentum currently with Flutter leading the way.
Flutters claim on its webpage promises nothing less than
[...] to build apps for mobile, web, desktop, and embedded devices ‚Äî all from a single codebase.
With a single codebase for every platform, the need for multiple development teams is not given anymore.
But how do you test on Android, iOS, and embedded Devices where selector-based approaches fall short?
üëÅ Let us look at what cutting-edge tools are out there already. üëÅ 
Visual (Regression) Testing aided by Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence
Visual Testing uses screenshots to compare the current state of an app to the specified one. The goal is to find differences in the User Interface like wrong layouts or different colors of elements. Changes like a wrong color of a button can be detected with this technique:
The problem with classic visual (regression) testing tools is that they are very rigid and react to tiny pixel changes. This makes them hard to use in real-world settings as the tests become flaky.
With the help of Machine Learning and AI, tools like Applitools are trying to get rid of that problem. Applitools trained their model Applitools Eyes to not match pixel-perfect but based on an understanding of the layout. It recognizes differences in the layout like missing elements.
With its Visual Selectors you can also add custom elements you have in your layout like icons.
Real Visual Testing with Machine Learning
Real Visual Testing takes this concept one step further by automating the User Interface as a real human user would. It uses Machine Learning to detect elements on a visual basis. Also, the user input happens on an operating system basis allowing for real mouse movement, clicks/taps, and keystrokes.
That enables testing all applications on all platforms and across all user interfaces. Furthermore, a test can easily detect bugs for example that stem from modal dialogs or banners that cover other elements.
What would a model interfere from our rudimentary example page? Let us find out with askui:
Now we will try to write something into the text field:
When you run the code above you will see the mouse moving to the text field and type in askui.
If you want to try it out for yourself feel free to clone the Git repository and check the askui docs for a complete introduction.
Outlook
Using Artificial Intelligence to detect elements will only be the beginning. We already see a rise in applications for advanced use cases. Two of which we want to discuss here.
Visual Question Answering
A human brain is a pattern-matching machine and can detect the slight difference in the following two pictures easily:
Machine Learning models usually can detect the triple _< girl, walking, bike >_ but are not able to distinguish between a girl walking a bike and a girl walking with a bike in the same picture.
But they get better and better and when they can do it reliably even more powerful selectors can be used in UI automation.
Natural Language Processing
This development is already at the breakthrough point with models able to generate beautiful art from prompts and systems like GitHub Copilot suggesting code on the fly.
For UI Automation it will mean a shift away from creating workflows and code execution to writing down what should be done. The tools will figure out a way to do it!
Conclusion
In this series, we showed the current state of User Interface automation. We discussed its shortcomings and how to mitigate them.
Then we went on to advanced techniques like Self-healing Tests which often use Smart Selectors in form of OCR, Picture-in-Picture search, and relational selectors. Especially relational selectors remedy the structural coupling of automation code to the code under test.
The future of UI Testing is looking bright with emerging tools tackling the problems of current selector-based tools. Bringing Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence to Visual (Regression) Testing becomes feasible with tools like Applitools Eyes.
Real Visual Testing solely relies on Machine Learning to detect elements as a human would. It also combines interacting with the UI like a real user, simulating mouse movement and keystrokes. We showed how askui can do exactly that!
Do you want to know more about UI automation's future with askui? Join our community!
Post Summary: In this last blog, we look at cutting-edge and future technologies that promise to solve UI Automation for user interfaces that are currently hard....

Name: Common Terms in Computer Vision
Post Body:
When you read about Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Computer Vision you often come across terms that seem to be common.

But do you know all of them and what they actually mean?

In this blog we will list the most common terms that we use in our day-to-day work.

¬†
¬† ¬†

¬† ¬† ¬†What can be said can be solved with AskUI. ¬† ¬†

¬† ¬†Sign up ¬†

Bounding Box

A Bounding Box is a rectangle around a detected element or region in a picture. In code they are represented with their coordinates. There are different formats used. Some examples:

  • pascal_voc: [xmin, ymin, ymax, ymax]
  • coco: [xmin, ymin, width, height]
  • yolo: normalized [xcenter, ycenter, width, height]

Example in JSON:

Annotation
An annotation can be the visual representation of a bounding box or just a keypoint. But also a textual description is possible.
Usually bounding boxes are used in grounding together with labels and to establish a ground-truth or reference for trainingdata and testdata for training computer vision models.
Annotations differ from labels in that they can include any additional metadata.
Label
A label is given to a bounding box or a keypoint and identifies which class or category an object or area the model assigned to it. In the above example the person-text above the bounding box is a label.
Labels are also used to train models where the training set consists of correctly labeled images.
Image Classification
Image classification is used to put a predefined label on an image.
For an image of a cat would get the label cat, while the image of a sunset would get the label sunset.
This seems like a trivial thing to do but it actually has a lot of practical use cases:
  • Recognition of objects or entities depicted in images
  • Classifying medical image for detecting abnormalities
  • Image retrieval based on categories
Image Segmentation
The goal of image segmentation is to divide an image into areas that belong together. The areas are visually distinctive from each other.
The output of the process is a set of segmentation masks that can be used to process the image further.
Take this segmentation of an avatar image where the masks define where a person is and where the background is. A practical application would be to remove the background based on these masks.
Object Detection
Object detection is used to identify objects in images and video. It is a crucial task in a lot of domains such as Surveillance and Security, Environmental Monitoring and Augmented Reality.
It takes visual input and determines the objects that are present. The objects are described with a bounding box and also get a class-label and sometimes a confidence score.
Feature
A distinctive feature in an area or keypoint of an image. Usually you attribute features to a specific class you want to detect.
For a mouse those could be the shape, surroundings or fur pattern. Those are represented as numerical vectors, called descriptors, that capture the visual properties of an area or keypoint.
Feature Vector
Feature vectors are not limited to Computer Vision, but used there for all kind of tasks.
A feature vector is generated from input data such as an image and contains one numerical entry for every feature. Feature vectors are typically high-dimensional.
In practice feature vectors get generated by a Backbone (see next heading) which are by themselves models trained to extract useful features.
Grounding
Grounding is the process of connecting high-level concepts, for example Mouse, with visual features, for example tail.
Now that you have high-level concepts and their representation in the model you can also put them into context and relation with each-other.
Grounding can also be done by humans for training data. There you annotate an input with bounding boxes and labels, so the model has a Ground Truth to learn from.
Referring Expression
Referring Expression in Computer Vision are used to describe objects or areas in images. They can contain attributes like color or relations to other objects.
Take this example: "The bike next to the child." You do not point to the bike directly but give a reference point child. Or you could give a description: "The red building next to the blue car.".
Referring Expressions are typically used in tasks like object localization, object detection or image retrieval.
Zero-Shot
In general zero-shot is when models can do tasks they were not specifically trained on.
To some extend, and most of them rather poorly, every model can perform tasks without specific training as the goal of training is to get a higher-level understanding of concepts.
Zero-shot learning in Computer Vision also includes more information than just labeled examples. The focus is on data that describes relationships between categories, so the model can generalize better to new categories.
This also requires large scale training on a lot of data, so the model is exposed to billions of examples and can generalize without specific training to new tasks.
Conclusion
That are all, but sure there are more. Do you know of any we should include?
Let us know on Social Media.
Post Summary: When you read about Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning and Computer Vision you often come across terms that seem to be common. But do you k....

Name: Concrete Use Cases for Neurosymbolic AI
Post Body:
The evolution of neurosymbolic AI promises a groundbreaking shift in the landscape of technology by seamlessly integrating the strengths of deep learning with the structured reasoning capabilities of symbolic AI. The potential applications span various industries, striving to make intelligent agents smarter and more adaptable in the real world. Below are some compelling use cases illustrating this integration at work.

Knowledge-Based Question Answering (KBQA)

One of the most exciting applications of neurosymbolic AI is in Knowledge-Based Question Answering (KBQA). Traditional AI systems often struggle with complex natural language queries that involve multiple relations or require reasoning over a wide knowledge base. However, with the potential of neurosymbolic AI, these challenges can be tackled more effectively. The ability to translate queries into logical forms enables intelligent systems to perform reasoning akin to human thought processes. This could revolutionize customer support, business intelligence, and scientific discovery by providing deeper insights and more precise answers to intricate questions.

Common Sense Reasoning in Vision Agents

Common sense reasoning remains a frontier where many AI systems fall short. Neurosymbolic AI serves to bridge this gap ‚Äî particularly with vision agents. The ability to track objects that aren‚Äôt always visible, similar to understanding object permanence in human development, exemplifies this. For self-driving vehicles, this means anticipating the trajectory of pedestrians who may be temporarily obscured. In healthcare, robotic assistants equipped with this capability could effectively locate and handle medical equipment in cluttered environments, enhancing operational efficiency and safety.

Natural Language Understanding

Neurosymbolic AI also promises significant advances in natural language understanding. By employing semantic parsing, this technology allows AI systems to interpret sentences into logical forms, leading to a more nuanced understanding of human language. This can empower AI assistants to respond to sophisticated requests and enable chatbots to engage in meaningful conversations. The impact is potential enhancement in customer service experiences and personal interactions with AI, fostering more intuitive human-computer interactions.

Accelerating Scientific Discovery

The realm of scientific discovery can greatly benefit from the implementation of neurosymbolic AI. Whereas traditional AI systems may lack the nuanced reasoning needed for complex tasks, neurosymbolic AI can integrate domain-specific knowledge to drive innovation. For example, in the design of new materials or in drug development, these intelligent systems could model unknown molecules more accurately, facilitating breakthroughs that can lead to novel solutions in material science and pharmacology.

Expanding Horizons with Neurosymbolic AI

The discussed use cases merely scratch the surface of what neurosymbolic AI can achieve. As research progresses and the technology matures, we anticipate an influx of innovative applications in diverse domains, offering solutions that overcome the limitations of traditional AI methods. The integration of symbolic reasoning into intelligent agents could be a game-changer, propelling the development of systems that are not only smarter but also more adaptable to complex, real-world challenges.

Neurosymbolic AI is poised to redefine our interaction with technology, potentially enabling intelligent agents to process information with an unprecedented depth of understanding. As this field continues to evolve, its impact will likely expand, shaping the future of technology across various disciplines.
Post Summary: The potential applications span various industries, striving to make intelligent agents smarter and more adaptable in the real world.

Name: Conditional Execution in AskUI Workflows
Post Body:
When you automate workflows you can NOT focus solely on the happy path where everything works as expected. The real world is way more complicated.

Especially when you automate User Interfaces (UI) you have to deal with elements that only sometimes appear in special cases, pop-ups that jump in your face and block access to other elements. Or the workflow has some inherent variance you need to account for.

In AskUI you can deal with all of these things by checking for conditions and choosing a different path through your workflow!

This blog post explains how to implement preconditions, so your workflows become managable and stable.

The Example

To illustrate the approach we will automate the Dark/Light-theme-switcher on the AskUI Practice Page in the top right corner.

‚Äç

Depending on the theme that is currently active the text of the button changes between Switch to Dark and Switch to Light.

Step 1: Check for an Element to Exist

To illustrate the mechanics we first want to check if we are currently in the Light-theme by trying to get() the text-element Switch to Dark. get() will always return an array. And if the element was found it will have at least one element in it, if not the array is empty (Check the API docs).

Now we can check if we can safely click the switch button by verifying the array is not empty:
Step2: Also Check for Other Variant
Let us now make our workflow adjust to the reality that the practice page can be either in dark or in light mode. In dark mode the button has the label Switch to Light. We try to get() this text first:
Then we add an else if to the check for the light theme. So depending on the existence of Switch to Dark or Switch to Light the button is clicked and the theme is switched in any case:
Step 3: Encapsulate Code into a Function
Putting all this code in your workflow may be maintainable for a small workflow. But once you have a lot of code you want to move it into a separate function and call it. This also makes it more maintainable and reusable by different workflows.
Conclusion
By using conditions in your workflow your workflow will become more stable as it can recover from deviations from the happy path. You can use this technique to automate preconditions that need to be fulfilled for a workflow to run successfully.
For example making sure that a user is logged in, or that the UI is in a desired state.
Post Summary: This blog post explains how to implement preconditions in AskUl workflows, so they become manageable and stable.

Name: Convenience Method expectAllExist()
Post Body:
Sometimes you need your AskUI workflow to adapt to variations in your User Interface (UI) when it is executed. This includes for example popups that may or may not appear or small changes in your UI depending on the state of the system.

In an earlier blog post about Conditional Execution we showed you how to execute different AskUI instructions depending on the (non-)existence of an element.

But what if you want to check for the existence of multiple elements at once? You have to write multiple instructions, which is a tedious process.

This is why we implemented the convenience method expectAllExist() which takes an array of descriptions and checks for their existence.

Prerequisites

  • AskUI installed in version >0.20.0

The API

The method expectAllExist() takes an array of element specifications and returns an object with an accumulated boolean allExist which is true when all elements have been detected. And, second, the element specifications with an additional property exists which is true when the individual element has been detected.

We will demonstrate the capabilities of expectAllExist() on our AskUI Practice Page. You can follow along if you like.
Example 1: Expect a Single Text Element
Let us start with the most common use case: Checking for the existence of a text element.
When you log the returned object it will look like this:
Now you can go ahead and do, or not do, something with the knowledge that it exists üòä.
Example 2: Expect a Complex Element with a Relation
The next thing we want to check is the button with the label CE that is right of the text %. We do it like this:
Example 3: Expect Multiple Elements
For the last example, you have to switch to the Register tab of the practice page.
We will check for the existence of the text Name:, the checkbox with the label Developer and last but not least the button with the label Submit that is below the text Profile.
Limitations
The new convenience method only works for elements of type text, button, checkbox, switch, textfield and element. Additionally it has a limitation for textfield when used in conjunction with a relation. Read below on what to pay attention to.
Unsupported Elements
We currently do not support the following element types: container, icon, image, otherElement, special and table.
Use only Relation for Switch, Checkbox, Textfield
Textfields, Switches and Checkboxes do not have a text label inside them naturally. Specifying a text property for these elements will lead to a not detected element. Please only the relation property as shown in the following example:
Conclusion
Expecting the existence of multiple elements can be a real drag if you do not use expectAllExist(). This new convenience method will help you to write more maintainable AskUI workflows and also prevent RSI hopefully.
If you have questions or need support, do not hesitate to join our Community.
Post Summary: The convenience method expectAllExist() takes an array of descriptions and checks for their existence. Saving you a ton of typing effort.

Name: Convenience Methods - Update TypeScript ADK 0.18.0
Post Body:
In an earlier blog post we explained how convenience methods could be used to write more expressive AskUI code.

Those were based on common use cases we noticed and already brought improvements.

But we also discovered they needed to be more streamlined and include relations, to be useful in every scenario. That is why we went back to the drawing board to redesign the API and also include more elements like switches and checkboxes.

We think this update will be very useful for your efficiency!

Prerequisites

  • AskUI installed and configured on your system (Windows, Linux, macOS)
  • Check package.json for askui in version 0.18.0

The Idea Behind the Update

We wanted to have a more expressive method signature with better code completion. Also the method signatures should be more alike, so using does not feel like "Oh I have to read the docs every time!?".

That is why we chose to use objects with properties, so you can leverage "names" for parameters and also better Intellisense. Generally, the objects look nearly the same for every method and now also include an optional relation, so you can target elements that normally have a label or text nearest to them in some way:

  • Example: await aui.clickCheckbox({label: 'Toggle', relation: {type: 'leftOf'}})

Breaking Changes

We introduced two breaking changes for existing convenience methods clickText() and clickButton(). This was necessary to align the method signatures with the newly implemented convenience methods presented later in this post.

clickText()

What it does: Clicks a text.

What does it solve: More concise code for clicking a specific text.

API docs for clickText()

clickButton()
What it does: Clicks a button that has a text on it. 
What does it solve: More concise code for clicking a button.
API docs for clickButton()
clickCheckbox()
What it does: Clicks a checkbox that has a label nearest to it. 
What does it solve: More concise code for finding and clicking a checkbox.
API docs for clickCheckbox()
Example code:
clickSwitch
What it does: Clicks a switch that has a label nearest to it. 
What does it solve: More concise code for finding and clicking a switch.
API docs for clickSwitch()
Example code:
typeIntoTextfield()
What it does: Types text into a textfield which is specified in relation to a label.
What does it solve: More concise code for typing text into a textfield, where the textfield can be specified through a relation.
API docs for typeIntoTextfield()
Example code:
Conclusion
The update for the convenience methods unifies most of the common use cases. It also introduces objects as parameters that feel like named parameters.
Please let us know if you find them useful or if you need a convenience method for a specific purpose.
Post Summary: We returned to the drawing board to redesign the API and include more elements like switches and checkboxes. This update will be beneficial!

Name: Deep Learning's Challenges and Neurosymbolic AI's Solutions
Post Body:
What Are the Main Limitations of Deep Learning?

Deep learning models excel at pattern recognition but face serious gaps:

  • They lack common sense reasoning.
  • They demand vast datasets.
  • They often operate as "black boxes," making them hard to explain.
  • They struggle to generalize to new scenarios.
  • They falter on multi-step logical reasoning.

These gaps limit AI‚Äôs broader adoption in critical industries.

Comparison: Deep Learning vs. Neurosymbolic AI (2025)

Below is a clear side-by-side view of how traditional deep learning stacks up against neurosymbolic AI in solving these issues.

Feature Deep Learning Neurosymbolic AI
Common Sense Reasoning Weak, pattern-based only Enhanced with symbolic logic
Data Requirements Needs large labeled datasets Can learn from fewer samples using rules
Explainability Black box, low transparency Rule-based paths, more traceable
Generalization Poor outside training data Better transfer to new scenarios
Complex Reasoning Limited multi-hop inference Supports multi-step logical tasks

How Does Neurosymbolic AI Improve Common Sense Reasoning?

Neurosymbolic AI combines neural networks with symbolic logic.
By embedding explicit rules and symbolic structures, it gives machines a scaffold to process concepts like object permanence  something humans intuitively grasp, but deep networks alone do not.

Can Neurosymbolic AI Reduce Data Dependency?

Yes. Traditional deep learning needs massive labeled datasets.
Neurosymbolic systems integrate prior knowledge and logical rules, enabling learning from fewer samples. This is vital for fields with limited data, such as rare disease diagnostics or niche industrial applications.

How Does Neurosymbolic AI Address Explainability?

Deep learning‚Äôs opaque models raise trust concerns in healthcare and finance.
By adding symbolic reasoning layers, neurosymbolic AI makes decision paths clearer. Logical rules provide traceability, so stakeholders can understand why a decision was made ‚Äî increasingly critical under regulations like the EU AI Act.

Why Is Neurosymbolic AI Better at Generalization?

Standard deep learning models often fail on data that diverges from training sets.
By embedding symbolic logic, neurosymbolic systems apply learned rules to novel situations, improving robustness and adaptability across domains.

How Does Neurosymbolic AI Handle Complex Reasoning?

Deep networks alone struggle with multi-hop or relational reasoning.
Neurosymbolic AI integrates symbolic inference engines that can:

  • Chain logical deductions across multiple facts.
  • Maintain entity relationships.
  • Resolve contradictions.

This synergy enables advanced problem-solving beyond pattern matching.

What Are Real-World Examples of Neurosymbolic AI?

1. Logical Neural Networks (LNNs):
They fuse neural layers with direct logical operators, handling uncertainty and partial truths.

2. Semantic Parsing with Symbolic Knowledge Bases:
Transforms language into logic queries, letting AI tap structured data for richer answers.

3. Visual Reasoning Tasks:
Projects now use hybrid models to track obscured objects, mimicking infant cognitive milestones.

Internal Links

  • Automating Complex Billing and Payment Workflows
  • CSS and XPath Selectors in Web Automation

FAQ: Neurosymbolic AI in 2025

Q: Is neurosymbolic AI production-ready?
Many frameworks are still experimental, but robotics and compliance-heavy industries have started early pilots.

Q: How does it compare to pure symbolic AI?
It merges the flexibility of learning from data (deep learning) with logical constraints, offering a balanced hybrid.

Conclusion: Why Neurosymbolic AI Is the Future

By merging data-driven learning with rule-based reasoning, neurosymbolic AI addresses deep learning‚Äôs core weaknesses.
It‚Äôs shaping the next generation of explainable, reliable, and generalizable intelligent systems critical for regulated, high-stakes environments.

‚Äç
Post Summary: How does neurosymbolic AI solve deep learning's issues with data, explainability, and reasoning? Explore practical 2025 insights.

Name: Demystifying Smart Selectors
Post Body:
Why Do Classical Selectors Often Fail in UI Testing?

Classical test automation relies heavily on DOM-based selectors like XPath or CSS.
These selectors identify UI elements by their position or attributes in the Document Object Model (DOM).

But here‚Äôs the issue:

  • Even small changes in the DOM (like renaming an ID or class) can break tests.
  • This leads to flaky tests that pass or fail unpredictably.
  • Debugging becomes painful when selectors are long, technical, and hard to interpret.

‚Äç

When humans test, they visually recognize a "Login" button regardless of HTML changes.Classical automation scripts, however, fail if the DOM structure shifts.

What Are Smart Selectors?

Smart selectors try to bridge this gap by simulating how humans perceive and interact with UI.
They combine visual or relational context with classic selectors to create more resilient tests.

1. OCR (Optical Character Recognition)

OCR scans the UI like a human eye does, recognizing visible text.

  • Great for clicking buttons labeled ‚ÄúSubmit‚Äù or verifying key messages.
  • Often combined with DOM selectors to strengthen tests.

2. Picture-in-Picture (PiP) Search

PiP works by matching small image snippets of UI elements across the screen.

  • Closer to human perception than strict DOM lookup.
  • Useful when there‚Äôs no stable DOM reference.

3. Relational Descriptions (Relative Locators)

Instead of selecting an element directly, smart selectors can find elements by their relationship to others.

  • Example: Locate an input field under a ‚ÄúPassword‚Äù label.
  • Helps validate UI layout and flow.

How Do These Smart Selectors Help QA Teams?

Approach Best For Watch Out For
OCR Text labels & human-like validation Sensitive to font/rendering changes
Picture-in-Picture Visual-heavy or graphical interfaces Can break with resolution differences
Relational Locators Forms, structured layouts Needs clear relationships in UI design
  • They reduce test maintenance by making scripts less sensitive to backend code changes.
  • They allow tests to catch visual or spatial issues that DOM selectors miss.

FAQ: Smart Selectors in UI Testing

Can smart selectors replace all XPath or CSS selectors?
Not completely. They work best together‚Äîsmart selectors add robustness where classic ones fail.

Are these slower to run?
OCR and PiP can slightly increase execution time, but save hours of maintenance by catching issues early.

When should you use them?
Use smart selectors for critical user journeys like login, checkout, or any UI with frequent DOM changes.

Related Reading

  • CSS and XPath Selectors in Web Automation: Strengths, Weaknesses, and Best Practices
  • Beyond Functionality: Testing for Accessibility in Web Automation
Post Summary: Learn how OCR, PiP, and relational smart selectors mimic human UI testing, reducing flaky tests in automation.

Name: Desktop Automation: How It Works, Why It Matters, and How to Implement It Effectively
Post Body:
Desktop automation streamlines repetitive computer-based tasks, boosting productivity and reducing human error. It leverages software tools that mimic user actions to automate workflows, from data entry to report generation.

What is Desktop Automation?

Desktop automation automates rule-based tasks on a computer, using tools like Robotic Process Automation (RPA) to perform actions typically done by humans.

  • Examples: Data entry, file management, report generation.
  • Main benefit: Frees employees to focus on strategic, value-driven work.

Unlike broader process automation, desktop automation targets local user environments, making it ideal for quick wins in productivity.

Why is Desktop Automation Critical for QA Teams and Tech-Driven Organizations?

Desktop automation is essential for QA managers, automation leaders, and engineering teams seeking to optimize time and quality.

  • Increased productivity: Automates manual, repetitive tasks, accelerating test preparation, data setup, and environment configuration.
  • Reduced human error: Ensures consistent execution and data accuracy.
  • Cost efficiency: Cuts labor hours on low-value work, reallocates resources to high-impact projects.
  • Improved compliance: Enforces data handling and process standards automatically.

By deploying desktop automation, teams can manage higher workloads with fewer mistakes and faster turnaround.

How Do You Choose the Right Desktop Automation Tool?

Selecting the best tool requires aligning features with your team‚Äôs technical needs.

Consideration Why It Matters
Task Complexity Some tools handle simple macros; others support advanced workflows with AI.
Integration Capabilities Must fit with your current systems and CI/CD pipelines.
Ease of Use GUI-based tools reduce onboarding time for QA or business users.
Scalability & Maintenance Ensure it can grow with your organization and support long-term improvements.

Tip: For UI-heavy testing or validations, prioritize tools with OCR or image recognition.

How to Implement Desktop Automation Effectively?

1. Identify the Right Processes

Focus on high-frequency, rule-driven tasks that slow down QA or operations. Examples:

  • Generating test data sets
  • Cross-checking files or logs
  • Triggering multi-step UI actions for regression tests

2. Plan Workflows Collaboratively

Map each step with QA leads, developers, and ops. Document:

  • Inputs, triggers, decision points
  • Expected outputs
  • Failure handling steps

3. Test Before Full Rollout

Run pilots. Validate both functional accuracy (does it do the job?) and non-functional aspects (performance, security).

4. Train & Communicate

Hold short sessions to demystify automation and highlight how it eliminates grunt work, not people.

How Do You Maintain and Improve Desktop Automation?

  • Monitor: Track execution logs, error rates, and processing times.
  • Report: Generate metrics to prove ROI, e.g. hours saved or errors reduced.
  • Update: Regularly install tool patches to avoid security or compatibility gaps.
  • Iterate: Gather user feedback to refine workflows or expand coverage.

What Are Common Challenges in Desktop Automation?

Challenge Solution
Complex interfaces Use OCR or visual recognition for dynamic UIs.
Software updates breaking scripts Test after updates; maintain modular, easily fixable scripts.
Security & privacy concerns Restrict access, encrypt data, and audit regularly.
Employee pushback Show how it offloads tedious work, and offer training.

FAQs

How is desktop automation different from test automation?
Desktop automation focuses on any local repetitive task, while test automation specifically validates software functionality.

Can small teams afford it?
Yes. Many tools offer tiered pricing or even open-source options that work well for startups.

What happens if the UI changes?
Advanced tools use OCR or context recognition to adapt. Regular maintenance is still needed.

Internal Resources

  • How Smart Selectors Improve UI Testing Resilience
  • Our Automation Glossary
  • AskUI Desktop Validation Solutions
Post Summary: Boost productivity & reduce errors with desktop automation. Learn tools, processes & challenges in our 2025 guide.

Name: Developing an Automated UI Controller using GPT Agents and GPT-4 Vision
Post Body:
1. Introduction

The emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT has ushered in a new era in text generation and AI advancements. While tools such as AutoGPT have aimed at task automation, their reliance on underlying DOM/HTML code poses challenges for desktop applications built on .NET/.SAP. The GPT-4 Vision (GPT-4v) API addresses this limitation by focusing on visual inputs, eliminating the need for HTML code.

See the original post here

1.1 The Challenge of Grounding

Although GPT-4v excels in image analysis, accurately identifying UI element locations remains a challenge. In response, a solution called "Grounding" has been introduced, involving pre-annotating images with tools like Segment-Anything (SAM) to simplify object identification for GPT-4v.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

1.2 Adapting to the Usecase

UI elements can be numbered for reference, streamlining the interaction process. For example, the "Start for Free" button might be associated with the number "34," enabling GPT-4v to provide instructions that can be translated into corresponding coordinates for controller actions.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

2. Building Agents

The envisioned product/tool aims to enter a goal/task and receive a set of actions to achieve it. The system operates in three sequential capabilities: goal breakdown, vision (image understanding), and system control. A GPT-4 text model acts as the orchestrator, interfacing with both GPT-4v and the device controller.

‚Äç

3. GPT-4V Integration: Visionary Function

GPT-4v serves as the visual interpreter, analyzing UI screenshots and identifying elements for interaction. An example function is provided to showcase how UI element identification is requested

4. Device Controller: The Interactive Core
The Controller class is pivotal, executing UI actions based on GPT-4v's guidance. Functions include moving the mouse, double-clicking, entering text, and capturing annotated screenshots, ensuring seamless interaction with the system:
- move_mouse(): Moves the cursor and performs clicks.
- double_click_at_location(): Executes double clicks at specified locations.
- enter_text_at_location(): Inputs text at a given location.
- take_screenshot(): Captures and annotates the current UI state.
‚Äç
The below class ensures seamless interaction with the system, acting based on GPT-4v's guidance.
5. Orchestrator: The Strategic Planner
The Orchestrator, a GPT-4 text model, plans and executes tasks by leveraging the capabilities of the Device Controller and GPT-4v. Key components include the Planner (goal breakdown and action strategy), UserProxyAgent (communication facilitator), and Controller (UI action execution).
‚Äç
Key Components
  • Planner: Breaks down goals and strategizes actions.
  • UserProxyAgent: Facilitates communication between the planner and the controller.
  • Controller: Executes actions within the UI.
‚Äç
Workflow Example
1. Initialization: The Orchestrator receives a task.
2. Planning: It outlines the necessary steps.‚Äç
3. Execution: The Controller interacts with the UI, guided by the Orchestrator‚Äôs strategy.
4. Verification: The Orchestrator checks the outcomes and adjusts actions if needed.
We use AutoGen, an open source library that lets GPTs talk to each other, to implement the Automated UI controller. After giving each GPT its system message (or identity), we register the functions so that the GPT is aware of them and can call them when needed.
6. Workflow on a Sample Task
The workflow involves the Orchestrator receiving a task, planning the necessary steps, executing actions through the Controller, and verifying outcomes. The article demonstrates a sample task‚Äî"click on the GitHub icon and click on the 'blogs' repository"‚Äîwith a log history showcasing various executed functions.
‚Äç
‚Äç
‚Äç
Attached below is a log history, performing various actions. We can see that various functions are called and executed accordingly.
‚Äç
This article provides insight into the evolving automation landscape, anticipating remarkable developments built upon these technologies.
Post Summary: The emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT has ushered in a new era in text generation and AI advancements. While tools such asAutoGP

Name: Different Types of Automation for Web Application Testing
Post Body:
Automation in web application testing minimizes manual effort, accelerates release cycles, and ensures applications meet quality and compliance standards. This guide breaks down the most critical types of automation, their benefits, and how they directly support your QA objectives.

Why is Automation Critical in Web Application Testing?

Automation cuts down repetitive manual testing, speeds up bug detection, and guarantees more consistent results. This enables teams to deliver stable applications faster, enhance user experience, and maintain a competitive advantage.

Summary: Key Benefits of Automating Each Test Type

Test Type Key Benefits of Automation
Geolocation Testing Ensures compliance, local content & ads
Data-Driven Testing Broader coverage, fewer scripts needed
Regression Testing Saves time, improves consistency
Cross-Browser Testing Detects UI bugs across browsers quickly
Stress/Load Testing Finds performance bottlenecks early

What is Geolocation Testing and Why Does it Matter?

Geolocation testing validates how your application behaves across different regions. It ensures legal compliance, content accuracy, and personalized experiences.

Key areas automated geolocation testing covers:

  • Device Geolocation Access: Checks that apps retrieve and use location data properly for services like maps or local searches.
  • Regional Content Compliance: Verifies the app meets content regulations in each country, preventing legal risks.
  • Localized Advertising: Confirms region-specific ads display correctly, improving engagement and adhering to local norms.

üìö Related: Read about Smart Selectors for better UI automation

How Does Data-Driven Automation Increase Coverage?

Data-driven testing separates test logic from data inputs. Automated tests run multiple times with varied datasets, maximizing coverage with fewer scripts.

Benefits:

  • Broad Test Scope: Validates more scenarios without writing additional tests.
  • Faster Regression: Quickly checks stability across diverse data conditions after updates.

Why Automate Regression Testing?

Regression testing ensures new changes don‚Äôt break existing features. Automating this process is essential in modern CI/CD environments.

Advantages:

  • Time Efficiency: Automated regression suites run faster than manual checks, especially in large apps.
  • Reliable Consistency: Tests execute the same way each time, eliminating human variability.

How Does Automation Improve Cross-Browser Testing?

Cross-browser testing ensures your app looks and functions properly across different browsers and operating systems.

Why use automation:

  • Faster Issue Detection: Automated tools uncover rendering or behavior differences quickly.
  • Greater Coverage: Easily test dozens of browser-OS combinations without manual effort.

What Role Does Automation Play in Stress & Load Testing?

Stress and load tests push your app to its limits to reveal performance bottlenecks. Automation makes these heavy tests feasible and repeatable.

Why automate:

  • Scalable Simulations: Run thousands of virtual users to spot issues before users do.
  • Continuous Performance Checks: Regularly assess app resilience under high demand.

Manual vs Automated Testing: Quick Comparison

Manual Only With Automation
Slow release cycles Faster deployments
Prone to human error Consistent repeatable results
Difficult regression checks Rapid regression validation
High long-term costs Investment pays off over time

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

Q: Should small teams invest in automation early?
A: Yes. Even lightweight automation frameworks can prevent regression bugs and save time as your app grows.

Q: How do I prioritize which tests to automate first?
A: Focus on high-risk areas, critical user flows, and repetitive tasks that consume manual QA hours.

Internal Resources

  • How Smart Selectors Improve UI Testing Resilience
  • Browser Versions and its Compatibility for Your Website
  • Beyond Functionality: Testing for Accessibility in Web Automation

Conclusion: Why Embrace Automation Now?

Automation in web application testing is no longer optional.

From geolocation compliance to performance under stress, automated tests guarantee speed, consistency, and adaptability in a landscape where user expectations and regulations constantly evolve.

Investing in robust automation today ensures your app not only meets current demands but is primed to handle future complexities.

‚Äç
Post Summary: Web app testing automation: benefits, types, and best practices for QA teams. Ensure quality, compliance, and performance across geographies.

Name: End-to-End Testing: How to Move Beyond Selenium for Desktop Applications
Post Body:
Why Look Beyond Selenium for Desktop Testing?

Selenium is excellent for browser automation, but it wasn't built for desktop apps. QA leaders are now exploring AI-driven tools to overcome this gap.

  • Selenium‚Äôs core limitation: It interacts with the DOM, making it ideal for web‚Äîbut useless for native desktop GUIs.
  • Growing need: As software stacks expand, teams want unified testing that covers both web and desktop environments.

What Is AskUI and How Does It Help?

AskUI is an AI-powered automation platform that performs end-to-end testing across both web and desktop applications by combining:

  • Visual recognition: It ‚Äúsees‚Äù buttons, fields, and icons on the screen via screenshots.
  • Natural language processing (NLP): You can write tests like, ‚ÄúOpen the app, click Login, enter user details.‚Äù

How Does Screenshot-Based Testing Work?

Unlike Selenium‚Äôs code-focused approach, AskUI captures the current screen state and finds interactive UI elements directly from images.

Key advantages:

  1. Works even if the underlying code or tech stack changes.
  2. Supports cross-platform scenarios (web + desktop) in one flow.
  3. Reduces the need for extensive scripting.

Can Non-Technical Testers Use It?

Yes. With natural language commands, even non-developers can write and maintain robust tests.

  • Example:
  • This bridges the gap between QA engineers and business users.
Is This Approach More Resilient Than Selenium?
Often, yes. Since tests rely on visible UI rather than brittle DOM selectors or internal APIs, small code refactors don‚Äôt break tests.

  

    
      

        Feature
        Selenium Testing
        AskUI Screenshot Testing
      

    
    
      

        Platform focus
        Web only
        Web + Desktop
      

      

        Relies on
        DOM structure
        Visual screen content
      

      

        Script complexity
        High
        Low (natural language)
      

      

        Adapts to UI redesigns
        Often fails
        Usually unaffected
      

    
  





What makes AskUI effective for testing desktop apps?
It skips DOM and API calls, analyzing the screen visually with AI perfect for traditional desktop GUIs.
Should Selenium be replaced with AskUI?
No. Selenium still leads browser testing. AskUI simply broadens your reach to include robust desktop tests.
Why is test maintenance simpler?
Because you avoid brittle DOM selectors, your tests survive UI style tweaks. Screenshot plus NLP keeps them stable.

Conclusion: Ready to Evolve Beyond Selenium?
If your QA strategy still relies only on Selenium, it may be time to adopt a more holistic approach. Tools like AskUI bring end-to-end testing to both web and desktop apps, using AI to simplify workflows and reduce fragile test scripts.

  • Review your current test coverage for desktop workflows.
  • Experiment with screenshot-based tools like AskUI to complement your Selenium suite.
  • Track improvements in test stability and maintenance overhead.

Name: End-to-End UI Automation Testing for Desktop & Mobile (Updated: July 2025)
Post Body:
What Is End-to-End (E2E) UI Automation Testing?

End-to-End UI automation testing verifies that your application works as a complete system by simulating real user workflows. Unlike unit or integration tests, E2E testing checks the entire tech stack‚Äîfrom the UI to the backend‚Äîensuring every component collaborates seamlessly.

This approach reduces critical bugs in production, protects user trust, and accelerates releases.

Why Should You Care About E2E UI Testing?

Launching an app without robust E2E UI testing is risky. Even beautifully designed apps can fail under real-world usage if workflows break or edge cases are missed.

E2E UI automation replicates user actions across your app, ensuring everything from login flows to complex transactions works flawlessly‚Äîon every browser and device.

How Does E2E UI Testing Work?

E2E tests perform user interactions programmatically, validating end-to-end scenarios. They:

  • Navigate through the UI like a user would.
  • Trigger backend APIs and database calls.
  • Verify outputs and system states.

Think of it this way:

  • Unit tests = check individual instruments.
  • Integration tests = check sections (strings, percussion).
  • E2E tests = ensure the entire orchestra plays in harmony.

What Tools Can You Use for E2E UI Testing?

QA teams rely on several frameworks:

Tool Key Strengths
Selenium Mature ecosystem, wide browser support
Cypress Fast, developer-friendly, modern JS architecture
Playwright Powerful for multi-browser & cross-platform testing
AskUI Visual automation that sees UI like a human; ideal for complex desktop apps

Explore our Desktop Validation Solutions ‚Üí

What Are the Main Benefits of E2E UI Automation?

  1. Enhanced Accuracy
    Removes manual errors, validating complete workflows consistently.
  2. Load Resilience
    Simulates high-traffic scenarios to catch performance issues early.
  3. Cost Savings
    Finds bugs before launch, when they‚Äôre cheaper to fix.
  4. Faster Releases
    Automated suites run around the clock, shortening feedback cycles.

What Challenges Should You Expect?

  • Setup Complexity: E2E tests take time to design, requiring robust architecture.
  • Test Fragility: Minor UI changes can break scripts, demanding maintenance.
  • Performance Trade-offs: Too many E2E tests can slow CI pipelines.

Best Practices for E2E UI Automation

  • Define Scope: Prioritize critical user journeys.
  • Use Cross-Browser Testing: Avoid surprises on Firefox vs Chrome vs Safari.
  • Regularly Update Tests: Refactor to match UI/feature changes.
  • Integrate Reporting: Tools like Allure or JUnit provide actionable insights.

FAQs

What makes AskUI different from Selenium or Cypress?
AskUI uses vision-based selectors, recognizing UI elements by appearance similar to a human tester. This makes it powerful for desktop apps or dynamic interfaces where traditional DOM locators fail.

Is E2E UI testing only for large teams?
No. Even startups benefit by automating core flows, catching bugs early, and building user trust.

Conclusion: Why E2E Testing Matters in 2025

End-to-End UI automation is more than just another QA checkbox it‚Äôs your safeguard against costly production bugs and churned users.

By validating real user journeys, you protect brand reputation and ensure every deployment delights rather than disappoints.
Post Summary: Why is E2E UI automation testing critical for QA teams? Discover tools, benefits, challenges, and best practices.

Name: Enhancing Software Engineering with Virtual Desktop Automation
Post Body:
What Is Virtual Desktop Automation in Software Engineering?

Tired of endless local setups that break?
Virtual desktop automation means running your entire dev stack in cloud-based environments, combined with automated tools. It replaces fragile manual configs with scalable, test-ready systems so your team codes, tests, and deploys faster, without surprises.

How Does Virtual Desktop Automation Streamline Workflows?

Still spending hours configuring environments?
Stop. Virtual desktops can spin up identical workspaces in minutes, paired with scripts that handle repetitive setup and QA tasks.

üìä At a glance:

Benefit Impact
Automated Environment Setup Zero manual steps, fewer errors
Remote Accessibility Same stack anywhere ‚Äî home, office, travel
Built-in Automated Testing Run QA + CI/CD without local headaches
Centralized Security Keep sensitive data off personal machines
Cost Efficiency No overpaying for idle hardware

Why Is Flexibility a Major Advantage?

What if your exact dev environment followed you anywhere?
With virtual desktops, it does. Whether on a caf√© Wi-Fi, your home office, or a corporate VPN  your same stack, tools, and scripts come along.

  • Perfect for hybrid or distributed teams.
  • Scale compute power instantly via the cloud.
  • Never waste hours reconfiguring a new laptop.

How Do Automation Tools Integrate with Virtual Desktops?

Testing manually? Or still debugging ‚Äúworks on my machine‚Äù failures?
Automated QA and CI/CD pipelines fit right into virtual desktops, running tests and builds without local dependencies breaking.

Examples:

  • Overnight regression suites catch bugs before coffee.
  • CI tools like Jenkins or GitLab spin up fresh VMs to validate every commit.
  • Automated UI checks ensure your product looks right across device profiles.

üìñ Related:

  • Different Types of Automation for Web Testing
  • Demystifying Smart Selectors

What About Security and Compliance?

Worried about sensitive data leaking from laptops?
Virtual desktops centralize your critical code and data in secure cloud instances. Admins control exactly who accesses what  meeting HIPAA, GDPR, or ISO standards far easier than on scattered local machines.

  • Data never lives on personal devices.
  • Encryption + centralized patching.
  • Detailed audit logs ready for regulators.

How Does Virtual Desktop Automation Improve Collaboration?

Stop chasing mismatched local setups.
With virtual environments, every developer, tester, or product owner works in the exact same stack.

  • Real-time debugging on shared VMs.
  • Faster feature approvals and QA sign-offs.
  • Zero ‚Äúwait, it works here but fails there‚Äù issues.

Is It Cost-Effective Compared to Traditional Setups?

Buying top-spec laptops for every dev  even if they barely use them?
Virtual desktops flip the model: pay only for the resources you actually consume. Spin up beefy GPUs for a heavy build, then shut them down.

  • Lower hardware refresh spend.
  • Fewer idle licenses or power bills.
  • Budgets shift to hiring or new product features.

FAQ: Virtual Desktop Automation for Software Teams

What tools run best here?

  • Automated QA like AskUI or Selenium
  • CI/CD platforms (Jenkins, GitLab CI)
  • Any IDE pre-loaded with your company‚Äôs stack

How quickly can teams migrate?

Many teams run pilots in 2‚Äì4 weeks, then scale org-wide in sprints.

Only for enterprises?

Not at all. Startups and growing remote teams arguably gain even more  they avoid costly local hardware investments.

Conclusion: Why Should You Adopt Virtual Desktop Automation?

Because slower teams lose.
Virtual desktop automation removes local friction, secures your code, standardizes tests, and empowers hybrid teams.

For vibe coders, QA managers, and anyone shipping fast  it‚Äôs a future-proof foundation that pays off from day one.

‚Äç
Post Summary: How virtual desktop automation improves productivity, security, and collaboration in software engineering.

Name: Enhancing Text Selection and Relational Selectors with Optional Parameters
Post Body:
In the past, you had to write text().withText(<your text>) for text selection. This was tedious to write and additionally hard to read, too.

Now, we've implemented optional parameters, allowing you to simply use text(<your text here>) with your preferred parameter. This makes it easier to select text and improves readability.

And before introducing optional parameters for relational selectors like above(), below(), leftOf(), and rightOf(), you could only select the first element. Making it impossible to automate things where you wanted to target the nth-element.

You can now add an index, which starts at zero, to select other elements more conveniently like this

await au.click().text().below(2).textfield().exec()

In this blog post we show you how you can use the optional parameters to improve your automations ü•≥

Optional Parameters for `text()`

Targeting a text-element before optional parameters was done like this:

This is unpleasant to write and also to read. Now you can shorten it by leaving out the withText() and supply your text directly to text() like this:
Optional Parameters for Relational Selectors
Let us start with an example first. How would you select the text WOOHOO when you can only target the text FIRST reliably?
Exactly. You would have to rely on SECOND which may clutter your code and blur your intentions like this!
await aui.moveMouseTo().text().rightOf().text('SECOND).exec();
But you can now use an index for relational selectors like above(): For the first element, input nothing or zero; for the second, input one; for the third, input two, and so on.
This enables you to select the second element right of FIRST with ease.
Conclusion
With the new optional parameter for `text()` we simplified the targeting of text elements.
With the optional index-Parameter for relational selectors like above() it is now possible to select the nth-element and target elements in your AskUI automations that were hard to target before.
Also check out the docs:
  • text()
  • Relational Selector above()

Name: Examples of Vision AI Agents
Post Body:
In today's digital landscape, vision AI agents are making significant strides, transforming the way we interact with technology. These agents use advanced algorithms to interpret, analyze, and act on visual data. This post delves into several examples of vision AI agents, showcasing their diverse applications and the innovative ways they are being used across different domains.

Stable Diffusion and AI Image Analyzers

One illustrative example of a vision AI agent is the system using Stable Diffusion for image generation. This configuration involves two primary components: a text-to-image generator and an AI image analyzer. The text-to-image generator produces images based on user prompts, while the AI image analyzer evaluates these images, providing valuable feedback for refinement. Through repeated iterations, this system enhances the quality of generated images. The process illustrates the synergy between creativity and analysis, as continuous feedback loops drive improvements in image generation results.

Vision Language Models (VLMs)

Vision Language Models (VLMs) epitomize the next level of AI capabilities by simultaneously processing visual and textual data. These models are adept at recognizing and contextualizing visual information, bridging the gap between images and their textual descriptions. They can generate text-based descriptions from images or create images from given text prompts. VLMs are particularly useful in business applications, where they streamline processes like automating customer support and digitizing invoices, making workflows more efficient and less reliant on human intervention.

AskUI Vision Agent

AskUI's Vision agent highlights another frontier of vision AI capabilities. With the ability to control a computer interface through visual input, AskUI can perform tasks such as conducting web research and interacting with digital applications. It simulates human actions like clicking buttons and entering text, effectively acting as a human surrogate for computer interaction. This AI capability advances productivity by automating tasks that typically require direct human engagement, thereby freeing up human resources for more strategic roles.

Automated Vision Tasks

In the realm of automation, vision AI agents are crafting pathways for generating Python programs to automate repetitive tasks. A notable application includes analyzing visual data to detect surfers near sharks in video footage. By leveraging AI algorithms to bind visual inputs and detected objects, these agents can automate surveillance and monitoring tasks efficiently, thereby enhancing safety measures and operational accuracy in potentially dangerous environments.

Interactive Computer Control

Interactive visions agents are revolutionizing computer control by enabling users to command their systems through visual cues. Workshops have demonstrated these agents in various operating systems like iOS, Linux, and Windows. They enhance productivity through automation processes such as form filling and quality assurance in software testing. By interpreting visual inputs effectively, vision AI agents significantly reduce the time and effort required for repetitive and routine tasks.

Conclusion

Vision AI agents are revolutionizing numerous fields by offering innovative solutions to both everyday tasks and complex challenges. From augmenting image generation processes to streamlining business operations and improving safety in hazardous scenarios, vision AI agents demonstrate a versatile range of applications, marking significant progress in the capabilities of artificial intelligence systems.
Post Summary: Vision AI agents are revolutionizing numerous fields by offering innovative solutions to both everyday tasks and complex challenges.

Name: Exploring Computer Vision Techniques
Post Body:
What is Computer Vision in AI?

Computer vision is a branch of AI that enables machines to extract, analyze, and act on information from images or videos. This technology powers everything from face unlock on your phone to object detection in autonomous vehicles.

What Are the Core Computer Vision Techniques?

Modern computer vision relies on a set of well-proven techniques, each tailored to different data problems. Here‚Äôs a quick breakdown:

  1. Feature Extraction: Identifies critical patterns or key points in images. Used for object recognition or tracking.
  2. Object Detection: Locates and classifies multiple objects in an image or video frame. Vital for self-driving systems.
  3. Motion Tracking: Monitors the movement of objects across frames. Helps in crowd analytics or sports tech.
  4. Face Recognition: Matches a face against stored profiles. Powers authentication systems.

Which Machine Learning Algorithms Are Used in Computer Vision?

Computer vision stacks typically combine domain-specific techniques with powerful ML algorithms. The most popular include:

Which Machine Learning Algorithms Are Used in Computer Vision?

Technique Best For Quick Description
CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) Image classification, object detection, facial analysis Deep learning models that excel at spatial pattern recognition.
RNNs (Recurrent Neural Networks) Sequential data like video frames or text overlays Capture temporal relationships, often paired with CNNs for video.
SVMs (Support Vector Machines) Binary or multiclass image classification Effective for structured features, robust in smaller datasets.
Random Forests Broad classification or regression tasks Ensemble of decision trees that generalize well, used in multi-modal systems.

How Are Startups Using Computer Vision Right Now?

For fast-moving AI product teams, computer vision is already core infrastructure. Typical use cases include:

  • Self-Driving Cars: Detect lanes, vehicles, and pedestrians in real time to make split-second decisions.
  • Medical Imaging: Flag anomalies in X-rays or MRIs faster and sometimes more accurately than radiologists.
  • Retail Automation: Track inventory, identify loyal customers, and spot theft attempts.
  • Security & Surveillance: Monitor large crowds for unusual patterns, improving incident response.

What Are the Strategic Advantages of Computer Vision?

Startups and dev teams leverage computer vision to:

  • Reduce Operational Costs: Automate inspections, compliance checks, and diagnostics.
  • Improve Accuracy: Minimize human error in high-stakes environments like healthcare or autonomous driving.
  • Scale Faster: Deploy features across thousands of endpoints (cameras, phones, sensors) without proportional labor increases.

FAQ: Computer Vision for Vibe Coders

How do I choose the right technique for my app?

If your main data is static images, start with CNNs. For tracking over time (video, motion), combine CNNs with RNNs. Use SVMs or Random Forests if you have smaller, well-labeled datasets.

Is this feasible for small dev teams?

Absolutely. With pre-trained models and cloud APIs, even lean teams can integrate advanced computer vision features without heavy infra.

Will it slow down deployment?

Not with the right setup. Edge-optimized models and GPU inference pipelines mean most vision workloads run in milliseconds.

Final Takeaway

Computer vision is no longer a bleeding-edge luxury it‚Äôs a foundational layer for competitive AI apps. By strategically choosing the right techniques, your team can ship smarter, safer, and faster products.

Ready to see how you can bring these vision techniques into your own app? Test it live with our new chat-driven AskUI beta or watch it in action.

üöÄ Want to try it yourself? Try our beta version here  |  üé• Watch the demo video
Post Summary: Discover key computer vision techniques CNNs, RNNs, SVMs and how startups use them for AI-driven apps, from medical scans to self-driving cars.

Name: Exploring Cypress: Can It Automate Desktop Applications?
Post Body:
What Is Cypress Designed For?

Cypress is an open-source end-to-end testing framework built for browser-based applications. It allows QA engineers to test modern frontend UIs directly in the browser with real-time feedback.

Key Capabilities (2025):

  • Runs inside the browser for direct DOM access
  • Real-time reloads and debugging
  • Flake-resistant test execution
  • Built-in support for major CI pipelines
  • No need for WebDriver or external dependencies

Important: Cypress cannot test beyond the browser context.

Can Cypress Automate Desktop Applications?

No, Cypress cannot automate native desktop applications.
It is limited to DOM-based interactions in Chromium browsers and cannot access native UI components such as system windows, file dialogs, or operating system menus.

Are There Plugins or Workarounds?

As of July 2025, there are no official or community-supported plugins that extend Cypress to support desktop automation.

Attempts to combine Cypress with tools like Electron or external scripting layers have proven fragile and are not recommended for production use.

What Are the Best Tools for Desktop App Automation?

QA engineers turn to tools built specifically for native GUI automation. Each has different strengths depending on your environment:

Tool Platform Support Highlights
AutoIt Windows only Scriptable; fast for small UI tasks.
SikuliX Cross-platform (Java) Image-based; good for legacy UIs.
WinAppDriver Windows only Microsoft UI Automation API support.
AskUI Recommended Windows, macOS, Linux Vision-based AI; automates web + desktop without selectors.

‚úÖ Among emerging tools, AskUI stands out in 2025 for its ability to visually automate both web and desktop interfaces ideal for teams seeking platform-agnostic UI automation without scripting element selectors.

Can I Use Cypress and Desktop Tools Together?

Yes with some orchestration effort.

You can:

  1. Run Cypress for web testing
  2. Use AskUI, AutoIt, or SikuliX for native UI automation
  3. Coordinate test flows using a CI pipeline (e.g., GitHub Actions, Jenkins)

While feasible, this hybrid model requires careful timing and test isolation to avoid false positives.

When Should QA Engineers Avoid Cypress?

Avoid Cypress when:

  • Testing native desktop apps (Windows/macOS/Linux)
  • Interacting with system dialogs or file explorers
  • Running tests in non-browser-based Electron windows
  • Needing to automate across web + desktop flows

Cross-Platform Testing in 2025: Tool Selection Guide

Application Type Recommended Tool(s)
Web UI (browser-based) Cypress
Native Windows UI WinAppDriver, AutoIt
Cross-platform Desktop SikuliX, AskUI
Web + Desktop Hybrid Unified AskUI

Tools like AskUI are increasingly adopted in QA pipelines for their ability to ‚Äúsee‚Äù and act on any UI browser or native based on visual context and natural language prompts.

FAQ

Can Cypress automate native desktop apps?

No. It is browser-only and cannot access native OS interfaces.

Is there a plugin to extend Cypress to desktop?

No, and none are expected in the official roadmap as of 2025.

What‚Äôs the most flexible tool for automating both web and desktop?

AskUI. It uses computer vision and natural language to automate visible interfaces across all platforms.
Post Summary: Cypress doesn‚Äôt support desktop app automation. Here's a 2025 update on what QA engineers should know and which tools to use instead.

Name: Exploring Power Automate: Can it Automate Desktop Applications?
Post Body:
When it comes to automating tasks, there's a constant search for tools that can handle the complexities of various applications. While many tools excel in automating web-based tasks, desktop applications often present a unique challenge.

What is Power Automate?

Power Automate is a cloud-based platform developed by Microsoft that allows users to automate workflows across a range of applications and services. Its strength lies in its extensive library of pre-built connectors, including popular services like Microsoft 365, Dynamics 365, SAP, and Salesforce. These connectors simplify the process of integrating different systems and automating tasks between them. Power Automate provides a user-friendly, low-code environment where users can design, deploy, and manage automated workflows.

The Desktop Dilemma

However, Power Automate encounters difficulties when confronted with desktop applications. While it offers Robotic Process Automation (RPA) capabilities to interact with legacy systems, these are often limited to pre-defined UI actions and may not handle complex desktop workflows effectively.

Visual Automation: AskUI

AskUI offers a different approach to desktop automation. AskUI utilizes the power of AI-driven Vision Agents that interact with desktop applications in a way similar to humans. These Vision Agents can "see" elements on the screen and perform actions based on visual cues, making them highly adaptable to various desktop environments. AskUI's Development Kit enables users to create custom Vision Agents that precisely automate even the most intricate desktop workflows.

Looking Forward: A Better Fit?

AskUI's focus on visual automation, combined with the flexibility of custom Vision Agents, makes it a strong contender for automating desktop applications. Its intuitive approach may offer a more effective and user-friendly solution for tackling the challenges of desktop automation, particularly in cases where traditional methods struggle.
Post Summary: Power Automate automates workflows across a range of applications. This leads to the question: can Appium automate desktop applications?

From MVP to Production: Why Speed Needs a Trust Layer
Post Body:
Fast Builds vs Trust: The Core Dilemma

In 2025, shipping an MVP in days is business as usual.
AI frameworks, component libraries, and automated CI/CD pipelines let most teams launch production code before the weekend is over.
But that same speed often skips critical checks and users catch it immediately.

According to the 2025 App Reliability Index, over 60% of new apps lose users in the first week, simply because trust breaks faster than you can build.
Imagine releasing your shiny new app on Friday, only to see retention plummet by Monday because a subtle UI glitch slipped through.

That‚Äôs the dilemma: you want to move quickly to test ideas, but each rushed build risks your product‚Äôs reputation.

Why AI-Powered QA Is the Missing Piece

Modern development teams already know: manual checks alone can‚Äôt keep up with today‚Äôs velocity.
This is where an AI-powered QA feature becomes essential.
It acts as the trust layer that matches your shipping speed running machine-scale validations that probe your app the way thousands of users would.

Instead of hoping human testers catch every edge case, this feature works right inside your CI/CD, tirelessly flagging issues before they ever reach real customers.

What Exactly Does the AI QA Feature Do?

This dedicated feature is purpose-built for developers who ship fast.
It runs thousands of smart visual checks and validates workflows automatically, catching:

‚úÖ Layout breaks that only appear on certain resolutions
‚úÖ Text overlaps or cut-offs from dynamic translations
‚úÖ Inconsistent component states triggered by unusual user flows

All without writing fragile scripts or maintaining endless selectors.
This means you get clear, automated proof that your app is stable your ‚Äústamp of quality‚Äù that both users and investors will trust.

Why This Matters for Vibe Coders & Fast Builders

By 2025, rapid releases aren‚Äôt impressive they‚Äôre expected.
What‚Äôs rare is pairing that speed with bulletproof reliability.

This AI QA feature lets you keep shipping fast without leaving your product‚Äôs trust to chance:

  • Catch regressions before they hit production
  • Automate thousands of UI scenarios with zero brittle code
  • Reduce manual QA hours by up to 60%, freeing your team for exploratory tests
  • Generate reports that prove your app meets rigorous quality standards

So your users stay engaged, your metrics keep climbing, and you build a reputation for shipping software that simply works.

See It Side by Side: Manual QA vs AI QA

Feature Manual QA James AI (AI QA)
Coverage Speed Weeks Hours
Scenarios Tested ~100 (team-limited) ~5,000+ auto-generated
Resilient to UI tweaks? Often breaks Vision-based, stays stable
Produces stakeholder reports? No Yes

Frequently Asked Questions

Can the feature spot non-obvious UI glitches?
Yes. Its vision-based diffing and smart assertions flag subtle issues like alignment shifts or conditional styling bugs that functional scripts would miss.

Will it actually reduce our manual QA hours?
Absolutely. Most teams cut repetitive UI validations by over 60%, letting manual testers focus on critical exploratory scenarios.

Does it produce reports I can share with stakeholders?
Yes. The feature generates detailed trust reports on which flows passed, where issues were found, and how your app stacks up against your benchmarks.

Why Every AI-Built MVP Needs This Trust Layer

Rapid releases are the baseline in 2025.
But shipping fast without proving quality still costs real users and eventually, your reputation.

This AI QA feature ensures your quickly built MVP isn‚Äôt just ready to launch, but ready to be trusted.
It‚Äôs not only about velocity; it‚Äôs about shipping with bulletproof quality baked in from day one.

Don‚Äôt wait for users to discover your bugs.
Add a trust layer now and ship with confidence.

Related Resources

  • Our new AI chat‚Äì Personal AI Test Engineer
  • How AskUI Automates UI Testing
  • Real-World Automation Case Studies
Post Summary: Ship MVPs fast without losing trust. AI QA is your safety net‚Äîcatch UI bugs early, prove quality, and keep users loyal from day one.

Name: From Manual Testing to Automated Excellence: A Roadmap for QA Teams
Post Body:
Manual testing has long been the foundation of QA. It‚Äôs hands-on, flexible, and ideal for early-stage development. But as products grow more complex and release cycles accelerate, manual testing alone can‚Äôt keep up.

To deliver consistent quality at speed, teams need to evolve and test automation is the way forward.

üëâ Curious how a real QA team made this shift?
See how Zucchetti transformed their testing with AskUI

The Limits of Manual Testing

Manual testing offers adaptability, but it doesn‚Äôt scale:

  • It‚Äôs slow when test coverage grows
  • Results vary depending on who runs the test
  • Regression testing becomes a bottleneck before every release

QA teams are expected to move faster without sacrificing quality. Automation helps bridge that gap  enabling the shift from manual to automated testing across the entire pipeline.

Automation: Beyond Speed

Test automation isn‚Äôt just about running tests faster. It brings:

  • Consistency across test runs
  • Earlier bug detection
  • Freed-up time for strategic, exploratory testing

And with tools like AskUI, even highly dynamic UIs or apps without stable selectors can be tested  using a visual approach that mimics how humans interact with the UI.

A Practical Roadmap for QA Automation

1. Start with the Right Test Cases

Focus on repetitive, stable, and business-critical flows: login, checkout, form submission, etc.

2. Pick Tools That Fit Your App

Traditional tools may struggle with modern UIs. Visual automation platforms like AskUI interact directly with rendered elements  perfect for canvas-based or visually complex apps.

3. Begin Small, Build Modular

Start with one test, break it into reusable blocks (e.g., ‚Äúlogin,‚Äù ‚Äúnavigate,‚Äù ‚Äúassert result‚Äù). This makes scaling easier later.

4. Involve the Team

Use tools that allow non-developers to understand and contribute to test automation. Collaboration improves both coverage and test design.

5. Track Progress

Measure:

  • Time saved
  • Bugs caught pre-release
  • Test stability across updates

Use this to iterate and expand automation over time.

Case in Point: Zucchetti's QA Transformation

Zucchetti, a major European software company, faced the usual manual testing challenges: time-consuming workflows, regressions slipping through, and difficulty scaling tests for a complex UI.

By adopting AskUI, they reduced test time, improved accuracy, and gave their QA team the freedom to focus on higher-value work.

Zucchetti‚Äôs story is a clear example of test automation success  showing what‚Äôs possible when QA teams commit to meaningful transformation.

What‚Äôs Next for QA Teams?

As software continues to evolve rapidly, QA teams are expected to do more  without slowing down delivery. While manual testing still plays a key role, it can no longer scale alone.

By combining automation with human expertise, teams can ensure both speed and quality. And with tools like AskUI, even testing visually complex or dynamic UIs becomes simpler than ever.

Whether you're just starting or scaling your automation strategy, a clear roadmap and the right technology make all the difference.
