Name: Join askui on the Web Summit 22
Post Body:
askui is happy to announce, that we will be part of the German Pavilion for Web Summit 22 from Nov 1 to Nov 4, 2022. The "German Pavilion" is the name of the official joint stand of German companies at trade fairs worldwide. As an exhibitor, German companies present their products and services under the "Made in Germany" brand.

In the internet portal german-pavilion.com you will find an overview of the German participations in international trade fairs. Each of the trade fair participations listed there has its own website. Here you will find detailed information on the participating German companies and the products on display in English and in the respective national language.

‚Äç

The Web Summit is one of the largest tech and startup conferences worldwide. They state on their website:

We‚Äôre a company from Dublin, Ireland, that holds events across the world: Web Summit in Lisbon, Web Summit Rio in Rio de Janeiro, Collision in Toronto, and RISE in Hong Kong.
Politico has said we run ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs premier tech conference‚Äù,
the Atlantic that Web Summit is ‚Äúwhere the future goes to be born‚Äù, and the New York Times that we assemble ‚Äúa grand conclave of the tech industry‚Äôs high priests.‚Äù
At a time of great uncertainty for many industries and, indeed, the world itself, we gather the founders and CEOs of technology companies, fast-growing startups, policymakers, and heads of state to ask a simple question: Where to next?

‚Äç

More information about the askui on the Web Summit 22 can be found here.
Post Summary: askui is joining the German Pavilon on Web Summit 22.

Name: Machine Learning in Testing
Post Body:
Having a reliable QA strategy is important for the smooth functioning of the software. While there are software testing methods that utilize the latest technological advancements to pinpoint bugs, save time, and run various test scenarios, adding Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) to the QA process takes it to a next level enabling businesses to enhance their testing process.

Types of Test Automation Using Machine Learning

  • Automated User Interface Testing (UI)

It can be fascinating to manually test website visuals, but it can also be challenging to catch some broken elements on the page. In this case, Machine Learning is best used to detect and verify UI bugs using image recognition technology.

  • Developing unit tests

Machine Learning helps developers spend more time writing code and less time creating and running unit tests. The creation and maintenance of AI-based unit test scripts are also useful at the end of the product life cycle.

  • API Testing

API testing is quite challenging without Machine Learning or Artificial Intelligence since it involves understanding how APIs work and creating test cases and scenarios. Machine Learning in test automation allows you to analyze and create tests based on API activity and traffic. However, modifying the tests will require an understanding of Representational State Transfer calls and their parameters.

  • Testing Scripts

Any update, upgrade, or code change will require altering the test scripts; therefore, you must qualify several test scripts. Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning tools can predict whether a test application will need multiple tests. As a result, you avoid wasting your time and money on unproductive test cases.

  • Artificial Intelligence and Machine learning-based test data generation

Datasets are the building blocks of AI models. The same is true for test scripts. As part of test automation, Machine Learning can be used to generate data sets resembling personal profiles such as photographs and weight information. The information is derived from trained Machine Learning models that utilize existing production datasets. In this way, datasets are created comparable to production data, which is ideal for software testing.

  • Regression Testing with Robotic Process Automation (RPA)

RPA automates existing IT systems while maintaining them simultaneously. A scan of the screen, navigation of the systems, and identification and collection of data occur. Through web and mobile applications, all tasks are automated and run through robots. In addition, its main advantages are scalability, cost savings, improved productivity, codeless testing, and accurate output.

Machine Learning and Test Automation: Future Applications and Opportunities

Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning are just scratching the surface for test automation. These technologies are still in development and have huge potential that could significantly enhance current test automation. There are lots of applications and opportunities that Machine Learning in test automation can provide in the future for IT enterprises, and here are some of them:

  • Test automation will become the standard with Machine Learning, ultimately replacing manual testing. Despite this, companies will adopt a culture of frequent testing using test automation.
  • With AI and Machine Learning taking over the role of producing, training, running, and generating results in less time and at a lower cost, IT organizations would be able to provide their customers with quality results.
  • An AI-based test generation tool will solve the issue of too many or too few test cases. The intelligent tools will probably make life easier for testers and coders, whether they are testing UIs or APIs.
  • In light of the rise of Predictive Test Selection, organizations struggling to manage huge datasets are likely to benefit greatly. Testing even a small change can take many IT enterprises hours and days. Test Selection predicts which tests will fail after incoming modifications are processed.
  • Combining test automation and Machine Learning will save time and money now and in the future, encouraging companies to use this duo across all departments of their company.

‚Äç

Name: Mastering Test Automation: A Comprehensive Guide
Post Body:
Welcome to our comprehensive guide on mastering test automation. In today's fast-paced software development landscape, the demand for efficient and effective testing methodologies has never been greater. Test automation has emerged as a crucial aspect of software testing, enabling organizations to improve efficiency, reduce time-to-market, and enhance software quality.

In this guide, we will delve into the world of test automation, covering everything from the basics and importance of test automation to setting up the test automation environment. We will explore the significance of choosing the right tools for test automation and provide insights into essential tools that can streamline your testing process. Additionally, we will guide you through the process of setting up a solid test automation framework, ensuring a robust foundation for your testing efforts.

Once the test automation environment is in place, we will shift our focus to developing and implementing test automation scripts. You will learn how to identify tests that are suitable for automation and how to write effective test scripts that cover critical functionality. We will also discuss best practices for running and managing test scripts, enabling you to maximize the efficiency of your test automation efforts.

Maintaining and enhancing the test automation suite is a crucial aspect of successful test automation. We will explore the importance of regularly reviewing and updating test scripts to ensure their relevance and accuracy. Additionally, we will discuss how to incorporate new tests as the product evolves and how to address test failures and flaky tests effectively.

Finally, we will explore how to measure the success of test automation. We will delve into defining success metrics for test automation and evaluating test coverage. Furthermore, we will discuss the importance of understanding the return on investment (ROI) of test automation and how it can drive decision-making within your organization.

Whether you are new to test automation or looking to enhance your existing skills, this comprehensive guide will equip you with the knowledge and techniques needed to master test automation. So, let's dive in and unlock the power of test automation for your software testing endeavors.

Understanding Test Automation: Basics and Importance

Test automation is a technique that involves the use of specialized software tools to automate the execution of tests, compare the actual results to the expected results, and generate detailed test reports. It is a vital component of modern software development and testing processes, offering numerous benefits to organizations of all sizes.

What is Test Automation?

Test automation involves the use of scripting or programming languages to create automated test scripts that simulate user interactions with the software under test. These scripts can perform various actions such as inputting data, interacting with user interfaces, and verifying expected outcomes. By automating these repetitive and time-consuming tasks, test automation helps teams save valuable time and resources while increasing the overall efficiency of the testing process.

The Importance of Test Automation

  1. Efficiency: Test automation significantly reduces the time and effort required to execute test cases. Automated tests can be run repeatedly and consistently, allowing for faster feedback on software quality. This efficiency enables teams to test more frequently, catch bugs earlier in the development cycle, and deliver high-quality software at a faster pace.
  2. Accuracy: Manual testing is prone to human error, which can lead to inconsistent results and unreliable test outcomes. Test automation eliminates the risk of human error, ensuring accurate and reliable test results. Automated tests can precisely follow predefined steps and verify expected outcomes, providing confidence in the software's functionality.
  3. Regression Testing: As software evolves and new features are added, regression testing becomes critical to ensure that existing functionality remains intact. Manual regression testing can be time-consuming and error-prone. Test automation allows for the creation of comprehensive regression test suites that can be executed effortlessly, guaranteeing that previously tested functionality continues to work as expected.
  4. Increased Test Coverage: Test automation enables teams to achieve higher test coverage by executing a large number of tests across different platforms, configurations, and data sets. Automated tests can cover a wider range of scenarios and edge cases, helping to identify potential issues that might go unnoticed in manual testing.
  5. Cost Savings: While there is an initial investment in setting up and maintaining test automation infrastructure, the long-term cost savings can be substantial. Automated tests can be executed repeatedly without incurring additional costs, unlike manual testing that requires dedicated resources. Moreover, by catching and fixing bugs earlier in the development cycle, test automation helps reduce the overall cost of software development.
  6. Team Collaboration: Test automation promotes collaboration and communication among team members. Automated tests serve as a shared resource that can be easily accessed and understood by team members, facilitating knowledge sharing and improving the overall testing process.

In summary, test automation offers several advantages, including improved efficiency, accuracy, regression testing, increased test coverage, cost savings, and enhanced team collaboration. By understanding the basics and importance of test automation, you are on track to harness its full potential in your software testing endeavors.

Setting up the Test Automation Environment

Setting up a robust test automation environment is crucial to ensure smooth and efficient test execution. This section will guide you through the essential steps and considerations for setting up your test automation environment.

Why Choosing the Right Tools is Crucial

Selecting the right tools for test automation is a critical decision that can greatly impact the success of your automation efforts. Here are a few factors to consider when choosing test automation tools:

  1. Compatibility: Ensure that the automation tools are compatible with the programming languages, frameworks, and technologies used in your software development process. Compatibility will ensure seamless integration and effective automation.
  2. Functionality: Evaluate the functionality offered by the automation tools. Look for features such as record and playback, object recognition, data-driven testing, and reporting capabilities. The tool should provide the necessary features to meet your specific testing requirements.
  3. Community Support: Consider the availability of online resources, documentation, and a supportive community for the chosen automation tools. A strong community support system can provide assistance, share best practices, and help overcome challenges during the automation process.
  4. Scalability: Assess the scalability of the automation tools to handle growing test suites and evolving software projects. The tool should be able to accommodate future expansion and increasing testing needs.

Essential Tools for Test Automation

To set up your test automation environment, you will need a combination of tools that cater to different aspects of the automation process. Here are the essential tools you should consider:

  1. Integrated Development Environment (IDE): An IDE is crucial for writing, editing, and debugging test scripts. Popular IDEs such as Eclipse, Visual Studio Code, or IntelliJ IDEA provide a user-friendly interface with features like code completion, debugging, and version control integration.
  2. Test Management Tool: A test management tool helps in organizing and managing test cases, test suites, and test data. It allows for easy test case creation, execution tracking, and reporting. Tools like TestRail, Zephyr, or TestLink can streamline your test management process.
  3. Automation Framework: An automation framework provides a structured approach to develop and execute automated tests. Frameworks like Selenium WebDriver, Appium, or Cypress provide libraries and utilities for interacting with web browsers, mobile devices, or desktop applications.
  4. Version Control System (VCS): A VCS allows teams to collaborate on test scripts, track changes, and manage different versions of the scripts. Git, SVN, or Mercurial are popular VCS options that provide versioning capabilities and facilitate team collaboration.
  5. Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) Tool: A CI/CD tool automates the build, test, and deployment process. Tools like Jenkins, Travis CI, or CircleCI can integrate with your test automation framework and trigger automated test runs upon code changes or scheduled intervals.

Setting up the Test Automation Framework

Once you have selected the necessary tools, the next step is to set up your test automation framework. Here are the key considerations:

  1. Choose a Programming Language: Select a programming language that is well-suited for your project and has good support within the automation community. Popular choices include Java, Python, C#, or JavaScript.
  2. Define the Test Automation Architecture: Determine the architecture of your automation framework, including the organization of test scripts, libraries, and configuration files. Consider adopting a modular or data-driven approach to enhance maintainability and reusability.
  3. Implement the Automation Infrastructure: Set up the necessary infrastructure for test automation, including the installation of required software, libraries, and dependencies. Ensure that the automation environment is properly configured and accessible to all team members.
  4. Establish Test Data Management: Define a strategy for managing test data, including creating and maintaining test data sets. Consider using tools or frameworks that can generate test data dynamically or integrate with databases or APIs for test data retrieval.
  5. Implement Test Reporting: Determine how test results will be captured and reported. Explore options like generating HTML reports, integrating with test management tools, or using dashboards for visual representation of test outcomes.

By carefully selecting the right tools and setting up a well-structured test automation framework, you can create an environment that supports efficient and effective test execution. This solid foundation will pave the way for successful test automation implementation.

Developing and Implementing Test Automation Scripts

Developing and implementing test automation scripts is a crucial step in achieving successful test automation. This section will guide you through the process of creating effective test scripts, from identifying tests to automate to running and managing the scripts.

Identifying Tests to Automate

Not all tests are suitable for automation. It is essential to identify the right tests to automate to maximize the benefits of test automation. Consider the following factors when selecting tests for automation:

  1. Repetitive Tests: Identify tests that need to be executed repeatedly, such as regression tests or smoke tests. Automating these repetitive tests saves time and effort, allowing testers to focus on more complex scenarios.
  2. High-Risk Tests: Tests that cover critical functionality or have a high risk of failure should be prioritized for automation. Automating such tests ensures consistent and thorough test coverage, reducing the chances of missing critical defects.
  3. Data-Driven Tests: Tests that involve multiple data sets or combinations are ideal candidates for automation. By parameterizing data, automated tests can be executed with different inputs, increasing test coverage and identifying potential issues.
  4. Time-Consuming Tests: Identify tests that require a significant amount of time to execute manually. Automating these time-consuming tests can drastically reduce the overall testing effort and enable faster feedback on software quality.

Writing Effective Test Scripts

Writing effective test scripts is essential for successful test automation. Follow these best practices to ensure your test scripts are reliable, maintainable, and reusable:

  1. Use a Structured Framework: Adopt a structured automation framework, such as the Page Object Model (POM) or the Screenplay Pattern, to organize your test scripts. These frameworks provide a clear separation of concerns, making scripts more maintainable and scalable.
  2. Create Clear and Descriptive Test Cases: Write test cases with clear and descriptive names that accurately reflect the test scenario. Each test case should have a specific objective and expected outcome.
  3. Keep Scripts Modular and Reusable: Break down test scripts into smaller, reusable components. This enables reusability across different test scenarios and reduces maintenance efforts when changes occur.
  4. Implement Proper Synchronization: Incorporate proper synchronization techniques in your test scripts to ensure that the application under test is in the desired state before performing actions or verifications. This helps avoid false positives or negatives due to timing issues.
  5. Implement Error Handling: Include error handling mechanisms in your test scripts to handle unexpected scenarios gracefully. This can involve capturing and logging errors, taking screenshots, or performing certain recovery actions.
  6. Use Assertions for Verification: Use assertions to verify expected outcomes during test execution. Assertions ensure that the application under test behaves as expected and provide confidence in the test results.

Running and Managing Test Scripts

Once your test scripts are developed, it is crucial to effectively run and manage them. Consider the following practices:

  1. Test Execution Configuration: Define the desired test execution configuration, including parameters such as browsers, devices, or operating systems. This allows for testing across different environments and ensures comprehensive coverage.
  2. Test Execution Orchestration: Utilize test execution frameworks or CI/CD tools to orchestrate the execution of test scripts. This enables automation runs to be triggered automatically upon code changes or scheduled intervals.
  3. Test Result Analysis: Analyze test results to identify failures or issues. Log failures with detailed information for easy debugging and resolution. Investigate failed tests promptly to determine whether the failure is due to a defect or a test script issue.
  4. Test Script Maintenance: Regularly review and update test scripts as the application under test evolves. Maintain synchronization between test scripts and application changes to ensure scripts remain valid and effective.

By following these best practices for developing and implementing test automation scripts, you can ensure that your automated tests are reliable, maintainable, and provide accurate feedback on software quality.

Maintaining and Enhancing the Test Automation Suite

Maintaining and enhancing the test automation suite is crucial for long-term success in test automation. This section will guide you through the essential steps to keep your test automation suite up-to-date, reliable, and effective.

Regularly Review and Update Test Scripts

Regularly reviewing and updating test scripts is essential to ensure their relevance and accuracy. Follow these practices for maintaining your test scripts:

  1. Test Script Review: Conduct periodic reviews of your test scripts to identify any outdated or redundant scripts. Review the test cases for accuracy, completeness, and alignment with the current application functionality.
  2. Eliminate Redundancy: Identify and eliminate redundant test scripts to avoid duplication of effort. Consolidate similar test cases into reusable components or scenarios.
  3. Update for Application Changes: As the application under test evolves, update your test scripts accordingly. Incorporate changes in UI elements, workflows, or functionalities to keep the scripts aligned with the current application state.
  4. Version Control: Utilize version control systems to track changes made to test scripts. This allows for easy rollback to previous versions if needed and provides a history of script modifications.

Incorporating New Tests as Product Evolves

As new features or functionalities are added to the software product, it is essential to incorporate new tests into your automation suite. Consider the following steps:

  1. Requirements Analysis: Analyze new requirements and understand the scope and impact on your automation suite. Identify the necessary test scenarios and determine whether new test cases need to be created or existing ones need to be modified.
  2. Test Case Design: Design new test cases to cover the new features or functionalities. Ensure that the test cases are comprehensive and cover different scenarios and edge cases.
  3. Script Development: Develop new test scripts based on the designed test cases. Leverage existing automation frameworks and reusable components to expedite script development.
  4. Integration with Test Management: Integrate the new test cases and scripts into your test management system. Update test suites, test plans, and test schedules to include the newly added tests.

Dealing with Test Failures and Flaky Tests

Test failures and flaky tests can undermine the reliability and effectiveness of your test automation suite. Employ the following strategies to address these issues:

  1. Root Cause Analysis: Perform root cause analysis to identify the underlying reasons for test failures. Investigate whether the failure is due to a genuine application defect or a test script issue. Address the root cause to prevent recurring failures.
  2. Logging and Debugging: Implement robust logging and debugging mechanisms in your test scripts. Capture relevant information, such as error messages, screenshots, or console logs, to aid in troubleshooting test failures.
  3. Test Environment Stability: Ensure the stability and consistency of the test environment. Unstable or inconsistent environments can lead to flaky tests. Maintain the test environment by regularly updating dependencies and configurations.
  4. Rerun and Retry Mechanisms: Implement rerun and retry mechanisms to handle intermittent failures caused by environmental factors or network issues. Retry failed tests a few times before considering them as genuine failures.

By regularly reviewing and updating test scripts, incorporating new tests as the product evolves, and addressing test failures and flaky tests, you can maintain and enhance the effectiveness of your test automation suite. This ensures that your automation efforts continue to provide accurate and reliable results throughout the software development lifecycle.

Measuring the Success of Test Automation

Measuring the success of test automation is essential to understand its impact and effectiveness within your organization. This section will guide you through the process of defining success metrics, evaluating test coverage, and understanding the return on investment (ROI) of your test automation efforts.

Defining Success Metrics for Test Automation

To measure the success of test automation, it is crucial to define relevant metrics that align with your testing goals and objectives. Consider the following metrics:

  1. Test Coverage: Measure the percentage of test coverage achieved through automation compared to manual testing. This metric indicates the extent to which your automated tests cover different functionalities and scenarios.
  2. Test Execution Time: Measure the time saved in executing automated tests compared to manual testing. This metric demonstrates the efficiency gained through automation and allows for faster feedback on software quality.
  3. Defect Detection: Measure the number of defects detected by automated tests compared to manual testing. This metric indicates the effectiveness of your automated tests in identifying software defects.
  4. Test Maintenance Effort: Measure the effort required to maintain and update test scripts. This metric helps assess the maintainability and sustainability of your test automation suite.

Evaluating Test Coverage

Evaluating test coverage is crucial to ensure that your automated tests adequately cover critical functionality and scenarios. Consider the following approaches to evaluate test coverage:

  1. Requirement Traceability: Map your automated tests to the corresponding requirements or user stories. This provides visibility into the coverage of different functional areas and ensures that all requirements are addressed through automation.
  2. Code Coverage Analysis: Utilize code coverage tools to measure the percentage of code covered by your automated tests. This helps identify areas of the code that are not adequately tested, allowing you to enhance test coverage in those areas.
  3. Risk-Based Testing: Prioritize test automation efforts based on the level of risk associated with different functionalities or scenarios. Focus on automating tests that cover high-risk areas to ensure comprehensive coverage.

Understanding the ROI of Test Automation

Understanding the return on investment (ROI) of test automation is crucial for decision-making and justifying the investment in automation efforts. Consider the following factors when evaluating the ROI:

  1. Time and Cost Savings: Measure the time and cost savings achieved through automation compared to manual testing. Consider factors such as reduced testing effort, faster feedback on software quality, and decreased time-to-market.
  2. Improved Testing Efficiency: Evaluate the increase in testing efficiency achieved through automation, such as the ability to execute tests in parallel, perform regression testing quickly, and handle larger test suites.
  3. Reduced Defect Leakage: Measure the reduction in defect leakage to production by identifying defects early in the development cycle through automated tests. This reduces the cost and effort associated with fixing defects in later stages.
  4. Resource Optimization: Assess the optimization of testing resources through automation. Determine the impact on resource allocation, such as testers being able to focus on more complex testing activities rather than repetitive manual tests.

By defining success metrics, evaluating test coverage, and understanding the ROI of test automation, you can effectively measure and communicate the impact and value of your test automation efforts. This will facilitate informed decision-making and enable continuous improvement in your testing processes.

‚Äç
Post Summary: In this guide, we will delve into the world of test automation, covering everything from the basics and importance of test automation to setting up...

Name: Mastering the Art of Automating UI Testing
Post Body:
In the ever-evolving realm of software development, delivering applications with flawless user interfaces (UIs) is crucial for success. UI testing, the process of evaluating the functionality and usability of an application's graphical interface, is essential for ensuring a positive user experience. However, manual UI testing can be time-consuming, repetitive, and prone to human error. This is where automating UI testing emerges as a game-changer. This blog post will explore the benefits, challenges, and best practices associated with automating UI testing, providing insights into how to streamline your testing processes and enhance the quality of your applications.

Why Automate UI Testing?

Automating UI testing brings a myriad of advantages:

  • Increased Efficiency and Speed: Automated tests can execute tasks much faster than human testers, allowing for quicker feedback cycles and accelerated development processes.
  • Improved Accuracy and Consistency:  Automated tests eliminate the variability inherent in manual testing, ensuring consistent and reliable results regardless of the tester's fatigue or experience.
  • Enhanced Test Coverage:  Automated tests can cover a broader range of test cases, including edge cases and scenarios that are difficult or impractical to test manually, leading to more comprehensive testing.
  • Reduced Costs:  While the initial setup of automated testing may involve some investment, the long-term cost savings due to increased efficiency and reduced manual effort are substantial.
  • Facilitates Continuous Integration and Delivery: Automated UI tests can be seamlessly integrated into CI/CD pipelines, allowing for continuous testing and delivery of software updates with confidence.

Navigating the Challenges of Automating UI Testing

Despite its benefits, automating UI testing comes with challenges:

  • Test Maintenance: Changes in the application's UI can break automated tests, requiring updates to the test scripts.
  • Test Fragility:  UI tests can be sensitive to changes in the environment, such as browser updates or operating system versions, leading to false positives or test failures. Careful test design and the use of robust testing frameworks can help address this.
  • Handling Dynamic Content: Web applications often contain dynamic elements that change frequently, making it challenging to create reliable automated tests. Techniques like waiting mechanisms and intelligent element locators can help overcome this.
  • Finding the Right Tool:  A plethora of UI testing tools are available, each with its strengths and weaknesses. Choosing the right tool that aligns with your testing needs, technical expertise, and budget is crucial.

Best Practices for Effective Automated UI Testing

To maximize the benefits of automating UI testing, follow these best practices:

  • Choose the Right Tool: Consider factors like ease of use, platform/browser support, reporting capabilities, and integration with your development environment.
  • Prioritize Test Cases: Focus on automating tests for critical functionalities, frequently used features, and scenarios prone to manual errors.
  • Create Modular and Reusable Tests: Design tests that can be easily modified and reused, reducing the effort required for test maintenance.
  • Use Clear and Descriptive Naming Conventions: This improves test readability and maintainability.
  • Leverage Data-Driven Testing:  Run the same test with different input data sets to cover a wider range of scenarios.
  • Incorporate Visual Validation: Use tools or techniques to verify the visual appearance of the UI, ensuring elements are displayed correctly and the layout is consistent.
  • Integrate with CI/CD: Automate the execution of UI tests as part of your CI/CD pipeline to provide continuous feedback on the quality of your application.

Tools for Automating UI Testing

Several tools are available to facilitate automating UI testing:

  • Selenium:  A widely used open-source framework for web application testing, offering a comprehensive set of tools for automating browser interactions.
  • Cypress: A modern JavaScript-based testing framework known for its speed, ease of use, and developer-friendly features.
  • Playwright: A cross-browser automation library developed by Microsoft, supporting multiple languages and offering features like auto-waiting and network interception.
  • AskUI: A vision based tool that works cross-platform because it automates the operating system inputs a real human user would do.

Conclusion

Automating UI testing is an integral part of modern software development practices. By embracing automation, organizations can enhance the efficiency, accuracy, and coverage of their testing efforts, resulting in higher-quality applications and improved user experiences. While challenges exist, following best practices and selecting the right tools can help organizations overcome these hurdles and reap the full benefits of automating UI testing.
Post Summary: In the ever-evolving realm of software development, delivering applications with flawless user interfaces (UIs) is crucial for success.

Author: Ron Junior van Cann

Name: Navigating the Evolving World of UI Testing Tools
Post Body:
The landscape of test automation is quite the dynamic playground these days. If you've been dabbling with UI testing tools‚Äîor any kind of test automation, for that matter‚Äîyou might agree that it's both an exhilarating ride and a bit of a head-scratcher. Grab a comfy chair and some popcorn as we explore this world where software developers, testers, and even AI are teaming up to make sure your app doesn't throw a tantrum.

The Role of UI Testing Tools

First off, UI testing tools are indispensable in today's test automation scene. They're like that trusty Swiss Army knife that every tech enthusiast wants in their toolkit. These tools can handle various automation tasks‚Äîthink of them as the backstage crew ensuring everything runs smoothly while the developers (a.k.a. the cast) take center stage.

The Good News: More Players at the Table

In recent years, the software development community has become increasingly aware of the value of test automation. Software developers are not only embracing these frameworks; many are actively contributing to them. It's like a neighborhood potluck where everyone brings their favorite dish, making the feast that much richer. Similarly, testers are sharpening their programming skills, adding another layer of awesome to the mix.

The Framework Future

While some may predict the extinction of traditional testing frameworks due to these developments, the reality is a tad different. Testing frameworks aren't going anywhere‚Äîthey've still got a lot of life in them. Much like a fine wine, they get better with age and are here to stay, serving as the foundation upon which new technologies and methodologies continue to be built.

Enter AI: The New Kid on the Block

Artificial Intelligence‚Äîa term tossed around quite a bit (buzzword alert!)‚Äîis creeping into the test automation domain. And no, it's not planning to take over your job, or the world, even if some sci-fi movies had you thinking otherwise.

AI in Action:  

- Element Localization: AI can help with locating elements more efficiently during testing, which is kind of like digital hide-and-seek where AI always knows where to look.

- Test Prioritization: Prioritize tests like a pro, ensuring critical tests get executed without sifting through piles of code manually.

- Automatic Test Case Creation: Let AI do the heavy lifting by generating tests‚Äîit's like having a brainstorming buddy who never tires.

- Monkey Testing: AI's got you covered in this arena too, randomly testing the system, trying to break things so you don't have to.

- Report Analysis: Wave goodbye to the tedious task of sifting through logs thanks to AI‚Äôs knack for digesting data and providing insights.

Yet, despite its promise, AI still has something to prove; perhaps it's like that new smartphone we're all excited about, but we're still clutching onto our trusty old devices for dear life.

In Conclusion

The world of UI testing tools and test automation is evolving fast. While software developers and testers are upping their game to integrate these tools seamlessly, the emergence of AI brings new opportunities‚Äîand some challenges, too. However, like a good suspense movie, staying tuned is half the fun!

In the end, it's all about finding balance and discovering what works best for your testing environment. Whether it's through frameworks, AI, or a collaboration of both, the future holds exciting possibilities for those willing to adapt and experiment. So, let's roll up our sleeves and keep exploring this thrilling evolution of test automation together!
Post Summary: The landscape of test automation is quite the dynamic playground these days. If you've been dabbling with UI testing tools...

Name: Neurosymbolic AI: Integrating Logic and Learning
Post Body:
Symbolic AI, rooted in early AI research, aims to mimic human intelligence by creating systems that manipulate symbols based on logical rules. These symbols are used to represent objects, concepts, and relationships in the world, allowing the system to deductively reason as a human might when solving logic puzzles. An illustrative instance is a symbolic AI system understanding the sentence "The ball is red," by deconstructing it into symbols like "ball," "red," and "is" to deduce that the ball possesses the attribute of redness.

The Limitations of Symbolic AI

Despite its effectiveness in specific domains, symbolic AI struggles with real-world complexity due to its dependence on explicit rules and handcrafted knowledge, making it brittle and inflexible. Identifying a cat in an image exemplifies this limitation‚Äî a purely symbolic AI system might rely on rigid rules such as "has fur," "has four legs," "has tail," which fall short in real-world scenarios where a cat may be partially obscured, viewed from different angles, or vary in lighting conditions.

The Emergence of Neurosymbolic AI

Neurosymbolic AI aims to bridge these gaps by merging deep learning's strengths with the reasoning abilities of symbolic AI. While deep learning excels at identifying patterns from vast data‚Äîkey for tasks like image recognition and natural language processing‚Äîneurosymbolic AI combines this with the symbolic AI's logical reasoning. In the cat identification example, a neurosymbolic AI system can use a deep learning model trained on extensive image data to identify the cat regardless of variations in pose, lighting, or occlusion. This model serves as a perceptive engine, converting sensory data into symbolic forms that the symbolic AI component can manipulate.

Benefits of Neurosymbolic AI

This integration allows neurosymbolic AI to move beyond traditional symbolic AI with several advantages:

1. Learning from Data: Neurosymbolic systems can learn directly from data using deep learning, enabling them to adapt to new situations and manage real-world uncertainty and ambiguity.

2. Common Sense Reasoning: By providing a framework for relationships between objects and concepts, symbolic AI equips neural networks with a common sense reasoning capability. This allows for complex inference, question answering, and problem-solving beyond pattern recognition.

3. Explainable Decisions: The transparency of symbolic AI's explicit rules and logic aids neurosymbolic AI systems in explaining their decision-making processes, crucial for building trust and understanding in AI applications.

Applications and Future Potential

Despite being a nascent field, neurosymbolic AI has demonstrated promise. Researchers have crafted systems capable of:

- Tracking objects even when hidden, showing an understanding of object permanence.

- Answering questions about images using combined neural networks, symbolic AI, and probabilistic reasoning.

- Translating natural language into logical forms to reason over knowledge bases and answer complex questions.

Conclusion

By integrating deep learning and symbolic reasoning, neurosymbolic AI is poised to advance intelligent agent AI, creating systems that learn, reason, and interact more like humans. Its potential to develop more sophisticated, adaptable, and explainable AI could revolutionize how intelligent systems benefit society, fostering increased trust and effectiveness.
Post Summary: Neurosymbolic AI aims to bridge these gaps by merging deep learning's strengths with the reasoning abilities of symbolic AI.

Name: Neurosymbolic AI: What is it?
Post Body:
Neurosymbolic AI is an emerging field that strives to bridge the gap between two powerful forms of artificial intelligence: deep learning and symbolic AI. The goal is to create intelligent agent AI that can learn, reason, and solve problems more like humans do.

Deep Learning

Deep learning, inspired by the structure of the human brain, has excelled in tasks like image recognition and language translation. Neural networks, the workhorse of deep learning, process vast amounts of data to identify patterns and make predictions. However, these systems struggle to explain their decisions, generalize to new situations, and lack the common sense reasoning that comes naturally to humans.

Symbolic AI

Symbolic AI, on the other hand, focuses on representing knowledge through symbols and rules. This approach excels at logical reasoning and providing clear explanations. However, symbolic AI systems often require extensive hand-crafted knowledge and can struggle to handle the complexities and uncertainties of the real world.

Neurosymbolic AI

Neurosymbolic AI seeks to combine the strengths of both approaches. Neural networks can be used to extract symbolic representations from data, such as identifying objects in images and translating pixels into symbolic form. Symbolic AI algorithms, in turn, can provide neural networks with common sense reasoning and domain knowledge, allowing them to describe relationships between objects, make predictions, and answer complex questions.

One promising avenue of research in neurosymbolic AI is to model AI systems after the way babies learn. Infants develop an understanding of the world through active exploration and interaction, gradually building a "common sense" model of physics and causality. By incorporating insights from developmental psychology and cognitive neuroscience, researchers hope to create AI systems that learn and reason more like children, requiring less data and exhibiting greater flexibility and adaptability.

Early Experiments

Early experiments in neurosymbolic AI have yielded encouraging results. For instance, researchers have developed algorithms that can track objects even when they are hidden, demonstrating a rudimentary understanding of object permanence, a concept mastered by infants early in development. Other research focuses on bridging the gap between vision and language, allowing AI systems to answer questions about images by combining neural networks with symbolic AI and probabilistic reasoning.

Natural language processing

Natural language processing is another key area where neurosymbolic AI holds promise. Researchers are developing techniques to translate natural language sentences into logical forms, enabling AI systems to leverage existing knowledge bases and perform more sophisticated reasoning tasks. This could lead to AI assistants that can understand and respond to complex requests, going beyond simple commands and engaging in more meaningful conversations.

Conclusion

The development of neurosymbolic AI is still in its early stages, but researchers believe it holds the key to unlocking the next generation of intelligent systems. By combining the strengths of deep learning and symbolic AI, neurosymbolic AI aims to create AI that is not only powerful but also explainable, adaptable, and capable of true common sense reasoning. These advances have the potential to revolutionize fields such as customer support, business intelligence, healthcare, and scientific discovery.
Post Summary: Neurosymbolic AI is an emerging field that strives to bridge the gap between two powerful forms of artificial intelligence: deep learning and symbolic

Name: New Features and Update News in AskUI
Post Body:
::: callout üì¢

We are excited to share the latest updates for AskUI Studio and the askui npm package! These updates include new features, bug fixes, and enhancements to make your AskUI experience even more convenient. Here is an overview of the recent updates:

  • Instruction Completion (AskUI Studio) - We have updated features in AskUI Studio that leads to instruction completion. This feature will help streamline your workflow and improve your productivity. For more details, check out the description below.
  • Interactive CLI - We have introduced an Interactive CLI in the askui npm package. As of version 0.13.0, you can use the seamless and intuitive command-line interface to simplify the setup process for your askui project. To learn more about the improvements, check out the description below or just try it out now!
  • annotate() function for comprehensive debugging - To enhance the debugging capabilities of askui, we have introduced a new feature to the annotate() function. This feature allows you to highlight single elements for more comprehensive debugging. You can find more information below.
  • Adjustable similarity filtering for text elements - We have added a new feature that allows you to adjust the similarity filtering for text elements. This enhancement provides more flexibility in filtering and improves the accuracy of text-based operations. Keep reading for more information.
  • Enhanced matching() filter for textual descriptions - With the latest version (0.13.1) of askui, we have enhanced our matching() filter. This filter allows you to filter elements based on textual descriptions, enhancing the search and filtering capabilities.
  • Reporter (Integrations Platform) - We have introduced a new feature to the reporting system of askui. Aiming to provide more flexibility mainly for enterprise applications, it provides an enhanced adaptability and usability.

‚Äç

AskUI Studio

1. Instruction Completion

First things first. We have improved the auto suggestion for the available commands. Now, as you type in the instruction input field, you will see the next available commands suggested in a list.

And after you finish an instruction, the instruction will labeled as complete, so that you know that the written instruction is valid.

‚Äç

2. Direct Argument Input

You can now input arguments directly after choosing a command. This will help you to have a more fluent and rapid workflow within AskUI Studio.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

3. Full API Access

The entire API, including frequently requested features like waitFor() is now accessible in AskUI Studio.

‚Äç

‚Äç

AskUI npm package

1. Interactive CLI

The Interactive Command Line Interface feature simplifies the setup process for the askui project, making it easier and more accessible.

‚Äç

Here is a quick how to use:

  1. Enter npx askui@latest init into the terminal and press enter.
  2. Answer the series of prompted questions:
  3. Preferred framework (e.g., Jest)
  4. Workspace ID
  5. Access token
  6. Proxy usage
  7. Option to add/overwrite tsconfig.json file
  8. The CLI will then automatically:
  9. Detect the operating system
  10. Copy project files
  11. Install askui dependency
  12. Set up the test framework
  13. Copy ESLint config files
  14. Add user credentials
  15. Write askui config
  16. Note: Proxy installation is a manual process, despite log indications.

AskUI npm package is available for free, so you can check it out now!

‚Äç

2. annotate() Can Highlight Single Element

This update introduces an optional AnnotationRequest parameter to the annotate**()** method, allowing you to annotate specific elements retrieved from the user interface by the get() method.

Here is a quick how to use:

  1. Use the get() method to retrieve elements.
  2. Pass the AnnotationRequest parameter to specify which elements to annotate.
  3. Execute the annotation command as shown in the provided example.

‚Äç

-- CODE language-ts line-numbers -- const detectedElements = await aui.get().text().withText("User Interfaces?").exec();await aui.annotate({ elements: detectedElements });

‚Äç

Link to our official API documentation

‚Äç

‚Äç

3. Adjustable Similarity Filtering for Text Element

The update introduces an optional similarity_score parameter for the .withText() method, allowing users to define a custom similarity threshold for text matching, enhancing precision and control in text-based searches. We use rapidfuzz to calculate the similarity of the texts.

Here is a quick example of how to use:

-- CODE language-ts line-numbers -- await aui .text() ¬†.withText("978-0-201-00", 90) // Requires at least 90% similarity ¬†.exec();

‚Äç

4. Enhanced matching() Function for Textual Description

The 'Matching' feature introduces a method to filter and interact with user interface elements based on a description in natural language.

Here is a quick example of the matching() function:

await aui.click().matching('a mask on purple background and a firefox logo').exec();

Link to our official API documentation

  • The matching() function recognizes color, famous company/product names, and general visual characteristics of elements.
  • The description should be as detailed as possible, including color, notable logos, and general appearance.
  • The feature's ability to accurately identify elements is highly dependent on the specificity and accuracy of the textual description.
  • There may be inconsistencies in recognizing less distinct or unique elements.
  • As an experimental feature, it may not always work as expected and could require multiple attempts to find the right description.

‚Äç

5. Report Integrations Platform

With the latest version of askui package, you can now integrate the test result report of askui into your existing workflows. This platform significantly streamlines the process of integrating askui with various reporting tools. In case you are working for an enterprise application, this feature will allow you to seamlessly incorporate automation results into your existing workflows. It offers a more personalized and efficient reporting experience, tailored to the specific needs of each enterprise environment.

Check out this Github repo for more detail:

  • https://github.com/askui/askui-reporters

‚Äç
Post Summary: We are excited to share the latest updates for AskUI Studio and the askui npm package! These updates include new features, bug fixes, and enhancem....

Name: No-Code Visual Testing: Automating Visual Regression Testing with Caesr.ai
Post Body:
The previous approach using the TypeScript SDK and external libraries like Jest and jest-image-snapshot is no longer the primary method within AskUI it is now Legacy. Modern Visual Regression Testing VRT via AskUI is now handled by the Caesr.AI's Vision Agent. We haven't abandoned VRT we've upgraded it to be smarter and simpler. Stop coding your visual comparisons start giving instructions to Caesr.ai in natural language.

What is Visual Regression Testing VRT

Visual Regression Testing VRT is the crucial process of ensuring that recent code changes haven't accidentally broken the visual appearance of your application. It confirms that buttons layouts and text appear exactly as intended for the end-user across every release.

The Old Problem Complex Toolchain Management

In the legacy setup implementing VRT meant manually integrating multiple components and writing custom code to handle image buffers and external Jest matchers. This introduced significant maintenance overhead and steepened the learning curve. The process was also prone to generating many false positives flagging irrelevant pixel shifts.

The New Solution VRT as a Single Chat Command Powered by Caesr.ai

Caesr.ai transforms VRT by integrating the entire visual testing pipeline into its AI Agent. The Agent handles screenshot capture baseline management image comparison using its advanced AI Vision and reporting all based on simple natural language.

The power of Caesr.ai's AI Vision lies in its ability to understand the context and structure of the UI not just raw pixels. This approach significantly reduces false positives by focusing on user-critical visual changes that actually impact the user experience.

Caesr.ai Prompt Example VRT Request

For other complex automation examples powered by a single prompt, explore:
  • Caesr: Analyze TikTok Viral Trends
  • One Prompt: Full Website QA
Conclusion
The shift to Caesr.AI fundamentally transforms Visual Regression Testing. You move from being a Toolchain Maintainer to a Test Strategist. Stop debugging environment issues image buffer errors and external library compatibility. Caesr.ai handles the complexity with AI Vision delivering robust self-maintaining VRT and freeing your team to focus on faster feature delivery.
Post Summary: Stop coding visual tests. AskUI shifts VRT from legacy Jest/TypeScript to Caesr.ai Chat. Use AI Vision and natural language to eliminate complex setup

Name: Open Source Automation Testing Tools for Web Applications
Post Body:
Open source automation testing tools for web applications are essential for developing and maintaining quality software in today's fast-paced digital world. Here, we will explore several notable tools that have carved out a niche in the field of automation testing.

SikuliX

SikuliX is a Java-based open-source tool that utilizes image recognition to automate tasks visible on the screen. Suitable for use across Windows, macOS, and various Linux/Unix systems, SikuliX allows you to create scripts and perform programming actions based on graphical elements.

Selenium

Selenium is a widely recognized open-source project that specializes in browser automation, facilitating the testing of web applications. It is developed in collaboration with browser vendors and the W3C to standardize its API for universal browser testing.

Robot Framework

Known for its versatility, Robot Framework is an open-source automation framework that supports both test automation and robotic process automation (RPA). It's powered by a large community and facilitated by the Robot Framework Foundation. The framework operates using keyword-driven testing and can be extended with additional libraries in languages like Python and Java.

Appium

Appium is an open-source platform aimed at UI automation across different app environments. Its ability to integrate user-generated drivers makes it a flexible solution for comprehensive application testing.

Katalon Studio

Though primarily a free, open-source tool, Katalon Studio also offers commercial enhancements for broader testing capabilities and scalability. These enhancements provide additional features not available in the open-source version, offering flexible deployment options both on-premises and in the cloud.

Playwright

Playwright is designed for end-to-end web application testing and is completely open-source. Some companies develop commercial products on top of its robust codebase, which includes AI-driven test generation and maintenance, adding a layer of efficiency and intelligence to testing processes.

AskUI

With the integration of AI vision, AskUI advances the field of UI automation by overcoming traditional, selector-based tool restrictions. Its adaptability makes it an attractive option for enterprises aiming to implement scalable, secure automation across various platforms.

Conclusion

Open source automation testing tools for web applications, like these, provide unmatched flexibility and innovation for software testing and development, catering to both individual developers and large organizations alike. Whether you‚Äôre testing a simple web application or building a complex enterprise solution, these tools offer a range of capabilities to meet diverse automation needs.

Post Summary: Here, we will explore several notable tools that have carved out a niche in the field of automation testing.

Name: Orchestrator Agents Enhancing AI Vision Agents
Post Body:
In recent years, artificial intelligence (AI) has made significant headway in various domains, notably in the visual processing domain. The orchestrator agent offers a strategic enhancement in how these systems operate. Essentially, the orchestrator agent serves as a sophisticated managerial layer that coordinates various vision AI agents, enabling a seamless transition between user intent and technical execution in visual tasks.

Central Role of the Orchestrator Agent

The orchestrator agent functions as a pivotal component within AI vision systems, acting not as a direct executor, but rather as a facilitator and manager. Its principal role is to interpret users' natural language queries and assign appropriate tasks to specialized AI vision agents. These tasks are then executed by these individual agents or other integrated tools, with the orchestrator agent synthesizing the outputs into a cohesive response.

By doing so, the orchestrator agent operates as a central control unit, crucially deciding on the selection and combination of AI tools and how best to present results to users. It essentially transforms disparate AI vision functions into a sophisticated and intelligent system, offering a user-friendly interface and enhanced interaction.

Enhancing Capabilities with an Orchestrator Agent

The implementation of an orchestrator agent in AI vision systems brings several notable enhancements:

1. Enhanced Communication and Understanding

The orchestrator agent improves communication between the system and its users by interpreting complex user requests into actionable tasks. Unlike conventional AI systems that might struggle with nuanced inquiries, the orchestrator agent can handle more intricate interactions. For instance, when a user wants to "track the player with the most movement," the orchestrator agent doesn't just execute blindly; it seeks clarification and explains its methodology. This results in a more transparent and intuitive user experience, bridging the gap between human language and machine execution effectively.

2. Expanded Functionality and Task Complexity

The coordination of multiple AI vision agents by the orchestrator agent vastly expands the system's functional scope. It enables the handling of more complex, multi-step tasks through its ability to delegate responsibilities among various specialized agents. For example, managing a sports video analysis that requires detection, tracking, and performance metrics evaluation can be efficiently orchestrated. This layered approach allows systems to approach real-world tasks with a sequence of comprehensive visual operations that a lone agent would struggle to manage effectively.

3. Improved Adaptability and Flexibility

Adaptability is critical in the fast-evolving landscape of artificial intelligence. The orchestrator agent's design allows it to integrate new tools and methodologies swiftly, ensuring that the system remains at the forefront of AI advancements. As new technologies or AI models emerge‚Äîlike an improved object tracking system‚Äîthe orchestrator agent can incorporate these advancements without disrupting the existing architecture. This adaptability not only enhances the system's current capabilities but also future-proofs it against technological obsolescence.

4. Elevated User Experience

An orchestrator agent significantly improves the user experience by managing interactions, offering feedback, and presenting results in an easily digestible format. Rather than burdening users with raw data or technical jargon, the orchestrator agent can generate visual summaries or interactive dashboards tailored to specific user requirements. This focus on user-centric design allows individuals to concentrate on their objectives without becoming encumbered by the complexities of vision AI processing.

Conclusion

The orchestrator agent orchestrates a finely-tuned interaction between multiple vision AI agents, enhancing the overall capabilities and offering an elevated user experience. By seamlessly integrating new technologies and executing complex tasks efficiently, the orchestrator agent ensures that vision AI systems remain current, adaptable, and user-friendly. As AI continues to evolve, the orchestrator agent holds the promise of making these systems increasingly sophisticated and accessible to broader audiences. Through enhanced communication, expanded functionalities, improved adaptability, and an elevated user experience, the orchestrator agent is transforming the way vision AI systems operate, offering sophisticated solutions for tackling real-world visual challenges.
Post Summary: Essentially, the orchestrator agent serves as a sophisticated managerial layer that coordinates various vision AI agents.

Name: Overcoming the Challenges of Automating .NET Canvas Applications
Post Body:
Automation is essential for delivering high quality applications quickly and consistently. But what happens when you're dealing with applications that render their UI on a canvas like many .NET desktop apps? Automating these is a whole different story.

Unlike standard web or desktop elements that are easy to identify using the DOM or UI trees, canvas-based UIs are drawn pixel by pixel. This makes them incredibly flexible but also incredibly difficult to automate. In this post, we‚Äôll break down why .NET canvas applications are so challenging to automate, what current tools offer, and how innovative solutions like AskUI are changing the game.

üëâ Discover how AskUI helped Zucchetti‚Äîand how it can help you

‚Äç

Why Are .NET Canvas Applications Hard to Automate?

Canvas elements render visuals dynamically, often outside traditional UI hierarchies. That means no buttons, no checkboxes, no text fields for your test automation tools to hook into. Here are the core challenges:

  • No DOM or UI Tree Access: Since canvas elements are just pixels on a screen, automation tools can‚Äôt locate elements by ID, class, or XPath.
  • Pixel Dependency: Interaction relies on screen coordinates, which can change based on resolution, scaling, and device setup.
  • Inconsistent Rendering: Different systems might render the same canvas content slightly differently, leading to flaky tests.
  • Complex User Interactions: Dragging, drawing, zooming, and gestures are difficult to simulate reliably.
  • Dynamic & Animated Content: Real-time updates make it hard to define fixed checkpoints or wait conditions.

The Limitations of Traditional Automation Tools

Standard test automation tools aren‚Äôt built for canvas. Selenium is great for web apps, but it can‚Äôt interact with canvas content directly. FlaUI supports .NET desktop apps better, but still struggles with canvas elements and often needs custom code. Winium is outdated and lacks support for modern UI needs. Appium is ideal for mobile testing, but not for desktop apps using canvas.

Because of these gaps, some teams try visual testing tools like Percy or Resemble.js, which compare screenshots to highlight changes. However, these tools don‚Äôt interact with the UI itself they just show visual differences, which isn‚Äôt enough for thorough automation.

Common Pitfalls in Canvas UI Automation

  1. Flaky Tests: Hardcoded coordinates break easily with minor UI shifts.
  2. Poor Debugging: Without UI references, it‚Äôs hard to pinpoint why a test failed.
  3. Accessibility Testing Gaps: Traditional tools can‚Äôt verify if canvas UIs meet accessibility standards.
  4. Performance Issues: High-resolution canvases or animations can slow down test execution.

Best Practices for .NET Canvas Automation

Despite these challenges, teams can still build reliable canvas automation by adopting smart practices:

  • Fix the Environment: Lock in screen resolution, DPI, and window size to reduce variability.
  • Use Visual Validation: Screenshot-based tools can detect layout and rendering changes.
  • Script Thoughtfully: Prefer logic via exposed APIs or in-app functions when available.
  • Add Smart Waits: Use polling, timeouts, and condition checks to handle dynamic content.
  • Monitor Closely: Integrate logging and visual reports to catch and fix issues fast.

The Better Way: AskUI + Computer Vision

Most automation tools weren‚Äôt built with canvas in mind but AskUI is different. It uses AI and computer vision to analyze your app visually, just like a human would. That means AskUI doesn‚Äôt rely on DOM trees or UI selectors. Instead, it ‚Äúsees‚Äù the canvas, interprets its content, and interacts with it intelligently.

This is especially useful for:

  • Interactive UIs with custom gestures or drawings
  • Real-time dashboards and animated charts
  • Games and simulation tools
  • Any .NET app that heavily uses canvas-based rendering

‚û°Ô∏è See it in action with Zucchetti‚Äôs success story

Zucchetti, a global enterprise software provider, faced all the classic canvas automation headaches. By switching to AskUI, they moved from slow, manual testing to fast, scalable automation without sacrificing accuracy.

Their story is a must-read for any QA or DevOps team tackling similar challenges.

Final Thoughts

.NET canvas applications don‚Äôt have to be a test automation nightmare. With the right mix of practices and the right technology especially tools built for visual and dynamic UIs you can overcome the obstacles and build stable, scalable test pipelines.

If you‚Äôre ready to stop struggling with fragile scripts and start automating canvas apps confidently:

üëâ Discover how AskUI helped Zucchetti‚Äîand how it can help you
Post Summary: Automating .NET canvas apps is tough‚Äîbut AI-driven tools like AskUI make it simple. See how Zucchetti solved it.

Name: Parallel Execution of AskUI Workflows with Jest
Post Body:
Have you ever needed to run your AskUI Workflows in parallel on multiple devices to speed up the execution?

That is possible with a little bit of configuration in Jest, the runner used to execute AskUI Workflows, and multiple AskUI Controllers.

This blog will walk you through the setup for two Android devices and running a bunch of workflows.

Prerequisites

  • AskUI installed and configured on your system (Windows, Linux, macOS)
  • GitHub repository to follow along

Start AskUI Controllers

‚ö†Ô∏è The commands shown below start the AskUI Controller on your local machine as we are controlling two Android devices. If you want to run your workflows on a remote machine, install and start the controllers there. Do not forget to get the IP of the remote machine for the URL to the controller!

Windows‚Äç

Jest
Next comes Jest, the javascript framework AskUI uses to run its workflows.
.env For Configuration Environment Variables
First, we want to have a way to configure how many parallel processes are running workflows. For this, we install the dotenv package like this:
Then we create a file .env in the root of the project and fill it with the following. We set the JEST_MAX_WORKER to two as we have two Android devices:
Configure Maximum Parallel Workers in jest.config.ts
We need the max workers feature from Jest which allows us to specify the number of workers that should run in parallel. It can be configured in the file jest.config.ts. We use the environment variable JEST_MAX_WORKER from the .env file.
Connect AskUI Controllers in askui-helper.ts
In the askui-helper.ts we hold an array of all AskUI Controller URLs we want to target. We take the configured maxWorkers and the workerId to connect each worker with a different AskUI Controller.
‚ö†Ô∏è If you do not use two Android devices and the AskUI Controller runs on a remote system, you must change the URLs in the uiControllerDeviceList.
When you start your run with this configuration you will see that the *.test.ts files will be executed in parallel and ONLY once. Each worker will generate a separate report, giving you detailed insights into the execution.
The important thing is that each worker is completely independent and encapsulated. This means the setup process from askui-helper.ts will run separately for each worker! This ensures that the workflows do not interfere with each other.
Conclusion
With a little bit of Jest configuration and multiple AskUI Controllers you can parallelize the execution of your AskUI Workflows.
If you have questions or need support, do not hesitate to join our Community.
Post Summary: Have you ever needed to run your AskUI Workflows in parallel on multiple devices to speed up the execution?

Name: Performance and Load Testing Tools for Agile Web Automation
Post Body:
The importance of continuous testing and automation for faster release cycles and improved software quality is undeniable. However, one crucial aspect that receives limited attention is the selection and integration of performance and load testing tools within Agile workflows.

This post addresses that gap, exploring the crucial role of performance testing tools in web automation testing, particularly in Agile environments.

Why Performance Matters in Agile

Agile methodologies prioritize rapid iterations and frequent releases. However, this accelerated pace can sometimes come at the expense of performance if not properly managed.  Performance issues, if left unaddressed, can lead to:

  • Poor User Experience: Slow-loading web pages, application crashes, and unresponsive features frustrate users and damage brand reputation.
  • Lost Revenue: Performance problems can directly impact business revenue, especially for e-commerce sites, where even minor delays can lead to abandoned shopping carts.
  • Scalability Challenges: As user traffic grows, performance bottlenecks can become more pronounced, hindering the application's ability to scale effectively.

Integrating Performance Testing into Agile Sprints

The iterative nature of Agile development presents both challenges and opportunities for performance testing. Traditional performance testing, often conducted in isolated phases, can be too slow and cumbersome for Agile's rapid release cycles.  A more effective approach involves:

  • Shift-Left Testing:  Incorporate performance testing early in the development cycle, ideally within each sprint. This allows for early detection and remediation of performance issues.
  • Continuous Performance Monitoring: Implement tools to monitor application performance continuously, providing real-time insights into key metrics and alerting teams to potential problems.
  • Automated Performance Tests: Integrate automated performance tests into the CI/CD pipeline, ensuring that each code change is evaluated for its performance impact.

Selecting the Right Performance and Load Testing Tools

Numerous performance and load testing tools are available, each with its strengths and weaknesses. Key factors to consider include:

  • Supported Technologies: The tool should be compatible with the technologies used in your web application, including programming languages, frameworks, and databases.
  • Ease of Use: Choose tools with intuitive interfaces and scripting capabilities to minimize the learning curve for your team.
  • Scalability:  The tool should be able to generate realistic load scenarios to simulate high user traffic and identify performance bottlenecks under stress.
  • Reporting and Analytics: Select tools that provide comprehensive reports, dashboards, and visualizations to help you analyze performance data and identify trends.
  • Integration with Agile Tools: Ensure compatibility and integration with your existing Agile development tools, such as Jira, Jenkins, or Azure DevOps.

Some widely-used performance and load testing tools for web automation testing include:

  • JMeter: An open-source Java-based tool, JMeter is highly versatile and supports a wide range of protocols and applications. It offers extensive scripting and reporting capabilities.
  • LoadRunner: A commercial tool from Micro Focus, LoadRunner is known for its scalability and enterprise-grade features, supporting complex load scenarios and integrations.
  • Gatling: An open-source Scala-based tool, Gatling emphasizes performance and scalability, offering a DSL for creating test scripts and generating detailed reports.

Beyond Tool Selection: Best Practices

Successfully integrating performance and load testing tools into Agile web automation involves more than just tool selection. Key best practices include:

  • Define Clear Performance Goals: Establish specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) performance goals aligned with business objectives.
  • Create Realistic Load Scenarios: Simulate real-world user behavior and traffic patterns to ensure accurate performance testing.
  • Analyze and Interpret Results: Go beyond pass/fail metrics and deeply analyze performance data to identify bottlenecks, trends, and areas for improvement.
  • Collaborate and Communicate: Foster open communication and collaboration between developers, testers, and operations teams to address performance issues proactively.

Conclusion

Performance and load testing are essential components of web automation testing, particularly in Agile environments where speed and quality are paramount. By carefully selecting and integrating the right tools, adopting best practices, and fostering a culture of performance awareness, organizations can ensure that their web applications deliver exceptional user experiences, drive business success, and scale effectively to meet future demands.
Post Summary: The importance of continuous testing and automation for faster release cycles and improved software quality is undeniable.

Name: Preventing a Digital D√©j√† Vu: Regression Testing in Web Automation
Post Body:
The crucial role of regression testing‚Äîverifying that new code changes don't adversely affect existing functionality‚Äîin ensuring software quality, particularly within Agile and DevOps environments that rely on continuous integration and delivery.

Web Applications: The Ever-Evolving Landscape

Web applications are inherently dynamic, subject to frequent updates, feature enhancements, and UI modifications. This constant evolution makes regression testing even more critical for web applications than for traditional software. Each change, even a seemingly minor one, has the potential to introduce unintended consequences, breaking existing functionality or creating visual inconsistencies.

Automating Regression Testing for Web Applications

The dynamic nature of web applications makes web automation testing a natural fit for regression testing. Automated tests can quickly and repeatedly execute test scenarios, simulating user interactions and verifying expected outcomes. This repeatability is essential for catching regressions early in the development cycle.

Benefits of Automated Regression Testing for Web Applications:

  • Faster Feedback Loops: Automated tests can run significantly faster than manual tests, providing rapid feedback to developers on the impact of their changes.
  • Increased Test Coverage: Automation allows for more comprehensive testing, covering a wider range of scenarios and edge cases than would be feasible with manual testing.
  • Reduced Regression Risk:  By consistently executing regression test suites, teams can significantly reduce the risk of regressions escaping into production.
  • Improved Developer Confidence:  Knowing that a robust regression test suite is in place gives developers the confidence to make changes without fear of breaking existing functionality.

Choosing the Right Tools and Frameworks

A wide range of tools and frameworks are available for web automation testing, each with strengths and weaknesses.  Selecting the appropriate tools depends on various factors, including the technology stack, project complexity, team skills, and budget.

Best Practices for Effective Regression Testing in Web Automation:

  • Prioritize Test Cases: Focus on automating tests that cover critical functionality, common user workflows, and areas prone to regressions.
  • Use Meaningful Test Data: Employ realistic and representative test data to ensure that tests accurately reflect real-world usage scenarios.
  • Maintain Test Scripts:  As web applications evolve, keep test scripts up-to-date to prevent false positives or test failures due to outdated locators.
  • Integrate with CI/CD Pipelines:  Automate the execution of regression tests as part of the continuous integration and delivery pipeline to catch regressions early in the process.

Conclusion: A Proactive Approach to Web Application Quality

Regression testing, particularly when automated, is an essential practice for ensuring the quality and stability of web applications. By embracing automation and adhering to best practices, development teams can proactively mitigate the risk of regressions, leading to more robust, reliable, and user-friendly web applications.
Post Summary: The crucial role of regression testing‚Äîverifying that new code changes don't adversely affect existing functionality‚Äîin ensuring software quality.
