Name: QA Automation: A Comprehensive Guide
Post Body:
Welcome to our comprehensive guide on QA Automation! In today's fast-paced digital world, ensuring the quality of software applications is of utmost importance. Manual testing alone is no longer sufficient to meet the demands of rapid development cycles and ever-increasing complexity. This is where QA Automation comes into play.

Building a QA Automation framework is crucial for successful automation. We will guide you through the process of choosing the right framework and setting it up for your specific needs. Additionally, we will share best practices for running your framework efficiently, ensuring optimal results.

Maintaining and upgrading your QA Automation framework is essential to keep up with the evolving technology landscape. We will discuss the importance of regularly checking for updates and provide insights on how to upgrade your framework smoothly. Furthermore, we will address common maintenance issues and offer strategies to overcome them.

To provide you with real-world examples and inspiration, we will showcase case studies of successful QA Automation implementations. These examples will demonstrate how organizations have achieved improved efficiency, reduced costs, and enhanced quality through automation.

In conclusion, we will discuss the future of QA Automation and summarize its importance in the software development process. By the end of this guide, you will have a comprehensive understanding of QA Automation and be equipped with the knowledge to implement it effectively in your projects.

So, let's embark on this journey together, and unlock the power of QA Automation for better software quality and development efficiency!

Understanding the Basics of QA Automation

QA Automation is a discipline within software testing that focuses on automating repetitive and time-consuming tasks in the testing process. It involves the use of specialized tools and technologies to execute test cases, validate software functionality, and identify defects or bugs.

What is QA Automation?

QA Automation refers to the practice of using automated scripts and tools to perform software testing tasks that were traditionally done manually. It aims to streamline the testing process, improve efficiency, and enhance the overall quality of the software being developed.

The Benefits of QA Automation

  1. Increased Efficiency: Automation allows for the execution of test cases at a much faster pace than manual testing. This helps reduce the time required to perform repetitive tasks, enabling testers to focus on more critical aspects of the testing process.
  2. Improved Accuracy: Automated tests follow predefined scripts, reducing the risk of human error and ensuring consistent test results. This leads to more accurate identification and reporting of defects.
  3. Cost Savings: While there may be an initial investment in automation tools and infrastructure, QA Automation can lead to significant cost savings in the long run. Automated tests can be executed repeatedly without incurring additional costs, unlike manual testing that requires continuous effort.
  4. Increased Test Coverage: With automation, it becomes feasible to execute a large number of test cases, covering various scenarios and configurations. This helps uncover more defects and ensures thorough test coverage.
  5. Faster Time-to-Market: By automating repetitive tasks, QA teams can accelerate the testing process, reducing the time required to release software updates. This enables organizations to deliver products to market faster and gain a competitive edge.

When to Use QA Automation?

While QA Automation offers numerous benefits, it is essential to identify the right scenarios where automation can be effectively applied. Some situations where automation can be advantageous include:

  1. Regression Testing: When new features or changes are introduced, regression testing ensures that existing functionality remains unaffected. Automation can help streamline the regression testing process and identify any unintended side effects.
  2. Performance Testing: Automation tools can simulate a large number of virtual users, allowing organizations to test the performance and scalability of their applications under various load conditions.
  3. Data-Driven Testing: In scenarios where multiple test cases need to be executed with different sets of data, automation can efficiently handle variations and speed up the testing process.
  4. Repetitive Tasks: Any testing tasks that are repetitive and time-consuming, such as smoke testing, can be automated to save time and effort.
  5. Cross-platform Testing: Automation tools can be utilized to test applications across different platforms, devices, and operating systems, ensuring consistent functionality.

Potential Challenges in QA Automation

While QA Automation offers significant advantages, it is important to be aware of potential challenges that may arise:

  1. Initial Setup Time: Setting up automation infrastructure and developing scripts can be time-consuming and require technical expertise.
  2. Maintenance Effort: Automated scripts need to be regularly updated to accommodate changes in the application under test. Maintenance efforts can be significant, especially for complex projects.
  3. False Positives and Negatives: Automated tests may sometimes produce false positives (reporting defects that don't exist) or false negatives (missing actual defects). It is crucial to constantly refine and enhance the test scripts to minimize such issues.
  4. Skill Requirements: QA Automation requires a certain level of technical skills and knowledge of automation tools. Training or hiring skilled resources may be necessary for successful implementation.

Despite these challenges, QA Automation remains a valuable approach to enhance software quality, improve efficiency, and drive successful software development projects. In the next section, we will explore the key elements of QA Automation in more detail.

The Key Elements of QA Automation

QA Automation encompasses several key elements that are crucial for its successful implementation. Understanding these elements will provide you with a solid foundation for building an effective QA automation strategy. Let's explore each element in detail:

1. Test Planning and Strategy

Before diving into automation, it is essential to have a well-defined test planning and strategy in place. This involves:

  • Identifying the scope and objectives of automation: Determine which areas of your application will benefit the most from automation and define the goals you want to achieve.
  • Test case selection: Choose the test cases that are suitable for automation. Prioritize test cases that are repetitive, time-consuming, or critical for the application's functionality.
  • Test data management: Ensure that you have the necessary test data available for automation. This includes creating and maintaining a repository of test data that covers different scenarios.
  • Test environment setup: Prepare the test environment with the required hardware, software, and network configurations to accurately simulate the production environment.

2. Automation Framework

An automation framework is a set of guidelines, best practices, and tools that provide a structured approach to automate the testing process. It includes:

  • Test script development: Develop reusable and modular test scripts using a programming language or an automation tool's scripting language. These scripts should be maintainable and adaptable to changes in the application.
  • Test data management: Implement mechanisms to manage test data, such as data-driven testing, where test data is separated from test scripts and stored in external sources like spreadsheets or databases.
  • Reporting and logging: Incorporate mechanisms to generate comprehensive test reports and log relevant information during test execution. This helps in tracking test results, identifying issues, and providing detailed insights.
  • Error handling and recovery: Define error handling mechanisms to handle exceptions, unexpected situations, and recover from failures during test execution.

3. Automation Tools and Technologies

Choosing the right automation tools and technologies is crucial for successful QA Automation. Consider the following factors when selecting tools:

  • Application compatibility: Ensure that the automation tools are compatible with the technology stack of your application. Different tools may specialize in web, mobile, desktop, or API testing.
  • Test script development support: Evaluate the ease of creating and maintaining test scripts using the automation tool. Look for features like record and playback, script debugging, and a user-friendly scripting interface.
  • Integration capabilities: Check if the automation tool can integrate with other tools in your development and testing ecosystem, such as issue tracking systems or continuous integration servers.
  • Community and support: Research the availability of documentation, forums, and active community support for the automation tool. This will help you troubleshoot issues and stay updated with the latest trends.

4. Test Execution and Reporting

Once the automation framework and tools are in place, test execution and reporting become crucial elements. Consider the following:

  • Test execution management: Schedule and manage the execution of automated test scripts, ensuring proper coordination with the development and release cycles.
  • Test result analysis: Analyze the test results, identify failures or defects, and report them in a structured manner. This helps stakeholders understand the quality and status of the application under test.
  • Defect tracking and management: Integrate your automation framework with a defect tracking system to efficiently track and manage reported defects. This ensures that issues are properly documented, assigned, and resolved.

5. Continuous Improvement and Maintenance

QA Automation is an ongoing process that requires continuous improvement and maintenance. Key considerations include:

  • Test script maintenance: Regularly update and enhance test scripts to accommodate changes in the application. This includes handling new features, bug fixes, and UI changes.
  • Test coverage expansion: Continuously expand the test coverage by identifying new test scenarios, edge cases, and potential areas of improvement.
  • Performance optimization: Optimize test scripts and their execution to reduce the overall test execution time and improve efficiency.
  • Collaboration and feedback: Foster collaboration between the development and testing teams to gather feedback, identify bottlenecks, and implement improvements in the automation process.

By understanding and incorporating these key elements into your QA Automation strategy, you will be well-equipped to achieve efficient and effective test automation. In the next section, we will dive deeper into the importance of QA Automation and the tools and technologies commonly used in the field.

Building a QA Automation Framework

Building a QA Automation framework is a crucial step in implementing effective QA Automation practices. A well-designed framework provides structure, organization, and consistency to the automation process. In this section, we will explore the key considerations and steps involved in building a QA Automation framework.

1. Choosing the Right Framework

Selecting the appropriate automation framework for your project is essential to ensure efficiency and maintainability. Consider the following factors when choosing a framework:

  • Application requirements: Assess the specific needs and requirements of your application. Different frameworks may be better suited for web-based applications, mobile apps, or API testing.
  • Programming language compatibility: Determine if the framework supports the programming language used in your project. This ensures seamless integration with the development ecosystem.
  • Scalability and extensibility: Evaluate the framework's ability to handle future growth and accommodate changes in the application. A flexible and extensible framework allows for easy addition of new test scenarios and functionalities.
  • Community and support: Research the availability of documentation, forums, and community support for the chosen framework. This ensures access to helpful resources and assistance in case of issues.

2. Setting Up Your QA Automation Framework

Once you have chosen a framework, the next step is to set it up for your specific project. Consider the following steps:

  • Environment setup: Prepare the necessary infrastructure, including hardware, software, and network configurations, to support the automation framework. This may involve setting up test servers, virtual machines, or cloud-based resources.
  • Framework installation and configuration: Install the chosen framework and its dependencies. Configure the framework to align with your project requirements, such as defining test directories, configuration files, and logging options.
  • Test data management: Establish a mechanism to manage test data. This may include creating test data repositories, integrating with external data sources, or implementing data-driven testing approaches.
  • Test script development: Begin developing test scripts using the chosen framework. Follow best practices for script organization, code modularity, and maintainability. Implement reusable functions, libraries, or modules to facilitate script development and maintenance.

3. Best Practices for Running Your Framework

To ensure optimal performance and maintainability of your QA Automation framework, it is important to follow best practices. Consider the following recommendations:

  • Test case management: Organize and manage test cases in a structured manner. Use descriptive naming conventions, categorize tests based on functionality or priority, and maintain documentation for easy reference.
  • Test script optimization: Optimize test scripts to improve execution time and efficiency. This includes minimizing unnecessary delays, using efficient locator strategies, and implementing parallel or distributed testing where applicable.
  • Error handling and reporting: Implement robust error handling mechanisms to handle exceptions and failures during test execution. Generate detailed test reports that provide insights into test results, including passed and failed tests, logs, and screenshots.
  • Version control: Utilize a version control system to track changes in your automation scripts. This allows for easy collaboration, rollback to previous versions, and maintaining a history of changes.

With a well-designed and properly configured QA Automation framework, you can streamline your testing process, ensure consistency, and achieve efficient test automation. In the next section, we will explore the crucial aspects of maintaining and upgrading your QA Automation framework to keep up with evolving requirements and technologies.

Maintaining and Upgrading Your QA Automation Framework

Maintaining and upgrading your QA Automation framework is crucial to ensure its effectiveness and alignment with evolving requirements and technologies. In this section, we will explore the key aspects of maintaining and upgrading your framework.

1. Regularly Checking for Updates

Stay up-to-date with the latest updates, patches, and new releases of your automation framework and its dependencies. Regularly check the official documentation, release notes, and community forums for any updates. This helps you benefit from bug fixes, performance improvements, and new features that can enhance your automation process.

2. How to Upgrade Your Framework

When upgrading your QA Automation framework, consider the following steps:

  • Evaluate the impact: Assess the impact of the upgrade on your existing test scripts, test data, and environment. Identify any potential compatibility issues or changes in behavior that may affect your automated tests.
  • Plan the upgrade process: Develop a detailed plan that outlines the steps involved in upgrading the framework. Consider factors such as downtime, resource availability, and the need for backup or rollback options.
  • Test the upgrade: Set up a test environment to validate the upgrade process. Execute your existing test scripts and verify their functionality in the upgraded framework. This helps ensure that your tests continue to function as expected after the upgrade.
  • Update test scripts and configurations: Modify your test scripts and configurations to align with any changes introduced in the upgraded framework. Update any deprecated or obsolete features, functions, or APIs to maintain compatibility.
  • Retest and validate: After making the necessary updates, retest your test scripts to ensure they function correctly in the upgraded framework. Validate that the test results are consistent with the previous version.

3. Dealing with Common Maintenance Issues

Maintenance issues may arise during the lifespan of your QA Automation framework. Here are some common issues and strategies to address them:

  • Script failures: Monitor and analyze test failures to identify the root cause. Update and improve your test scripts to handle any changes in the application or environment that may be causing failures.
  • Changing application interfaces: If the application's user interface (UI) undergoes changes, such as layout modifications or new elements, update your test scripts accordingly. Implement robust and flexible locators to ensure script stability.
  • Test data management: Regularly review and update your test data repositories to ensure they reflect the current state of the application. Remove obsolete or redundant test data and add new data as needed.
  • Performance optimization: Continuously monitor and optimize the performance of your test scripts and framework. Identify and address any bottlenecks or resource-intensive operations that may impact test execution time.
  • Collaboration and knowledge sharing: Foster collaboration between team members involved in maintaining the automation framework. Encourage sharing of best practices, lessons learned, and updates on changes or issues encountered.

By proactively maintaining and upgrading your QA Automation framework, you can ensure its longevity, adaptability to changing requirements, and optimal performance. In the next section, we will explore case studies and examples of successful QA Automation implementations to provide you with real-world insights and inspiration.

Case Studies and Examples of Successful QA Automation

Examining real-world case studies and examples of successful QA Automation implementations can provide valuable insights and inspiration for your own automation journey. In this section, we will explore a few notable examples and discuss the benefits they have achieved through QA Automation.

Case Study 1: Company X - Streamlining Regression Testing

Company X, a leading software development company, faced challenges with their regression testing process. With each release, they had to manually execute a large number of test cases, which consumed significant time and resources. To address this, they implemented QA Automation using a popular automation framework.

By automating their regression testing, Company X experienced several benefits:

  • Efficiency: Test execution time reduced significantly, allowing them to release updates faster without compromising quality.
  • Test Coverage: With automated tests, they were able to cover a broader range of test scenarios, including edge cases and different configurations.
  • Resource Optimization: The automation framework enabled them to allocate their testing resources more effectively, focusing on critical areas of the application.
  • Cost Savings: By reducing manual effort and improving efficiency, Company X achieved cost savings in their testing process.

Case Study 2: Company Y - Continuous Integration and Testing

Company Y, an e-commerce company, implemented continuous integration and testing practices to ensure faster and more reliable software releases. They integrated their QA Automation framework with their version control system and continuous integration server.

The benefits that Company Y achieved through the implementation of QA Automation and continuous integration include:

  • Early Bug Detection: Automated tests were executed with every code change, allowing for early detection and resolution of defects.
  • Improved Collaboration: The integration of automation with the development process fostered collaboration between developers and testers, resulting in faster feedback loops and improved communication.
  • Continuous Feedback: Test results and reports were automatically generated and shared with the development team, enabling them to address issues promptly.
  • Reliable Releases: The combination of automation and continuous integration ensured that only stable and thoroughly tested code was released to production.

Case Study 3: Company Z - Mobile App Testing

Company Z, a mobile app development company, faced the challenge of testing their app across multiple devices and platforms. They implemented a robust QA Automation framework specifically designed for mobile app testing.

The benefits of their mobile app testing automation initiative included:

  • Enhanced Test Coverage: With automation, they could test their app on a wide range of devices, operating systems, and screen resolutions. This ensured comprehensive coverage and a consistent user experience.
  • Rapid Testing: Automated tests significantly reduced the time required for testing, enabling them to release updates more frequently.
  • Improved Device Compatibility: The automation framework helped identify device-specific issues, allowing them to optimize their app's compatibility across various devices and platforms.
  • Scalability: As the number of supported devices grew, the automation framework provided the scalability needed to handle the expanding test matrix.

These case studies highlight the potential benefits and advantages that QA Automation can bring to organizations. By leveraging automation frameworks and best practices, companies can achieve improved efficiency, cost savings, enhanced test coverage, and reliable software releases.

In the next section, we will explore the future of QA Automation, including emerging trends and technologies that are shaping the field.

Conclusion

In conclusion, QA Automation plays a vital role in ensuring the quality and reliability of software applications in today's fast-paced and competitive environment. By automating repetitive and time-consuming testing tasks, organizations can streamline their testing processes, improve efficiency, and deliver high-quality software products to market faster.

Throughout this comprehensive guide, we have covered the basics of QA Automation, including its importance and benefits. We explored the key elements involved in QA Automation, such as test planning and strategy, automation frameworks, tools and technologies, test execution, and reporting.

We also discussed the critical aspects of building, maintaining, and upgrading a QA Automation framework. By choosing the right framework, setting it up correctly, and following best practices, organizations can ensure optimal performance and maintainability of their automation efforts.

Furthermore, we explored real-world case studies and examples of successful QA Automation implementations. These case studies highlighted the tangible benefits that organizations have achieved through automation, including increased efficiency, improved collaboration, cost savings, and reliable software releases.

Looking into the future of QA Automation, we anticipate the continued growth and adoption of automation in software testing. Emerging trends and technologies, such as artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), will further enhance the capabilities of QA Automation, enabling advanced testing techniques and intelligent test generation.

In conclusion, QA Automation is a powerful approach that significantly contributes to the success of software development projects. By embracing automation, organizations can accelerate their testing processes, improve software quality, and gain a competitive edge in the market.

We hope this comprehensive guide has provided you with the knowledge and insights to embark on your QA Automation journey. Remember, successful automation requires careful planning, continuous improvement, and the right combination of tools and strategies. Embrace automation and unlock its potential to transform your software testing practices.

Name: RPA vs. APA (2025 Trends): A Developer's Guide to Agentic Automation
Post Body:
What is Agentic Process Automation (APA)?

Agentic Process Automation (APA) is the leading automation paradigm of 2025, using autonomous AI agents to execute complex, non-deterministic tasks. Powered by advanced multimodal LLMs, these agents understand not just text, but also images, voice, and even UI screen recordings to learn processes and make context-aware decisions without rigid, pre-programmed rules.

This marks a definitive shift from automating static, repetitive actions to orchestrating dynamic, end-to-end business logic. Developers can now configure agents using natural language and APIs, unlocking automation for domains that were previously too complex.

How Does APA Differ From Traditional RPA?

APA fundamentally upgrades RPA by replacing static, rule-based bots with dynamic, intelligent agents capable of handling ambiguity. While Robotic Process Automation (RPA) excels at automating predictable tasks in stable environments, it fails when faced with process variations or unstructured data. APA is built to thrive in these dynamic conditions.

Here is the 2025 technical stack comparison:

RPA vs APA Comparison Table
Feature ü§ñ Robotic Process Automation (RPA) üöÄ Agentic Process Automation (APA)
Core Technology Rule-based scripts, UI automation Multimodal LLMs, Self-Healing Frameworks, GenAI
Task Handling Repetitive, structured, predictable tasks Complex, dynamic, non-deterministic workflows
Adaptability Low. Breaks with UI or process changes. High. Adapts to new information & exceptions.
Decision Making Follows pre-defined `if/then` logic. Autonomous, context-aware decisions.
Setup & Config Developer-led process mapping (code/low-code). Natural language prompts, SOPs, API calls.
Use Case Example Copying data from a spreadsheet to a CRM. Watching a video to learn a task, then executing it.

What Are Multi-Agent Systems in APA?

A multi-agent system is a framework where multiple specialized AI agents collaborate to achieve a complex goal. This architecture is crucial for tackling enterprise-scale problems by deconstructing a workflow into manageable tasks, managed by what is now called AgentOps.

For example, in a content generation pipeline:

  1. Research Agent scours the web for trending topics and data.
  2. Writer Agent drafts an article based on the research.
  3. Editor Agent fact-checks, refines the tone, and formats the output.
  4. Publisher Agent pushes the content to a CMS and schedules it.

This collaborative approach requires robust inter-agent communication protocols and governance, which are central tenets of the emerging AgentOps discipline.

How Do You Manage Agents in Production? The Rise of AgentOps

As organizations move from experimenting with single agents to deploying multi-agent systems, a new discipline has emerged: AgentOps. AgentOps is the DevOps for AI agents, providing the framework for managing the lifecycle of non-deterministic, autonomous systems in production.

Key components of AgentOps include:

  • Deployment & Orchestration: Managing the coordinated deployment of multiple agents.
  • Observability & Monitoring: Tracking agent performance, decision-making processes, and token consumption.
  • Governance & Security: Setting permissions, managing identities, and creating audit trails for agent actions.
  • Prompt Management: Version control and A/B testing for the prompts that define agent behavior.

What Are the 2025 Frontiers in Agentic AI?

The cutting edge of APA in 2025 has moved beyond simple task execution into truly autonomous operation. The two most significant frontiers are:

  1. Self-Healing Workflows: Agents can now detect when a process breaks‚Äîdue to a changed UI element, a deprecated API endpoint, or an unexpected error‚Äîand autonomously find a new solution. For example, if a website's "Submit" button changes its ID, a self-healing agent can analyze the DOM to find the new button and update its own process, requiring zero human intervention.
  2. Dynamic Tool Discovery: Instead of being limited to a pre-defined set of tools (APIs), advanced agents can actively search for and learn to use new tools on the fly. When faced with a novel problem, an agent could find a relevant public API, read its documentation, and integrate it into its workflow to solve the task.

What Are the Evolved Security & Ethical Risks of APA (2025)?

The increased autonomy of APA introduces more sophisticated risks that require an "identity-first" security posture. Agents are a new, complex attack surface within your organization.

Key evolved risks include:

  • Emergent Behavior Bugs: In complex multi-agent systems, the interaction between agents can lead to unforeseen and undesirable outcomes that are difficult to debug.
  • Sophisticated Data Exfiltration: A compromised agent with broad permissions could autonomously navigate internal systems to find and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  • Machine Identity Management: Each agent requires a secure, managed identity with the principle of least privilege. Unsecured agent identities are a primary threat vector.
  • Automation Bias: As agents become more capable, teams may over-trust their outputs, leading to a lack of critical human oversight in high-stakes decisions.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

What is AgentOps and why is it essential for scaling automation?

AgentOps is the set of practices and tools for managing the complete lifecycle of AI agents in a production environment, similar to how DevOps manages traditional software. It is essential because autonomous agents are non-deterministic and require specialized methods for deployment, monitoring, governance, and security to be scaled reliably and safely across an enterprise.

How will APA change software business models?

APA is accelerating the shift from traditional SaaS licensing (per seat, per month) to outcome-based pricing. Instead of paying for access to the software, companies will increasingly pay for the results the agents deliver‚Äîsuch as cost per processed insurance claim, fee per qualified sales lead, or revenue share from automated e-commerce optimizations.

Can APA integrate with existing enterprise systems and APIs?

Yes, robust integration is a core function of APA. Agents are equipped with "tools" that allow them to interact with any system that has an API, enabling them to orchestrate workflows across your entire tech stack, from modern SaaS platforms to legacy enterprise systems.

What skills does my team need to transition from RPA to APA?

The transition requires a skill shift from process scripting to AI-centric roles. Key skills include prompt engineering, API integration management, AgentOps practices, data science for validation, and a strong understanding of system design for building secure and resilient multi-agent architectures.
Post Summary: Agentic Process Automation (APA) uses adaptive AI agents for dynamic workflows, unlike rigid RPA. A 2025 guide to APA vs. RPA, AgentOps & key risks.

Name: Reasoning in the Context of Intelligent Agent AI
Post Body:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) continues to evolve with advancements aimed at enhancing its reasoning capabilities, making intelligent agent AI more sophisticated and human-like. The quest to elevate AI systems from mere pattern recognition to effective reasoning reflects the essence of cognitive abilities that characterize human intelligence. This exploration delves into the fundamental aspects of reasoning in AI, shedding light on its current limitations and innovations such as neurosymbolic AI, which aims to bridge the gap.

Understanding Reasoning in AI

In humans, reasoning is the ability to logically analyze situations, draw inferences, and make informed decisions. It's a critical component of cognition that allows us to interact with the world, solve challenges, and navigate decision-making processes. For AI systems, replicating this ability is crucial to enhance their functionality and reliability in real-world applications.

Challenges Faced by Traditional AI in Reasoning

Traditional AI methodologies have their strengths and weaknesses when it comes to reasoning. Symbolic AI systems, which are based on logic and predefined rules, offer a degree of reasoning but falter when faced with real-world complexity. Their rigidity makes them unsuitable for dealing with the fluid, uncertain nature of real-life scenarios. On the other hand, deep learning, a subset of AI that excels in pattern recognition, lacks the capability to reason beyond learned patterns. It struggles to provide explanations for its outputs and handle common sense reasoning tasks.

The Neurosymbolic AI Approach

To overcome these challenges, neurosymbolic AI proposes a fusion between deep learning and symbolic logic. By integrating the data-driven learning strengths of neural networks with the logical structuring of symbolic AI, neurosymbolic AI aims to achieve a more adaptable and human-like reasoning ability. This combination strives to facilitate understanding and decision-making processes that are both robust and explainable.

Types of Reasoning Targeted by Neurosymbolic AI

The potential of neurosymbolic AI unfolds through various reasoning capabilities it seeks to master:

  • ‚ÄçCommon Sense Reasoning: This involves making logical inferences based on everyday knowledge and experiences, similar to how humans perceive the continuity of objects even when they are out of view.‚Äç
  • Multi-hop Reasoning: This type of reasoning enables AI to connect and draw conclusions from multiple pieces of information or steps, akin to building a narrative or solving complex puzzles.‚Äç
  • Quantitative, Geographic, and Temporal Reasoning: These specialized reasoning forms involve understanding and analyzing numerical data, spatial locations, and temporal sequences respectively, enhancing AI's capability to operate in diverse scenarios.

Logical Neural Networks (LNNs): A Step Forward

A noteworthy development in neurosymbolic AI is the advent of Logical Neural Networks (LNNs). LNNs are designed to incorporate reasoning into neural networks through real-valued logic, which represents uncertainty and the interaction strength among logical clauses. This innovation allows AI systems to perform nuanced and sophisticated reasoning, offering a significant leap from traditional neural networks.

Reasoning and Explainability in AI

Reasoning enhances not only the capability of AI systems but also their transparency. Symbolic reasoning, which relies on explicit rules and logic, improves the explainability of AI. This transparency is vital for building trust and ensuring accountability, especially in critical applications where understanding the rationale behind AI decisions is paramount.

Conclusion

Intelligent agent AI is increasingly driven by the need to possess reasoning abilities parallel to human intelligence. Innovations like neurosymbolic AI aim to imbue AI systems with more adaptable, human-like reasoning abilities, transcending the conventional limitations of traditional AI approaches. As these systems evolve, they promise to make AI applications more relatable, explainable, and ultimately more valuable in our daily lives.
Post Summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) continues to evolve with advancements aimed at enhancing its reasoning capabilities.

Name: Relational Selectors in AskUI
Post Body:
In this tutorial, we will explain how all the different relational selectors work in askui, so you get a thorough understanding of them.

Relational selectors can be difficult and sometimes confusing to work with at first. Sometimes it is even not clear why a specific element will not be selected or why the selector does not seem to work.

After reading this tutorial you will know how to use the full power of all the relational selectors. Additionally, you learn what pitfalls you can fall into and how to avoid them in the future.

In this article we‚Äôll discuss the following relational selectors:

  • above()
  • below()
  • contains()
  • in()
  • leftOf()
  • rightOf()
  • nearestTo()

Prerequisites

  • You have AskUI installed (Windows, Linux, macOS)
  • You can access the Selectorshub practice page

above()

When you want to click on a textfield and it is above an element, like for example a button with the text Submit. You can do it with above(). The following code snippet moves the mouse to the textfield above the Submit-button:

below()
When you want to select a textfield you can do so by finding the correct label, which is often above the textfield. The following code snippet moves the mouse to the textfield below the text Mobile Number:
contains()
For selecting an element, that contains another element, contains() is the right candidate. It is especially useful if you want to select a textfield with a placeholder text inside it. The text inside the textfield is annotated as an element itself.
If you have problems with selecting a specific element, always run annotate() to create a screenshot of all the annotations or use annotateInteractively() to see if you need to use contains().
The following snippet moves the mouse to a textfield based on its placeholder text First Crush which is contained in the textfield:
in()
When you want to target an element that is inside another element you can use in().
The following code snippet moves the mouse pointer to the text of the first textfield AskUI found:
leftOf() and rightOf()
If you want to select an element based on its location left or right of another element you have to use leftOf() or rightOf() respectively.
üí° If you do not specify another filter like withText() then you will get the nearest element. Otherwise, askui retrieves the nearest element that matches the filter!
nearestTo()
Filtering with the nearestTo() filter will return the element nearest to another element. This is useful when the direction is not clear on where to search. Especially responsive designs are prone to wrap elements into a new line where leftOf() and rightOf() would fail.
Additional Considerations About the Distance Metric
The distance is not entirely based on physical distance. If you use an additional filter like withText() it optimizes to find the best match. It also considers special cases, for example, modal dialogs. Therefore the element selected by askui might sometimes be wrong from a user's point of view.
You can use moveMouseTo() like in the following example to see what element a command targets.
Conclusion
Relational selectors are a powerful tool to create robust automation. However, sometimes they are tricky to master.
This tutorial equipped you with the knowledge to use their full power in your automation.
If you have a recurring or persisting issue, don‚Äôt hesitate to ask the community for help!
Post Summary: In this tutorial, we will explain how all the different relational selectors work in askui, so you get a thorough understanding of them. Relationa ...

The New Solution Declarative Logic with Caesr.ai Prompts

Name: Revolutionizing Citrix Application Testing: How AskUI's Vision Agents Break New Ground
Post Body:
In the ever-evolving landscape of software quality assurance, testing Citrix-based applications has long been a significant challenge for QA teams and automation engineers. Traditional test automation frameworks often fall short when dealing with the unique environment of Citrix, leaving many organizations struggling to maintain efficient and effective testing processes. This article explores the limitations of conventional approaches and introduces a groundbreaking solution: AskUI's Vision Agents.

‚Äç

The Citrix Testing Conundrum: Why Traditional Automation Fails

Before diving into the solution, it's crucial to understand why Citrix applications pose such a challenge for traditional test automation frameworks:

‚Äç

  1. Object Recognition Failures: Conventional frameworks rely heavily on selectors to identify UI elements. However, in Citrix environments where applications are delivered as image streams, these selectors simply don't work.
  2. Incompatibility with Virtualized Environments: Many automation tools aren't designed to interact with virtualized applications, leading to unreliable test execution and false positives.
  3. Version Control Nightmares: Keeping test scripts in sync with different versions of Citrix Receiver and XenApp servers is a constant battle, often resulting in brittle tests that break with each update.
  4. Performance Variability: Network conditions and server load in Citrix environments can cause inconsistent test results, baffling traditional frameworks and making it difficult to establish a reliable baseline.
  5. Limited Access to Application Internals: Citrix's abstraction layer prevents direct access to application code, rendering many conventional testing approaches useless and limiting the depth of possible tests.

‚Äç

Introducing AskUI's Vision Agents: A Paradigm Shift in Citrix Testing

AskUI's Vision Agents represent a revolutionary approach to testing Citrix applications, leveraging advanced AI and computer vision technology to overcome the limitations of traditional frameworks. Here's how our solution addresses each of the challenges mentioned above:

  1. Visual Recognition: Unlike selector-based tools, our AI-powered Vision Agents "see" the application just like a human tester would. This visual approach overcomes the fundamental challenge of object recognition in Citrix environments.
  2. Platform Agnostic Testing: Whether your Citrix applications run on Windows, Mac, Linux, or any other OS, our Vision Agents adapt seamlessly, eliminating cross-platform testing headaches.
  3. Version-Independent Automation: Say goodbye to version compatibility issues. Our agents work with what they see, not what version it claims to be, ensuring your tests remain stable across Citrix updates.
  4. Adaptive Performance Handling: Intelligent waiting mechanisms and retry logic ensure stable test execution despite Citrix's performance variability, providing consistent results even in challenging network conditions.
  5. Deep Interaction Capabilities: By interacting with the application at the visual level, our Vision Agents can perform complex testing scenarios that were previously impossible in Citrix environments.

‚Äç

Real-World Impact: AskUI in Action

To illustrate the effectiveness of AskUI's Vision Agents, consider this case study from a Fortune 500 company struggling with their Citrix-based ERP system testing:

  • Test execution time reduced by 75%
  • Test coverage increased from 40% to 95%
  • Defect leakage to production dropped by 80%
  • Release frequency improved from quarterly to monthly

These dramatic improvements showcase the transformative power of AskUI's approach to Citrix testing, enabling organizations to achieve faster, more comprehensive, and more reliable test automation.

‚Äç

Conclusion: Embracing the Future of Citrix Testing

As the software industry continues to evolve, so too must our approaches to testing and quality assurance. AskUI's Vision Agents represent a significant leap forward in the field of Citrix application testing, offering a solution that not only addresses the longstanding challenges of this environment but also opens up new possibilities for comprehensive, efficient, and reliable test automation.

‚Äç

By leveraging AI and computer vision technology, AskUI empowers QA teams to overcome the limitations of traditional frameworks and achieve unprecedented levels of test coverage and reliability in Citrix environments. As organizations increasingly rely on virtualized applications to drive their business processes, solutions like AskUI's Vision Agents will become indispensable tools in ensuring the quality and reliability of these critical systems.

‚Äç

For those looking to revolutionize their Citrix testing processes, embrace automation at a new level, and drive significant improvements in software quality and release cycles, AskUI's Vision Agents offer a compelling path forward. The future of Citrix testing is here ‚Äì are you ready to evolve?

‚Äç

Name: Revolutionizing Workflows with Desktop Automation Software: A Comprehensive Guide
Post Body:
In the digital age, maintaining productivity while managing repetitive tasks can be challenging. This is where desktop automation software comes into play. Designed to automate a myriad of tasks directly on your computer, these solutions streamline activities, enhancing both efficiency and focus.

What is Desktop Automation Software?

Desktop automation software includes tools that exploit the power of automation to perform tasks ranging from simple file manipulations to complex data processes. These solutions mimic human interactions with applications and operating systems, helping users manage workloads effectively.

How Does It Work?

Desktop automation software generally uses two primary methods for automating tasks:

1. Record and Replay: This approach involves recording a user's actions and replaying them to automate tasks.

2. Scripting and Programming: Allows for more complex and customized automation tailored to specific needs through various scripting languages.

This flexibility ensures that both simple and complex automation needs are addressed.

Key Features to Look For

When selecting desktop automation software, consider the following features:

- Task Automation: Simplifies repetitive tasks such as data entry and file management.

- Integration Capabilities: Ensures compatibility across various platforms and applications.

- Scripting Environment: Facilitates customization through scripting languages.

- User Interface Interaction: Automates interactions like clicks and keyboard inputs.

- Error Handling: Provides robust management and recovery from errors encountered during automation.

- Scheduling: Automates tasks based on time or event triggers.

Benefits and Common Applications

Core Benefits

- Time Savings and Productivity: By automating time-consuming tasks, users can allocate more time to strategic activities.

- Accuracy and Cost Efficiency: Reduces the likelihood of human errors and minimizes resource expenditure.

- Scalability: Manages increasing workload without the need for additional manpower.

Typical Applications

- Data processing

- Report generation

- Email management

- Software testing

- Workflow automation

Types of Desktop Automation Software

Open Source Solutions

- Examples: AutoHotkey, SikuliX, Robot Framework

- Characteristics: While customizable, they often require technical expertise for effective implementation.

Commercial Platforms

- Examples: UiPath, Automation Anywhere, WinAutomation

- Characteristics: These provide comprehensive features and professional support, suitable for both individual users and large enterprises.

Implementing Desktop Automation Software

To effectively implement desktop automation software, follow these steps:

1. Identify Automation Tasks: Pinpoint tasks that would benefit from automation.

2. Select Suitable Software: Choose software that aligns with your needs and technical expertise.

3. Learn Software Features: Familiarize yourself with the capabilities and constraints of your chosen software.

4. Design Automation Workflows: Develop clear workflows for the tasks you wish to automate.

5. Create Scripts or Workflows: Build and refine automation scripts or workflows.

6. Test and Debug: Ensure reliability by thoroughly testing and debugging your solutions.

7. Implement and Monitor: Deploy the automation and keep an eye on its performance.

8. Continually Improve: Regularly assess and enhance your automation processes for ongoing effectiveness.

The Future of Desktop Automation

As technology evolves, so too will desktop automation software. Anticipate exciting advancements such as:

- AI Integration: Improving decision-making and data analysis.

- Cloud-Based and Mobile Automation: Offering increased flexibility and accessibility.

- Process Mining: Delivering enhanced workflow insights for optimization.

- Hyper-Automation: Combining multiple technologies to tackle complex processes.

Conclusion

Desktop automation software stands as a formidable ally in the quest for enhanced productivity and efficiency. By choosing the right tools and strategically integrating them into your workflows, you can position yourself to thrive in an increasingly technology-driven world. Future-proof your operations by harnessing the power of AI desktop automation today.

Recommended read: Top 10 Automation Tools for Desktop
Post Summary: Maintaining productivity while managing repetitive tasks can be challenging. This is where desktop automation software comes into play.

Name: Run AskUI Workflow on Your Local Windows Machine with Self-Hosted Runner
Post Body:
ATTENTION: We sunsetted AskUI Studio Workflows for our new Agent Hub. Please check our Getting Started blogpost!

‚Äç

‚Äç

In this guide, we will walk you through the steps that you need for running an AskUI self-hosted runner on your local Windows machine. The AskUI self-hosted runner is a self-hosted component that downloads your workflows from AskUI Studio and runs them on the device it is hosted at. So this guide presumes that you already have an account for the AskUI Studio as well as know how to create a workflow in it. If you don't have an account yet, please first create one here for free.

Table of Content

  1. Install the Remote Device Controller
  2. Create a Workflow in the AskUI Studio
  3. Run AskUI Development Environment (ADE)
  4. Connect Your AskUI Account
  5. Run the Self-Hosted Runner
  6. Run the Workflow in the AskUI Studio

‚Äç

1. Install the Remote Device Controller

First, install the Remote Device Controller with the AskUI Installer.

It will install the following components:

  • AskUI Controller
  • AskUI Development Environment (ADE)
  • AskUI Development Kit (SDK)
  • AskUI Runner (Executing workflows from AskUI Studio)

Here is a more descriptive explanation of the installation process (link to the documentation).

2. Create a Workflow in the AskUI Studio

Now let's create a simple workflow for testing our self-hosted runner on the local Windows machine.

First create a new workflow with the name windows_test, then copy and paste the code below into the Code view:

After pressing the SAVE button on the right top corner, you will have a workflow created in your Steps view:

Quickly explained, this workflow will,
  1. Press the command key, which is equivalent to the windows key.
  2. Type wordpad in the search field of the start menu.
  3. Press the enter key to open the Wordpad app.
  4. Move the mouse cursor to the coordinate 500, 500.
It is a very simple workflow that automates the process of opening the Wordpad app on your local Windows machine and move the mouse cursor to a certain coordinate, yet good enough to ensure that the AskUI self-hosted runner is properly prepared on your local machine.
3. Run AskUI Development Environment (ADE)

  2. Run the command askui-shell (type it and press Enter). This brings you into the AskUI Development Environment (short ADE) where you can configure your installation, start the AskUI Controller, create new AskUI-Projects and run workflows.
4. Connect Your AskUI Account
Run the following command to authenticate and connect your ADE to your AskUI account. Replace the strings with your real credentials.

5. Run the Self-Hosted Runner
To run this workflow on your local Windows machine, we will need to run two different components on the local machine.
First start the AskUI Controller with the command below:

This will start the AskUI Controller and will select the first display(index 0) from the left side as the target display to be automated. You can skip the DisplayNum option if you have only one display.
‚Äç
After running the AskUI Controller, open another PowerShell window and run the command after activating the ADE with askui-shell as same in the previous step:

The Tags option tells the runner which Run from your AskUI Studio it shall fetch the workflow from. We will run our workflow with the exactly same tag in the next step.
6. Run the Workflow in the AskUI Studio
Now let's go back to our AskUI Studio and run the workflow.
Go to the Runs view by clicking the Runs tab on the side.
Then, click the [+ New run] and create a new run with the information below. It is important to give the exact same Tag as we did in the PowerShell in the previous step:

After creating a new run by clicking the CREATE button, the AskUI Runner will start to run the selected workflow on the local Windows machine. Here is the full video of the automation that we run:
Conclusion
Following the steps outlined in this guide, you have successfully set up and run an AskUI self-hosted runner on your local Windows machine. This enables you to automate tasks using workflows created in the AskUI Studio directly on your device. If you need more informations of our ADE and self-hosted runner on Windows, please check out our official documentations listed below:

And if you face issues or get more questions about AskUI, don't hesitate to contact us!

Name: Run AskUI Workflows with Pipedream for Smoke Testing
Post Body:
Dylan Pierce shared an interesting approach to smoke testing at our meetup: Fill out a contact form with the help of Computer Vision & Large Language Models. Especially the vision part was impressive but it lacked one specific feature: Interaction with the form. How can you be sure your form works if you do not try to fill it out and send it?
This is where I thought an AskUI integration into the Pipedream workflow could be useful. AskUI uses visual selectors instead of code selectors and can interact like a human with a form like that. Giving us a real smoke test!
In this blog, I will describe how I integrated AskUI into a Pipedream workflow to benefit for visual selection and user interaction.

Prerequisites

  • AskUI Controller installed and configured on a remote accessible system like Gitpod or a cloud machine. You can use our Try-Out-Repository or install on your own system (Windows, Linux, macOS)
  • Pipedream account and a workflow. Follow their Introduction

What Will We Build? Aka the Use Case

Dylan Pierce showed an awesome use case with Pipedream and Puppeteer, where he implemented a smoke test with the help of AI without writing any selectors by himself. I highly recommend to watch the recording:

¬†Please accept marketing-cookies to watch this video.

Our Use Case: Smoke Test with Visual Selectors

Dylans use case involved querying a Large Language/Multimodal Model to implement the smoke test. We will modify this a little bit to use the visual selectors from AskUI, which do not rely on the specific UI-technology but identify elements through their appearance with an AI vision model.

Here are the steps we will implement:

  • Trigger the smoke test once per day
  • Perform the smoke test with AskUI on a remote system
  • Send an email if the smoke test was successful or not

1. Add a Trigger

The first thing Pipedream wants us to add is a trigger. We add a Schedule trigger that will run our Workflow everyday at 9:00 AM.

2. Prepare a Custom Code Action

AskUI does not have an action in Pipedream. So we will make use of the AskUI node package and run a custom code action. For this we a a _Code action. In this action we will fill out the simple authentication from https://authenticationtest.com/simpleFormAuth/. If we see the success page we will send

We have to do the following steps:

  • Add a property uiControllerUrl, so we do not have to hardcode it into the code
  • Store our credentials in environment variables
  • Import UiControlClient from the AskUI node package
  • Configure the AskUI UiControlClient to use the credentials and the uiControllerUrl

The first thing we want to add to our custom code is the uiControllerUrl. Click Refresh fields so the Configure tab shows up at the start of the action. Here is the relevant code snippet.

Then head over to environment variables and add your workspaceId and accessToken there. You obtained those by following the prerequisites instructions above. You can now setup the connection to the AskUI Controller over the UiControlClient like this. Notice how easy it is to use arbitrary node-packages in Pipedream? I only needed to import UiControlClient and it just worked ü•≥.
Note: The following code also contains the teardown.
3. Write the AskUI Workflow
When you look at our example form, we want to fill out, you notice that we have to do the following things:
  • Write simpleForm@authenticationtest.com into the textfield E-Mail Address
  • Write pa$$w0rd into the next textfield
  • Click the button Log In
  • Validate the success
The less inference we invoke the faster the AskUI workflow will execute. Everything that prompts AskUI to search for an element on the screen invokes inference. So let us try to invoke the inference only once by finding the first textfield for the E-Mail Address. Then we will use keypresses to navigate the form. This is the code to achieve this:
Send an Email
Doing a smoke test without reporting about its success state would not help us. So we will just send us an email with the Send Yourself an Email action. 
As subject we choose Smoke Test State and for the text we reference our success variable we returned in our action above with {{steps.code.$return_value.success}}.
Gitpod As Remote Machine
If you do not have a remote machine ready-to-go you can use a service like Gitpod. We have a prepared Try-Out-Repository which comes with AskUI already setup and a VNC to observe the AskUI workflow. Start the repository in Gitpod over the Open in Gitpod-button and let it finish the predefined AskUI workflow. When it reached the AskUI Docs (docs.askui.com) maximize the browser window in the Simple Browser tab.
Switch to the TERMINAL tab and start the AskUI-Controller with the following command:
Also make sure that you expose the port to the AskUI Controller (open lock icon). Head to the PORTS tab and make the port 6769 public. Then copy the URL and add it as the property uiControllerUrl in the Pipedream action. 
Conclusion
Building a smoke test with Pipedream and AskUI was a practical use case to see how both tools integrate. The simplicity of Pipedream and its ability to integrate JavaScript code and Node packages was helpful. With that AskUI could be setup seamlessly inside an action and connected to an external AskUI Controller.
Post Summary: This blog describes all the steps on how to integrate AskUI into a Pipedream workflow, so we get the benefit of visual selection and user interaction.

Name: Setting up Android Devices for Testing Native Mobile Apps With AskUI
Post Body:
In this tutorial, we will walk you through how to set up an Android device for developing and testing mobile apps running on Android devices. Depending on the testing environment, i.e. whether it is a real Android device or an emulator, the procedure might slightly differ. But the overall process of the setup will be more or less the same.

If you rather want to see AskUI in action on Android with two use cases. Check out the following blog posts:

  • Automate Web Search On Android Device
  • Automate Github 2-factor Authentication With Android Device

Requirements

  • Android Studio installed
  • (optional) Android device, if you want to run your app on a real device

1. Install Android SDK Command-line Tools

If you have the Android Studio installed, you have to verify if you have the Android SDK Command-line Tools and the Android SDK Platform-Tools installed. They both are packages containing several command line tools that are useful for developing apps for Android devices.

To verify the installation of them,

  • Click on the More Actions button, and then
  • Open the SDK Manager

‚Äç

  • Then, select Android SDK from the list on the left side of the window.
  • Go to the SDK Tools tab, and check the Android SDK Command-line Tools and the Android SDK Platform-Tools. After clicking the OK button, it will start to install the tools we have selected.

‚Äç

2. Set up the Test Device

After installing the necessary tools in the Android Studio, we can start to set up the Android device that we want to use for the development.

Set up a Real Android Device

This part is for setting up a real Android device. If you want to use the Android Emulator instead, then you can skip it and go directly to the next step.

To use additional development features in an Android device, we need to enable the Developer Options within the device. To enable the Developer Options, tap the Build Number option 7 times. You can find this option in one of the following locations, depending on your Android version:

  • Android 9 (API level 28) and higher: Settings > About Phone > Build Number
  • Android 8.0.0 (API level 26) and Android 8.1.0 (API level 26): Settings > System > About Phone > Build Number
  • Android 7.1 (API level 25) and lower: Settings > About Phone > Build Number

After enabling the Developer Options, we can enable the USB debugging option. This option will allow the Android Studio and other SDK tools to recognize your Android device via USB. To enable USB debugging, toggle the USB debugging option in the Developer Options menu. You can find this option in one of the following locations, depending on your Android version:

  • Android 9 (API level 28) and higher: Settings > System > Advanced > Developer Options > USB debugging
  • Android 8.0.0 (API level 26) and Android 8.1.0 (API level 26): Settings > System > Developer Options > USB debugging
  • Android 7.1 (API level 25) and lower: Settings > Developer Options > USB debugging

Set up an Android Emulator

If you want to use the Android Emulator for testing purposes, we have to create a virtual device that runs in the emulator. After running the Android Studio,

  • Click on the More Actions button, and then
  • Open the Virtual Device Manager

If no virtual device is created, we can create one by clicking the Create device button on the top left corner of the Virtual Device Manager window.

You will now see the Virtual Device Configuration window. Within the configuration window, you will be asked to:

  • Choose a hardware profile
  • Choose a system image

‚Äç

The hardware profile represents the specification of the hardware that will be used as a virtual device. Various presets of Android devices e.g. Pixel or Nexus are provided. But you can also create your own hardware profile, after which you will be customizing parameters in such:

  • Screen size
  • Resolution
  • Using Hardware buttons (Back, Home, Menu, Volume, etc.)
  • Using On-device sensors (Accelerometer, Gyroscope, GPS)

After choosing a hardware profile, we will be choosing a system image for the Android device. Here we can choose one from a variety of Android images, from the latest Android 13 Tiramisu down to the Android 7 Nougat. If you have the Android studio freshly installed and haven't used it yet, then it will start to download the image after selecting one.

After finishing to create a new virtual device, we will be able to see our new device listed in the Device Manager. Click the device's play button(‚ñ∂Ô∏è) to run it.

‚Äç

3. Set up the ADBKeyboard

Until now, we have prepared our Android device and now we are ready to go for testing our Android app. But before we jump into the test phase, we will set up one more utility that will make the test procedure easier.

ADBKeyboard is a virtual keyboard that can be installed on Android devices. It enables us to type within the Android device by using command lines via adb command line tool.

One noticeable advantage of using ADBKeyboard is that it can also handle base64 encoding, which becomes handy if you want to type Unicode characters such as emojisüî• For more details about this virtual keyboard, see here.

‚Äç

To install the ADBKeyboard on your device,

  1. Download the ADB-Keyboard package from this GitHub Repo
  2. Unzip it.
  3. Find your device:
# make sure that your Android device is connected.
# in case of using the emulator, it should be running
adb devices

     4. Install the ADBkeyboard on the device:

# inside ADBKeyBoard-2.0/
adb -s <your device id> install ADBKeyboard.apk

     5. Configure the ADB Keyboard:

adb -s <your device id> shell settings put secure default_input_method com.android.adbkeyboard/.AdbIME

     6. Enable the ADB Keyboard:

adb -s <your device id> shell ime enable com.android.adbkeyboard/.AdbIME

     7. To check if it is enabled:

Click on a textfield in an app and see if the ADB Keyboard {ON} notification is shown at the bottom of the screen.

4. Done

We are finally done with the preparation for testing apps running on Android devices. In the next post, we will cover a simple test automation case utilizing AskUI on the device we set up in this article.

If you have a recurring or persisting issue while following this tutorial, don‚Äôt hesitate to ask the community for help!
Post Summary: In this tutorial, we will walk you through how to set up an Android device for developing and testing mobile apps running on Android devices..........

Author: Johannes Dienst

Name: Simplifying Automation Reports: Moving from Jest to Caesr AI
Post Body:
IMPORTANT: Transition to AI Agent Reporting

The TypeScript/JavaScript SDK is no longer the primary method within AskUI. It is now the previous generation. This means manual integration of Jest reporters is an obsolete method. We strongly recommend switching automation logic to the Python SDK to leverage the automated reporting capabilities of the Caesr.ai AI Agent platform. Stop writing repetitive configuration files and manual image handling code.

The Old Problem: Heavy Manual Configuration

To generate useful reports (XML, HTML) with the legacy system, developers had to:

  1. Install multiple separate npm packages like jest-junit, jest-html-reporters.
  2. Manually configure the jest.config.ts file to include these reporters.
  3. Write complex TypeScript code to manually process screenshots which converting base64 strings to buffers just to attach them to a report.This process required significant effort to maintain the reporting pipeline.

The New Solution: Automated Reporting with Caesr.ai

Caesr.ai transforms reporting from a manual configuration burden into a default, automated feature.

1. Instant, Rich Reporting

Every workflow executed by the Caesr.ai AI Agent automatically generates a rich report. This report inherently includes:

  • Detailed steps of the AI Agent's execution.
  • Screenshots for every single action performed by the Agent.
  • Assertions and final pass/fail status.

This eliminates the need for any Jest reporter packages, manual configuration files, or buffer processing code.

2. Primary Language Focus

We strongly recommend utilizing the Python SDK which is AskUI's primary language. The system includes native support for Pytest and other common test runners which provides users with sophisticated reporting capabilities and CI/CD integration without requiring them to handle the complex TypeScript/Jest toolchain from previous versions.

Reporting Becomes Automated, Not Configured

The time spent managing jest.config.ts files and manually converting images is over. The implementation of Caesr.ai enables reporting to transition from its current state as a delicate custom setup process into an automated standard function which enables your team to concentrate on automation development instead of reporter configuration.
Post Summary: Caesr.ai eliminates Jest reporters. Switch from Legacy JS/TS to AI Agents for automated, visual test reports via Python.

Name: Simplifying UI Data Extraction and Assertions with Caesr.ai
Post Body:
IMPORTANT Transition to AI Agent Automation

The TypeScript/JavaScript SDK is no longer the primary method within AskUI. It is now the previous generation. We strongly recommend switching automation logic to the Python SDK to leverage the full power of the Caesr.ai AI Agent platform. Stop writing unnecessary control flow functions and start telling the AI what you need.

The Old Problem Complex Code for Data Extraction and Assertions

The previous automation environment needed developers to create complex multi-step code for reliable assertion testing. Developers had to use TypeScript/JavaScript code like regular expressions and array manipulation to parse data extracted by aui.get(), and then rely on external libraries like Jest to check the result. This system complexity resulted in increased test instability and extended maintenance duration.

The New Solution AI-Powered Declarative Verification

Caesr.ai streamlines this entire process.It performs data extraction and conditional logic and verification tasks through its integrated vision and language models which respond to basic natural language instructions. This system eliminates the requirement for manual parsing operations and external assertion libraries

Caesr.ai Prompt Example Replacing Manual Assertion Logic

The AI Agent handles the entire workflow autonomously, from reading the dynamic CAPTCHA to verifying the final state.

Role of the Python SDK
While Caesr.AI is the primary no-code interface for simple tasks, the Python SDK remains the recommended method for developers. It acts as the powerful entry point for advanced users who require deeper integration. This includes setting up the test execution environment or integrating AI workflows into CI/CD pipelines.
For other complex automation examples powered by a single prompt, explore:
  • Caesr: Analyze TikTok Viral Trends
  • One Prompt: Full Website QA
Conclusion
Caesr.ai fundamentally changes how assertions are done. By moving away from brittle TypeScript parsing and external Jest dependencies, you gain robustness and clarity. Trust the AI Agent to handle the extraction and verification, allowing your team to build highly stable UI workflows with minimal code.
Post Summary: Switch from Legacy JS/TS functions to Caesr.AI. AI Agents use natural language to handle all logic and assertions, eliminating code maintenance.
